header: Russia’s War Could Make It India’s World
desc: The invasion of Ukraine, compounding the effects of the pandemic, has contributed to the ascent of a giant that defies easy alignment. It could be the decisive force in a changing global system.
author: Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima

header: Ukraine at war: 2022 in photos.
desc: NA
author: Andrea Kannapell

header: Zelensky’s New Year’s Eve addresses have a strong following among Ukrainians.
desc: NA
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Shashank Bengali

header: Putin and Zelensky will give dueling addresses today with no end to fighting in sight.
desc: Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will share their New Year’s messages as the war grinds on toward its one-year anniversary.
author: Cassandra Vinograd and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia says its officials and officers in Ukraine don’t have to declare income.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
desc: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
desc: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
author: Lara Jakes

header: Ukraine Keeps Downing Russian Drones, but Price Tag Is High
desc: When costly missiles take out cheap drones, the real winner over time may be the country that spends less.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Activist who removed Banksy mural from Kyiv suburb could face prison, police say.
desc: The mural, showing a woman in a bathrobe wearing a gas mask and holding a fire extinguisher, was one of seven artworks painted by Banksy on war-ravaged buildings in and around Kyiv.
author: Javier C. Hernández

header: Putin Prepares Russians for a Long Fight Ahead
desc: The Russian leader has dropped the pretense that life goes on as normal despite the war, evident in the Kremlin’s quick acknowledgment of mass casualties inflicted by Ukraine last weekend.
author: Anton Troianovski and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Defending against Russian drones is expensive, but Ukraine sees the cost as worth it.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Julian E. Barnes, Shashank Bengali and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian prosecutors identify a Russian torture site, adding to a list of more than 50.
desc: NA
author: Andrea Kannapell

header: A U.S.-made long-range rocket system has helped give Ukraine momentum in the war.
desc: Washington delivered the first batch of truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers, known as HIMARS,
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt

header: Deadly strike on Russians in Ukraine exposes Moscow’s military failings.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Away from the spotlight, Ukraine and Russia trade border fire in rural villages.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘Fear Still Remains’: Ukraine Finds Sexual Crimes Where Russian Troops Ruled
desc: Investigators have uncovered widespread evidence of abuse by Moscow’s forces, including rape and forced nudity. Kremlin officials have repeatedly denied accusations of rights violations.
author: Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak

header: For Russian Troops, Cellphone Use Is a Persistent, Lethal Danger
desc: Ukrainian artillery targets Russian soldiers by pinpointing their phone signals. Despite the deadly results, Russian troops keep defying a ban on cellphone use near the front.
author: Alan Yuhas, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yousur Al-Hlou

header: More than 60 percent of Bakhmut has been destroyed, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: Russia has continued to press an offensive aimed at capturing the eastern city, after suffering a string of setbacks elsewhere in Ukraine in recent months.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Lacking precision missiles, Russia is increasing its use of drones, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: Shashank Bengali

header: France promises Ukraine armored vehicles as the U.S. weighs doing the same.
desc: President Emmanuel Macron pledged to provide AMX-10 RC armored vehicles, though Mr. Macron’s office did not specify how many of the vehicles would be delivered or when.
author: Aurelien Breeden

header: Ukraine Claims Heavy Russian Losses in Waves of Missile Strikes
desc: Kyiv says its forces have killed or wounded hundreds of Russian soldiers in a series of pinpoint attacks. Russia has confirmed only one of three waves of strikes.
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert

header: Putin Calls a 36-Hour Cease-Fire, but Ukraine and U.S. Are Skeptical
desc: The cease-fire would coincide with the Eastern Orthodox Christmas on Saturday, but Kremlin adversaries and some analysts call it a ploy for military and political advantage.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia issues the first pardons to prisoners who fought in Ukraine, state media reports.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner paramilitary group, is seen in a video congratulating men for completing their military contracts.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina

header: Ukraine moves toward charging 2 Russian commanders accused of ordering strikes that killed civilians.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson

header: Ukraine recorded its largest annual fall in G.D.P. in over 30 years, a top minister says.
desc: NA
author: Jason Karaian and Enjoli Liston

header: Attacks Continue in Ukraine Despite Russia’s Supposed Cease-Fire
desc: Ukraine never accepted Russia’s unilateral Christmas truce, dismissing it as a hollow ploy, and Russian shelling was as intense as ever in a hotly contested city.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: New Armored Vehicles Will Help Ukraine Take the Fight to Russia
desc: The Western allies’ provision of infantry fighting vehicles signals their support for new offensives in coming months, analysts said.
author: Steven Erlanger and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: The U.S. announces a $3 billion package of military aid to Ukraine, including armored fighting vehicles.
desc: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the administration would also send $682 million to countries on NATO’s eastern flank.
author: Michael D. Shear and John Ismay

header: In a Ukraine Workshop, the Quest to Build the Perfect Grenade
desc: A Ukrainian unit is tinkering with tape, a scale, a 3-D printer and other items to turn a fragmentation grenade into a tank-killer. It’s a steep and risky challenge.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Battered and Strained by War, Ukraine’s Economy Adapts to Survive
desc: After 10 months of Russian destruction, Ukraine’s economy shrank by 30 percent. But companies have packed up and moved, switched products and found support abroad.
author: Liz Alderman

header: Ukrainians Celebrate Orthodox Christmas at a Holy Site Long Linked to Moscow
desc: The sermon, a deeply symbolic moment after months of tension with the Moscow-led branch of the church, came as a cease-fire failed to materialize.
author: Megan Specia

header: Ukraine says recent pledges show that key weapons are no longer ‘taboo’ for its allies.
desc: The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, welcomed pledges this week from France, Germany and the United States of military aid that his government had been seeking for months.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Continued shelling backs up Ukraine’s doubts about Putin’s cease-fire.
desc: NA
author: Megan Specia

header: ‘Fear still remains’: Ukraine finds sexual crimes where Russian troops ruled.
desc: Russian officials have denied abuses against civilians despite widespread evidence of sexual violence by Russian troops documented by Ukrainian and international investigators.
author: Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak

header: The U.S. imposes sanctions on more Iranians over the drones Russia is using in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Julian E. Barnes

header: Now Fighting for Ukraine: Volunteers Seeking Revenge Against Russia
desc: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Without Hesitation, Ukraine Goes Toe to Toe With Russia in Bakhmut
desc: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung

header: Putin’s Efforts to Divide the West Over Ukraine Fall Flat
desc: A cease-fire proposal seemingly aimed at splintering Western unity has instead been met with Western escalation, underscoring Moscow’s diplomatic struggles.
author: Max Fisher

header: The House Is in Ruins, but the Holiday Feast Goes On
desc: Orthodox Christmas came under harsh circumstances in Ukraine this year. For families like the Kovtuns, living next to the remains of their shell-struck home, celebration was an act of defiance.
author: Megan Specia

header: Ukraine rejects Russia’s claim of a deadly strike on troops in the east.
desc: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it had carried out a strike that “killed 600 people,” but no evidence has emerged to support the claim.
author: Megan Specia

header: The pace of offensives has been slower in the east.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Shifting strategy, Ukraine goes toe to toe with Russia in Bakhmut.
desc: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: A Russian strike on a market killed two women, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In the bitter cold, a Ukrainian team searches ‘not for bodies, but for souls.’
desc: NA
author: Nicole Tung and Evelina Riabenko

header: The invasion of Ukraine has contributed to the ascent of India, a giant that defies easy alignment.
desc: NA
author: Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima

header: Russia Replaces Commander for Ukraine War, as Signs of Dissension Grow
desc: Allies of President Vladimir V. Putin contradicted each other about battlefield progress, as a war command shake-up put another Kremlin loyalist in charge.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine strips a wealthy pro-Russian politician of his citizenship.
desc: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician who is close to the Russian president, was handed over to Moscow in September as part of a prisoner swap while awaiting trial on treason charges.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: What Does It Mean to Provide ‘Security Guarantees’ to Ukraine?
desc: A postwar Ukraine will want to ensure that Russia does not attack again. But is there anything short of full NATO membership that will satisfy Kyiv and deter Moscow?
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Russian Mercenary Group Says It Has Taken Contested Ukrainian Town
desc: With a harsh winter putting sweeping offensives on hold, the war has shifted back to bloody battles of attrition like the one for the small city of Bakhmut and the smaller town of Soledar.
author: Megan Specia, Ivan Nechepurenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Come On In, the Internet Is Fine: Kyiv Workers Get Online in Unlikely Spots
desc: Sporadic power outages have people resorting to makeshift office spaces in the Ukrainian capital. Stores have set up power hubs, and workers are getting comfortable doing their jobs in home furnishing displays.
author: Megan Specia

header: Russia posts a $47 billion budget deficit for 2022, its second highest in the post-Soviet era.
desc: The budget gap reached 3.3 trillion rubles, or 2.3 percent of the size of the Russian economy, according to the country’s finance minister.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Britain is considering sending tanks to Ukraine, in what would be a first.
desc: The British Challenger II could become the first Western-made main battle tank to be provided to Ukraine since Russia invaded almost a year ago.
author: Lara Jakes and Stephen Castle

header: Poland says it’s willing to provide Ukraine with German-made tanks, adding pressure on Berlin to agree.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: Foreign volunteers seeking revenge against Russia bolster the ranks of Ukraine’s Army.
desc: NA
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Putin’s efforts to divide the West over Ukraine are falling flat.
desc: NA
author: Max Fisher

header: Western Tanks Appear Headed to Ukraine, Breaking Another Taboo
desc: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.
author: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger

header: Russia’s Claim to Seize a Ukrainian Town Exposes Rifts Among Forces
desc: After Russia’s Defense Ministry said its troops had taken Soledar, a leader of the Wagner mercenary group accused the military of stealing credit. Ukraine said its forces were still fighting there.
author: Alan Yuhas, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Gen. Valery Gerasimov, the new head of Russia’s war effort, is the Kremlin’s top military commander.
desc: In a statement announcing the appointment, the Russian Defense Ministry hinted at a renewed campaign in Ukraine.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The transfer of an Israeli missile-warning system to Ukraine is delayed, ambassador says.
desc: NA
author: Isabel Kershner

header: Western tanks appear to be headed to Ukraine, breaking another taboo.
desc: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.
author: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger

header: A funeral near Kyiv bears witness to the toll of fierce fighting in Ukraine’s east.
desc: Neither Russia nor Ukraine divulges its battle losses, but both have said the other is paying a heavy price in lives. The loss of one Ukrainian commander offers one small window on the cost of the battle for the east.
author: Photographs and Text by Lynsey Addario

header: As Poland and Britain weigh sending tanks to Kyiv, pressure on other allies mounts.
desc: U.S. and European defense officials have long held concerns that giving Ukraine tanks could prompt Russia to escalate the war.
author: Anushka Patil

header: The internet is a lifeline in Ukraine. Keeping it running is a key government focus, a minister says.
desc: NA
author: Megan Specia

header: A worldwide recession might be averted, the I.M.F. chief says, but the war in Ukraine is a caveat.
desc: NA
author: Alan Rappeport

header: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
desc: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
desc: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: Dead, Alive or Devastated After Russian Strike on Apartments
desc: Rescue workers were still digging through the ruins of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.
author: Megan Specia and Nicole Tung

header: Russia unleashes dozens of missiles on Ukraine.
desc: Russian forces have targeted Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and other cities with missile and drone attacks off-and-on for months, devastating the power grid and forcing rolling blackouts.
author: Megan Specia

header: Britain Says It Will Give Ukraine Tanks, Breaching a Western Taboo
desc: Western countries have balked at giving Ukraine tanks and other powerful weapons. As increased spring fighting looms, that seems to be changing.
author: Megan Specia and Ben Hubbard

header: ‘I’m Sorry, We’re From Moscow.’ In Bali, Warring Sides Learn to Cohabitate
desc: Thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have fled their homelands for Bali. But even in a tropical paradise, the war is ever-present.
author: Sui-Lee Wee and Nyimas Laula

header: Rescuers rush to save people buried in rubble of a building destroyed by a Russian missile.
desc: A 15-year-old girl was among the 14 people killed. The search for survivors continues.
author: Nicole Tung, Megan Specia and Cassandra Vinograd

header: For Families and Detainees in Russian-Occupied Areas, a Grim Wait
desc: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: A United Europe Weathers Crises, but Deeper Challenges Remain
desc: Differences on NATO and E.U. enlargement, energy and climate, and relationships with the United States, China, Russia and Ukraine will prime Davos talks.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: The U.K. says it aims to give tanks to Ukraine, a move long resisted by allies.
desc: NA
author: Lara Jakes

header: As Humanitarian Crises Escalate, So Do Demands to End Them
desc: David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee, says the global refugee crisis “is manageable, not insoluble.”
author: Claudia Dreifus

header: Ukraine’s first lady urges leaders at Davos to use their influence to help her country.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Megan Specia

header: Death Toll of Russian Strike in Dnipro Rises to 40, Ukraine Says
desc: The authorities said 34 people remained missing after three days of searching for the living and the dead at an apartment building struck by a Russian missile in Dnipro.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia

header: What 70 Years of War Can Tell Us About the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
desc: Despite some postmodern features, the fighting resembles a type of conflict from decades past: wars fought between nations in which one does not conquer the other outright.
author: Max Fisher

header: A Wagner fighter defects to Norway, promising to expose Russian war crimes in Ukraine.
desc: The rare defection by a former member of the notorious Russian paramilitary force could aid investigations into Moscow’s atrocities.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Henrik Pryser Libell and Michael Schwirtz

header: At a Pivotal Moment in Ukraine, U.S. and Allies Will Decide on Sending Arms
desc: Ukraine has a narrow window of time to retake more territory ahead of an expected Russian spring offensive, but to do that it needs weapons like armored vehicles.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: The Australian Open bans Russian and Belarusian flags.
desc: Tennis has struggled with its response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which Belarus has supported.
author: Natasha Frost

header: Germany’s defense minister resigns after criticism over her handling of the war.
desc: The minister was repeatedly attacked over public blunders and her handling of the war in Ukraine. She is the most senior member of Olaf Scholz’s government to resign.
author: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: The U.N. confirms civilian deaths in Ukraine have surpassed 7,000, but says the real toll is far higher.
desc: The total includes only those that U.N. investigators have been able to corroborate, and does not include the dozens killed in Saturday’s strike on Dnipro.
author: Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: The war in Ukraine upended energy markets. What does that mean for the climate?
desc: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.
author: David Gelles

header: School Is in Session, Power or Not
desc: In Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, Russian strikes and power outages are part of the school day. Teachers and students press on with resolve.
author: Megan Specia and Laura Boushnak

header: Ukraine says it will take time to determine the cause of a helicopter crash that killed 14 people.
desc: The helicopter came down near a kindergarten and a residential building outside Kyiv, killing the interior minister and others and causing severe damage.
author: Ben Shpigel and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Minister Killed in Helicopter Crash Oversaw Some Security Forces
desc: Denys Monastyrsky was the highest-ranking Ukrainian government official to die since Russia’s invasion began in February last year.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine’s Allies Pledge to Send Major Infusion of Military Aid
desc: As representatives from dozens of countries prepared to attend a war-planning meeting in Germany, the talk was of missiles, air defense and — above all — tanks.
author: Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: Why Tanks Are Tripping Up the West
desc: Western nations are amping up offensive military power for Ukraine in almost every category except the one Kyiv says it needs the most. Here’s why.
author: Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: Helicopter Crash Kills Ukrainian Minister in Blow to Wartime Leadership
desc: The crash in a suburb of Kyiv killed at least 14 people, officials said, including the interior minister, a top adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky, who oversaw Ukraine’s domestic security.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia

header: ‘Tragedies are outpacing life’: In a video address at Davos, Zelensky mourns the dead and pleads for help.
desc: At the start of his address, the Ukrainian president called for a minute of silence to honor the country’s minister of internal affairs.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Tinkering with tape, a scale and a 3-D printer, one Ukrainian unit is on a quest to build the perfect grenade.
desc: NA
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: C.I.A. Director Visited Kyiv for Meeting With Zelensky
desc: The director, William J. Burns, has made periodic visits to Ukraine to meet with intelligence officials and to exchange information with the country’s president.
author: Julian E. Barnes

header: South Africa to Hold Naval Drill With Russia and China Amid Ukraine War
desc: The 10-day naval exercises are a show of diplomatic independence for South Africa, which is part of an alliance with Brazil, Russia, India and China — known as BRICS.
author: Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon

header: Ukraine allies announce new military aid ahead of a key meeting of defense ministers.
desc: NA
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Allies Fail to Agree on Sending Tanks to Ukraine
desc: Officials tried to play down the rift. But Germany is still insisting it will not be the country to take the first step alone, for fear of incurring Moscow’s wrath.
author: Erika Solomon

header: Safe at Home in Dnipro, Until a Russian Missile Struck
desc: Despite the ever-present danger of war, life in Ukraine proceeds almost normally at times. Then, suddenly, it all changes, as it did in Dnipro last weekend after a missile struck an apartment complex.
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: A Hit French Novel Tries to Explain Putin. Too Well, Some Critics Say.
desc: A popular novel, “The Wizard of the Kremlin,” presents a sympathetic portrait of the Russian leader, critics say, raising concerns that it might influence national policy toward the Ukraine war.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Amid Mounting Frustration With Germany, Ukraine Holds Out Hope It Will Get Tanks
desc: While Germany has not yet made a decision on whether to send Leopard 2s to Ukraine, a Kyiv official said his country’s soldiers would begin training on them.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: What are Stryker vehicles? And why is the Pentagon sending them to Ukraine?
desc: The vehicles weigh about 20 tons and have eight wheels. They move quickly while carrying soldiers and can be armed with a variety of weapons.
author: John Ismay

header: A Navy SEAL who deserted in 2019 has been killed in Ukraine.
desc: The man, Daniel W. Swift, was the latest American to be killed in Ukraine, where hundreds of international volunteers have gone to fight in Ukraine’s defense.
author: Anushka Patil

header: Multiple factors make providing Western tanks to Ukraine problematic.
desc: NA
author: Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: The Biden administration is warming to helping Ukraine target Crimea.
desc: NA
author: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

header: A Russian missile lands outside a kindergarten in eastern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: The U.S.’s top general says it would be ‘very, very difficult’ to eject Russian forces from Ukraine this year.
desc: NA
author: Ben Shpigel

header: In Moscow, a Quiet Antiwar Protest With Flowers and Plush Toys
desc: Amid Russia’s crackdown on resistance to the war in Ukraine, some have dared to lay bouquets and other offerings at a statue of a Ukrainian poet, protesting the recent Russian strike on civilians in Dnipro.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Germany’s Reluctance on Tanks Stems From Its History and Its Politics
desc: A post-Nazi aversion to war and a commitment to promoting peace through engagement combines with an old fixation on Russia and a deep aversion to leading militarily.
author: Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

header: Zelensky vows action against corruption after a minister is fired for embezzlement.
desc: The Ukrainian leader said the dismissal should serve as notice to officials whose actions “violate the principle of justice.”
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Zelensky Urges Ukrainians to Remain Unified
desc: On a day meant to mark the unification of Ukraine in 1919, the country’s leader said it was vital for Ukrainians of all regions to bind together.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: For families and detainees in Russian-occupied areas, the wait drags on.
desc: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Germany’s reluctance to send tanks to Ukraine stems from its history and politics.
desc: NA
author: Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

header: Analysis: The NATO alliance is holding strong on Ukraine, but fractures are emerging.
desc: NA
author: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

header: Poland says permission from Germany is ‘a secondary issue’ with Leopard tanks.
desc: NA
author: Ron DePasquale

header: In Kyiv, one tour guide aims to change attitudes about Soviet-era architecture.
desc: NA
author: Brendan Hoffman

header: In Dnipro, a seemingly ordinary Saturday turned tragic in an instant.
desc: NA
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Poland asks Germany’s permission to send its Leopard tanks to Ukraine.
desc: Germany says it will decide shortly on whether to send advanced tanks to Kyiv, which has been pleading for such equipment for months.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Several Ukrainian officials are fired amid a scandal involving military purchases.
desc: A deputy defense minister was among those removed from their posts, as was a deputy prosecutor general who caused a scandal by taking a wartime vacation to Spain.
author: Michael Schwirtz, Maria Varenikova and Cassandra Vinograd

header: Germany and U.S., Dropping Resistance, Will Send Battle Tanks to Ukraine
desc: Although welcomed by Kyiv as a critical weapon to expel Russia’s invasion, the Leopard 2 tanks from Germany and Abrams tanks from the United States are unlikely to arrive soon.
author: Erika Solomon, Peter Baker and Eric Nagourney

header: Ukraine Fires Officials Amid Corruption Scandal, as Allies Watch Closely
desc: As it fights Russia’s invasion, Ukraine depends for its survival on aid from Western nations, which have concerns about endemic graft and how the money is used.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Maria Varenikova

header: Western Tanks Are Coming to Ukraine, but Will They Be Enough?
desc: Western allies have pledged to send at least 105 tanks, far less than Ukraine says it needs, and it may be months before they join the battle.
author: Lara Jakes and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Ukraine says that its forces have retreated from Soledar after an intense battle.
desc: Ukraine’s military acknowledged a gain for Russian forces that brings them closer to encircling the strategic eastern city of Bakhmut.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Schwirtz

header: Two British men went to Soledar. Neither came back.
desc: Andrew Bagshaw, 47, and Chris Parry, 28, were part of an ad hoc cohort of foreigners who have gone to Ukraine despite little to no experience with combat situations.
author: Anushka Patil

header: Russia’s War Breathes New Life Into a Cold War Symbol
desc: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a news network originally set up as a C.I.A. operation early in the Cold War, is experiencing a renaissance and making a case for its independence.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Spanish Police Arrest a Man in Letter Bomb Case
desc: A 74-year-old Spanish man made and sent all of the six letter bombs himself, the authorities alleged, though the “participation or influence of other people” was not ruled out.
author: Euan Ward and José Bautista

header: The M1 Abrams, headed to Ukraine, is the main U.S. battle tank.
desc: NA
author: John Ismay

header: In Wave of Strikes, Russian Missiles Kill 12 Across Ukraine
desc: Russia’s forces once again pounded energy infrastructure and other civilian sites, a day after the United States and Germany pledged to send dozens of tanks to Ukraine.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Alan Yuhas

header: Ukraine War Accelerates Shift of Power in Europe to the East
desc: The war has raised the influence of Central and Eastern European countries with negative views of Russia, amplified calls to expand the E.U. and NATO, and dimmed the power of France and Germany.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Russia Outlaws a News Site and a Rights Group, Stifling Critical Voices
desc: The Kremlin stepped up efforts to banish independent sources of news. Prosecutors labeled Meduza, a popular news site, “undesirable,” so anyone who aids or promotes it can be prosecuted.
author: Alan Yuhas

header: As Ukraine awaits promised tanks from the West, the fighting continues.
desc: NA
author: Lauren McCarthy

header: Russia says it will switch four occupied Ukrainian regions to Moscow time.
desc: Russia, which has many time zones, is seeking to integrate the regions after illegally annexing them in September.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russian shelling kills eight civilians in Donetsk Province in eastern Ukraine.
desc: Some military experts and Ukrainian military leaders have said they expect that Moscow will launch a new offensive in the Donbas region in the coming weeks or months.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: White House officials tell senators that Ukraine is committed to anti-corruption.
desc: The firing of several top members of the government in Kyiv had stirred concern over how U.S. aid was being used.
author: Michael Crowley

header: Ukraine shot down 47 Russian missiles, the country’s air force said.
desc: NA
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: The war is shifting the balance of power from ‘Old Europe’ to newer nations of the east.
desc: NA
author: Steven Erlanger

header: After securing tanks, Ukraine turns to the next weapon on its wish list: Fighter jets.
desc: NA
author: Shashank Bengali

header: Fighting Rages in Eastern Ukraine Over Critical Supply Routes
desc: While the heaviest fighting is still around the city of Bakhmut, in recent days Russian forces have stepped up assaults on a strategic town farther to the south.
author: Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz

header: Russia and Ukraine Battle for Control of Villages Near the Key City of Bakhmut
desc: The area is a flash point in an offensive that Moscow views as crucial for its goal of seizing the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Kharkiv Got Some Breathing Space, but Still Doesn’t Breathe Easily
desc: For the past four months, residents have slowly trickled back into the reclaimed city. But signs of the conflict — and the chance that it might return — are everywhere.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

header: Czech Republic Elects Retired NATO General as Its President
desc: Petr Pavel, a political novice, defeated Andrej Babis, a populist business tycoon and former prime minister, in the first of several important European elections this year.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Israel Launched Drone Attack on Iranian Facility, Officials Say

header: The I.M.F. says the war poses a risk to a resilient global economy.

desc: NA

header: Putin uses a World War II anniversary to vow victory in Ukraine.

desc: NA

desc: NA

header: Russian officials accuse Ukraine of launching several attack drones over its territory.
desc: The Ukrainian government publicly follows a policy of deliberate ambiguity about strikes on Russian territory.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russia’s New Offensive Sends Conscripts Into the Teeth of Ukraine’s Lines
desc: A month into the campaign, Russian forces have barely budged despite forays by small units in fields, pine forests and ruined towns.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Tyler Hicks

header: In Central Asia, Blinken Will Urge Distance From Russia, and Ukraine War
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is making the first trip by a Biden administration cabinet official to the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.
author: Edward Wong, Anton Troianovski and Stanley Reed

header: Zelensky says the situation in Bakhmut is ‘getting more and more difficult.’
desc: The eastern city, which had a prewar population of around 70,000 people, has become a focus of the fighting, with both sides pouring in troops and taking significant losses.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Satellite imagery shows possible damage to a Russian surveillance plane in Belarus.
desc: The British Ministry of Defense said that the loss of the plane would be significant if confirmed, “as it is critical to Russian air operations for providing an air battle space picture.”
author: Christoph Koettl

header: Blinken Finds Receptive Leaders in Central Asia, Where Russia Seeks Aid
desc: The U.S. secretary of state’s diplomatic mission is part of a broader Biden administration effort to strengthen support for Ukraine, or at least push neutral nations to refrain from aiding Russia.
author: Edward Wong and Andrew Higgins

header: Ukraine War Squeezes Street Snack in Uganda
desc: The price of a rolex — eggs rolled up in flatbread — has almost doubled in the last year.
author: Abdi Latif Dahir

header: China Welcomes Belarusian Leader Amid Concerns About Ukraine
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s visit comes shortly after the United States accused Beijing of preparing to give arms and ammunition to Russia to help its war on Ukraine.
author: David Pierson

header: In First Wartime Meeting, Blinken Confronts His Russian Counterpart
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he told Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, that Moscow must end its war against Ukraine and return to a nuclear arms control treaty.
author: Edward Wong

header: Russian partisans with ties to Ukraine say they briefly took control of a village in Russia.
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia canceled a trip to be briefed on the incursion near the border with Ukraine. He described the incident as a “terrorist” attack.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine is sending reinforcements after the Russians surrounded Bakhmut on three sides.
desc: In recent weeks, Russian forces have been rushed to the front line, helping Moscow seize more villages and towns.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: A Ukrainian Mayor Disappeared, but Questions of His Loyalty Did Not
desc: Traitor or hero? A decision by the former mayor of Kherson to remain in his post under Russian occupation has divided opinion, even after he vanished.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Ivor Prickett

header: In an Epic Battle of Tanks, Russia Was Routed, Repeating Earlier Mistakes
desc: A three-week fight in the town of Vuhledar in southern Ukraine produced what Ukrainian officials say was the biggest tank battle of the war so far, and a stinging setback for the Russians.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Incursion in Russian Border Town Puts Kremlin on Emergency Footing
desc: An armed group said it briefly took control of a border town in Russia’s Bryansk region, but what actually took place there was shrouded in conflicting claims.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Marc Santora and Alan Yuhas

header: Here are the basics of the feud between Russia’s top mercenary chief and the Kremlin’s military leaders.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia steps up attacks in Bakhmut as Ukraine pledges reinforcements.
desc: NA
author: Daniel Victor

header: At U.S. Base in Germany, Ukraine’s Military Conducts War Games
desc: The exercises come as Ukraine is emerging from a winter that was expected to offer a lull in fighting. Ukraine’s president appeared to signal recently that the country is preparing for a major offensive.
author: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

header: Ukraine Reinforces Embattled Bakhmut, but Mission Is Unclear
desc: Amid persistent rumors of Ukrainian withdrawal from the war’s most prolonged battle, officials said nothing about the size or purpose of the reinforcement.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Edward Wong

header: Whirring Into Action in Ukraine’s Skies
desc: Against the odds, Ukraine’s helicopter brigades are not only still operational, but are an inspirational component of its war effort.
author: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: The U.S. will send $400 million in new military aid to Ukraine, including precision-guided rockets.
desc: Western leaders have warned of a looming artillery shortage for Ukraine as its troops burn through thousands of shells each day in trying to push back Russian forces.
author: Lara Jakes and Helene Cooper

header: As fighting intensifies, Ukraine says its forces are still holding Bakhmut.
desc: The city of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, has taken on a deep symbolic resonance for both sides, which have incurred staggering numbers of casualties.
author: Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak

header: As Ukraine Clings to Bakhmut, What’s Its Strategy and What’s at Stake?
desc: Ukraine is determined to hold the eastern city as long as it can. How high a price is it willing to pay? What might force its withdrawal? And what would a retreat look like — and mean?
author: Marc Santora

header: The E.U. Offered to Embrace Ukraine, but Now What?
desc: The European Union and NATO have promised a path to membership for the embattled country. But real partnership will hold risks and benefits for both sides.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: A Visit to One of the War’s Most Violent Front Lines
desc: I recently traveled to the Donetsk region, where I got to know some of the soldiers. Here’s what they told me.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: The U.S. attorney general meets with Zelensky during a surprise visit to Ukraine.
desc: A major topic of talks was how to hold Russia accountable for any war crimes committed over the past year.
author: Glenn Thrush

header: With Ukraine Under Pressure in Bakhmut, Fight Becomes a Battle Over Roads
desc: Ukraine’s military said that Russia was inching ahead in its efforts to encircle the city but that it had beaten back several attacks on supply routes.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Nobel Prize Is No Defense Against Jail for a Winner in Belarus
desc: Ales Bialiatski, last year’s Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has been sentenced by Belarus to 10 years in prison, on charges that rights advocates have dismissed as politically motivated.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Germany’s Scholz Visits Washington Amid Worries Over Ukraine ‘End Game’
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz arrives Friday for a quiet working visit with President Biden, sparking speculation that they will discuss tough questions on how to end the war.
author: Erika Solomon

header: Ukrainian Soldiers, Nearly Encircled, Push Russians Back
desc: The battle for Bakhmut is not over — at least not yet. Ukrainian assault brigades offered Moscow a bloody reminder of that over the weekend.
author: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: They’re Exporting Billions in Arms. Just Not to Ukraine.
desc: As traditional weapons suppliers like the U.S. face wartime production shortages, South Korea has stepped in to fill the gap, while trying not to provoke Moscow.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: He Heeded Russia’s Call to Enlist. Five Months Later, He Was Dead.
desc: Pvt. Ivan Ovlashenko was one of at least 16,000 Russians who have died in Ukraine, more than in the Soviets’ Afghan war. It’s getting hard for the Kremlin to cover that up.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: A video shows the apparent execution of a Ukrainian prisoner of war.
desc: Ukrainian officials said they had opened a war crimes investigation.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russian Forces Attack Bakhmut From Three Directions
desc: Russian troops and Wagner mercenaries are still waging a fierce battle to encircle the eastern Ukrainian city, officials said.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Signals It Will Keep Battling for Bakhmut to Drain Russia
desc: Gradual Russian advances and high Ukrainian casualties have fueled talk of a retreat from the eastern city, but Ukrainians say Russian losses are worse, a reason to keep them fighting.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Claims a Drone Strike on a Military Target Inside Russia
desc: The claim was a rare public acknowledgment of a cross-border attack in Russian territory.
author: Marc Santora

header: Estonia Election Delivers Vote of Confidence for Ukraine Aid
desc: The party of Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, who has pushed the West to send more weapons to Kyiv and impose tougher penalties on Moscow, took about double the tally of the second-place finisher.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: This Is What Trench Warfare on the Front Line Is Like
desc: The Ukrainian military calls it the zero position, where Russian soldiers are close enough to see, and where an old war tactic takes a horrific toll.
author: Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora

header: Seeking Stability at Yoga Classes in Kyiv
desc: Air-raid sirens might disrupt the calm, but yoga classes in Kyiv continue to find eager participants. Here’s who I met.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Conditions at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant have deteriorated, Ukraine says.
desc: The International Atomic Energy Agency last week warned that the situation at the plant, which Moscow seized soon after its invasion in February, was “precarious.”
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A wide range of pro-Ukrainian groups operate in the shadows of the war.
desc: The new intelligence suggesting the involvement of such a group in explosions that damaged the Nord Stream pipelines last year is extremely vague.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian incursions into Russia have usually been kept quiet, until now.
desc: At the funeral for four fighters killed in Russia and finally returned to Ukraine, fellow soldiers talked openly about the mission.
author: Marc Santora and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Ukraine Claims Bakhmut Battle Is Wagner’s ‘Last Stand’
desc: Ukrainians say Russia’s Wagner mercenary group is running low on fighters recruited from prisons, used in attacks on Bakhmut, where Ukraine has also endured heavy losses.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: At War: Images From an Expanding Ukraine Conflict
desc: A photographic chronicle of the second year of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: NA

header: Germany treads a careful line over reports that a pro-Ukrainian group sabotaged the Nord Stream pipeline.
desc: Defense Minister Boris Pistorius said Germany was waiting for further investigations, after reports in The New York Times and other news outlets.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Ukraine Needs Shells, and Arms Makers Want Money. Enter the E.U.
desc: Ukraine is firing artillery shells faster than manufacturers can make them. Brussels is working on a plan to increase production by guaranteeing big advance purchases.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Russia Lacks Firepower to Keep Advancing, U.S. Intelligence Chief Says
desc: While both Ukrainians and Russians say the pitched battle for the city of Bakhmut could determine whether Russia can pursue more of an offensive, Western officials are skeptical.
author: Julian E. Barnes, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: The Background on the Protests in Georgia
desc: Demonstrators worry that Georgia is reneging on commitments to foster closer ties with Europe and moving toward closer ties with Russia.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Shashank Bengali

header: A Russian Editor Evades Putin’s Censorship
desc: Galina Timchenko, founder of the dissident news site Meduza, has adapted as the information noose has tightened since the invasion of Ukraine.
author: Alison Smale

header: Russia Blasts Ukrainian Cities, Including Biggest Use of Advanced Missiles
desc: Of 81 missiles fired, six were hypersonic weapons, among Russia’s newest and most advanced, which are all but impossible to shoot down.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Latvia is sending cars seized from drunken drivers to Ukraine.
desc: The first batch of cars will start making their way on Friday, the head of a charity helping deliver them said, and will go to the military and hospitals.
author: Emma Bubola

header: A U.S.-developed rocket system becomes one of Ukraine’s most lethal weapons.
desc: A New York Times team was given rare access to witness an M270 in operation near the front line.
author: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Evelina Riabenko

header: Satellite images show widespread destruction after heavy fighting in Bakhmut
desc: New satellite pictures of the eastern Ukrainian city, where a brutal battle has been raging for months, showed bridges over a strategically important river had been destroyed.
author: Elena Shao and Marco Hernandez

header: The E.U. and NATO promised Ukraine a path to membership. But real partnership holds risks.
desc: NA
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Crowds gather to mourn ‘Da Vinci,’ a young Ukrainian soldier killed near Bakhmut.
desc: Dmytro Kotsiubailo, better known as “Da Vinci,” was killed near Bakhmut on March 7.
author: Marc Santora

header: Changing His Tune for Mother Russia
desc: As the Kremlin seeks to remake Russia’s institutions to comport with its militaristic worldview, cultural figures are picking a side. One singer made his choice — and is growing rich.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Georgy Birger

header: Questions surround Russia’s use of hypersonic missiles in its latest attack.
desc: Moscow on Thursday fired the largest number of the air-launched weapons used in a single wave since the war began a year ago.
author: John Ismay, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine highlights its desire for air defense weapons after Russia’s latest strikes.
desc: NA
author: Shashank Bengali

header: The leaders of Britain and France met in Paris with Ukraine on the agenda.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson

header: Front Line Shifts in Russia’s and Ukraine’s Battle for Bakhmut, Analysts Say
desc: Britain’s defense intelligence agency said that Russian forces had taken control of most of Bakhmut’s east, but advances farther west might be challenging.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Ukraine Steps Up Calls for Evacuation of Kupiansk Under Relentless Russian Shelling
desc: Attacks on the northeast town in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine continued on Sunday.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: In Fields Sown With Bombs, Ukraine’s Farmers Risk Deadly Harvest
desc: Some who till the breadbaskets of Ukraine have already lost three seasons of planting to war. With mines and cluster bombs widely scattered, normal harvests seem far in the future.
author: Michael Schwirtz, Stanislav Kozliuk and Ivor Prickett

header: War in Ukraine Puts Centuries of Swiss Neutrality to the Test
desc: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
author: Erika Solomon

header: From ‘Hitler’ to ‘Sharing One Fate’: Saudi-Iran Pact Could Transform the Middle East
desc: Both countries as well as the broader region have much to gain from the reset in relations — if the agreement truly holds.
author: Vivian Nereim

header: China’s Role in Iran-Saudi Arabia Deal Shows Xi’s Global Goals
desc: Brokering a rapprochement between the Middle Eastern rivals underscores the Chinese leader’s ambition of offering an alternative to a U.S.-led world order.
author: David Pierson

header: An Activist’s Flight Reveals Widening Repression in Algeria
desc: Four years after a popular uprising fueled hopes for change and real democracy, the country’s government is using vaguely defined statutes to round up hundreds.
author: Constant Méheut

header: As Russian Shelling Intensifies, True Liberation Eludes Ukrainian City
desc: Months after Ukrainian forces pushed out Russian occupiers, the city of Kherson remains very much a war zone.
author: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

header: The Black Sea is a crucial theater in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
desc: Long dominated by Russia’s navy, the Black Sea has been the scene of Ukrainian defiance. It’s also been a rare point of agreement between the two countries.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian Attacks Along a Wide Arc of Ukraine Yield Little but Casualties
desc: Moscow’s forces have stepped up artillery and infantry assaults across eastern Ukraine, trying to improve their position before either side attempts a major breakthrough.
author: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Zelensky names a soldier whose death was captured on video a Hero of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Randy Pennell

header: Grain deal, Bakhmut and more: What to watch for this week.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson

header: International Court to Open War Crimes Cases Against Russia, Officials Say
desc: The cases before the International Criminal Court would accuse Russia of abducting Ukrainian children and of deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure.
author: Marlise Simons

header: ‘Navalny’ wins the Oscar for best documentary as the dissident’s wife issues a defiant message.
desc: The film followed Aleksei Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as he investigated his own near-fatal poisoning in 2020.
author: Daniel Victor

header: ‘Russia Outside Russia’: For Elite, Dubai Becomes a Wartime Harbor
desc: In the exclusive neighborhoods and palatial shopping malls of the United Arab Emirates’ biggest city, wealthy Russians can build a new life without having to cut ties to their home country.
author: Anton Troianovski and Andrea DiCenzo

header: He heeded Russia’s call to enlist. Five months later, he was dead.
desc: NA
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: Bakhmut remains of ‘paramount strategic importance’ to Ukraine, its top general says.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Burns Through Ammunition in Bakhmut, Putting Future Fights at Risk
desc: The military is using thousands of artillery shells a day as it tries to hold the eastern city, which could jeopardize a planned springtime campaign.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

header: Ukraine’s allies are set to discuss the dwindling ammunition supply.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine’s Allies Promise Weapons for Spring Counteroffensive
desc: Ukraine and Russia are both running low on ammunition, and both are scrambling to replenish their stocks and gain a competitive edge.
author: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt, Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Poland Says It Will Arm Ukraine With Warplanes, Raising Stakes
desc: The Polish leader said he would send jets designed by the Soviet Union to help Ukraine fend off Russian forces. It was unclear if other allies might follow suit.
author: Andrew Higgins and Lara Jakes

header: Putin claims the West is trying to ‘pull apart’ Russia.
desc: NA
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Why the Black Sea Is a Flashpoint Between Russia and the West
desc: It has long been a theater of competition between Russia and the West, a dynamic supercharged by the Ukraine war.
author: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman

header: What We Know So Far About the Downed American Drone
desc: The incident was the first known physical contact between the Russian and American militaries since the war in Ukraine began.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In describing the drone incident, U.S. officials stick to specific language.
desc: “Intercepts” are common, but statements issued after the encounter in the Black Sea this week suggest that Russia’s actions were unusual.
author: Eric Schmitt

header: Salvaging the drone that crashed in the Black Sea presents big obstacles, experts say.
desc: The operation could take weeks and cost tens of millions of dollars, and just locating the drone might not be easy.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Poland says it foiled a Russian spy ring seeking to sabotage arms shipments to Ukraine.
desc: The sabotage, the Polish interior minister said, was planned “at the request of Russian intelligence” and “aimed at paralyzing the supply of equipment, weapons and aid to Ukraine.”
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Arrest Warrant From Criminal Court Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity
desc: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.
author: Mark Landler

header: More MIG fighters will help Ukraine, but what Kyiv really wants are F-16s.
desc: Ukrainian officials and military analysts do not expect the MIG jets pledged so far by Poland and Slovakia to fundamentally alter the battle in the skies.
author: Marc Santora

header: Slovakia follows Poland in pledging warplanes for Ukraine, but most of its jets are in disrepair.
desc: The news came after Poland’s president said that his country would send MIG-29 jets, a move that appeared intended to open the door to more advanced warplanes from NATO allies.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: As Dreams of Peace Wither, Nightmares Flourish in Ukraine’s Sleep
desc: A survey asked hundreds of wartime Ukrainians what they dreamed about. Many replied: the war.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: In Stoic Ukraine, Stony Faces Are Starting to Crack and to Cry
desc: Although Ukrainians excel at putting up a brave front, a tremendous amount of suffering is being kept bottled up and sometimes bursts out.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Russia Signals It Will Take More Ukrainian Children, a Crime in Progress
desc: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin highlights a practice that the Kremlin has not concealed and says will continue.
author: Marc Santora and Emma Bubola

header: China’s Leader Will Visit Putin Under Shadow of War-Crimes Warrant
desc: Global divisions over Russia’s actions in Ukraine widened as China said Xi Jinping would go to Russia to help make peace, in a move widely seen as a stark sign of support for President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: Alan Yuhas

header: Defiant Putin Visits Mariupol, a City Razed by Russian Forces
desc: The trip was the Russian leader’s first to territory his forces captured since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and came shortly after an international court issued a warrant for his arrest for war crimes.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrés R. Martínez

header: Who is Maria Lvova-Belova?
desc: As Vladimir V. Putin’s commissioner for children’s rights, she has led Russia’s efforts to deport thousands of Ukrainian children.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Here’s what to know about the I.C.C.’s arrest warrant for Putin.
desc: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin and a Russian official for war crimes. Here’s a look at the warrant and what it could mean for Russia’s leader.
author: Marlise Simons, Charlie Savage and Anushka Patil

header: Putin and Xi Celebrate Ties Unbroken by Russia’s War in Ukraine
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, to Russia, briefly noting Beijing’s peace plan for Ukraine but stressing Moscow and Beijing’s enduring partnership.
author: Valerie Hopkins, Chris Buckley and Anton Troianovski

header: An explosion in Crimea destroyed Russian cruise missiles, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: Kremlin-appointed authorities in Crimea denied the claim saying that all the drones had been “aimed at civilian objects.”
author: Carly Olson and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The White House Authorizes $350 Million in Military Aid for Ukraine
desc: The latest infusion of aid is aimed at giving Ukraine much needed ammunition ahead of a planned spring offensive.
author: Carly Olson

header: Inch by Bloody Inch in Ukraine War, Russia Is Closing In on Bakhmut
desc: Sending unarmed “diggers” into the front lines and near certain death, Russian troops are making slow but inexorable progress.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: E.U. Officials Agree to Supply More Artillery Shells to Ukraine
desc: European leaders adopted a plan to provide Ukraine with badly needed shells, while replenishing their own national stocks.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Xi heads to Russia saying little about Ukraine.
desc: China is calling Xi Jinping’s visit a “trip for peace,” but he is unlikely to risk straining the country’s ties with Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: Chris Buckley and Anton Troianovski

header: Besides China, Russia Maintains Warm Relations With These Countries
desc: India and South Africa are among the nations that have not criticized Russia for invading Ukraine. Some others have supplied military aid.
author: Daniel Victor

header: Why China and Russia Are Closer Than Ever
desc: This week’s meeting between the leaders of China and Russia marks another key moment in the deepening relationship between the two powers.
author: Nicole Hong

header: Xi refrains from mentioning Ukraine in Moscow, instead focusing on generalities.
desc: NA
author: Anton Troianovski

header: To Ukraine, Xi’s push for peace seems at odds with the battlefield reality.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Xi and Putin Bind China and Russia’s Economies Further, Despite War in Ukraine
desc: On the second day of the Chinese leader’s state visit in Moscow, Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin declared an enduring economic partnership, in an effort to insulate their countries from punitive Western measures.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Chris Buckley

header: In a Brother Act With Putin, Xi Reveals China’s Fear of Containment
desc: Instead of focusing on a solution to the war in Ukraine, the Chinese leader’s visit to Moscow reinforced China and Russia’s shared opposition to American dominance.
author: Chris Buckley

header: Its Forces Under Siege, Ukraine Hits Distant, Russian-Held Crimea
desc: The Crimean Peninsula, which Russia seized in 2014, has been a staging ground for other attacks and an increasingly attractive target for Ukraine.
author: Marc Santora

header: Japan’s Prime Minister Becomes Latest G7 Leader to Visit Ukraine
desc: Fumio Kishida, who has been seeking a more active role for his country in international affairs, made an unannounced trip to meet with Ukraine’s president.
author: Ben Dooley and Victoria Kim

header: Ukrainian Soldiers Speed Through U.S. Training on Patriot Missiles
desc: At the end of a 10-week crash course at a U.S. Army base in Oklahoma, the Ukrainians are essentially running their own training in preparation for the front lines.
author: Eric Schmitt

header: She Posted Online About the War in Ukraine. Then She Faced a Prison Term.
desc: The case of Olesya Krivtsova, a Russian student who ended up on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list, has underscored the perils of using social media to criticize the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Zelensky Makes Morale-Boosting Trip to Bakhmut
desc: The Ukrainian leader also condemned a deadly Russian missile attack against an apartment building in Zaporizhzhia.
author: Marc Santora, Valerie Hopkins, Enjoli Liston and Victoria Kim

header: The Monks in the Middle of Russia’s War in Ukraine
desc: A war-fueled rift between the living clerics loyal to Moscow and those loyal to Kyiv is coming to a head.
author: Marc Santora

header: Canada extends the deadline for Ukrainians to apply for a temporary visa program.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson

header: Britain’s Prince William thanks Poland’s president for supporting Ukraine.
desc: He met with President Andrzej Duda on the second day of his visit to Poland.
author: Anushka Patil

header: A Refuge for Russians and Ukrainians, Bali Rethinks Its Open-Door Policy
desc: After multiple accounts of tourists behaving badly, its governor wants Russia and Ukraine to lose access to Indonesia’s visa-on-arrival program.
author: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono

header: Stolen Valor: The U.S. Volunteers in Ukraine Who Lie, Waste and Bicker
desc: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.
author: Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Slovakia Makes Its First Delivery of Pledged Soviet-Era Fighter Jets to Ukraine
desc: The arrival of the aging MIG-29s is not expected to significantly change battlefield dynamics, and the planes will most likely be used for spare parts for Ukraine’s own Soviet-era jets.
author: Anushka Patil

header: ‘Give Me an Abrams!’ Ukrainian Tank Commanders Grow Impatient.
desc: For now, they are holding on with inferior Soviet-era tanks, but relish the idea of taking on the Russians with modern Western battle tanks.
author: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: From Combat in Ukraine to Rehab in Minnesota, With No Time to Waste
desc: War has forced Ukraine to become skilled at treating amputees, but there are too many for its overtaxed medical workers. Some are finding their way to a prosthetics clinic in Minnesota.
author: David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

header: As Zelensky Visits Kherson, World Bank Says Ukraine Needs $411 Billion to Rebuild
desc: The bank released a significantly higher figure as European Union leaders approved plans to provide Kyiv with one million artillery shells over the next 12 months.
author: Enjoli Liston, Victoria Kim and Monika Pronczuk

header: No Letup in Bakhmut as Ukraine and Russia Brace for Battles Elsewhere
desc: Both sides expect a Ukrainian offensive while the Bakhmut fight continues, but the head of the Wagner mercenary group said Russia must be clearer about its goals.
author: Shashank Bengali and Anton Troianovski

header: A conference to help locate Ukraine’s abducted children is being organized, the E.U.’s top official says.
desc: NA
author: Monika Pronczuk

header: Spain’s prime minister plans to visit Beijing for talks on China’s contentious peace proposal.
desc: China has been trying to build support for its proposal to start peace talks, but Ukraine’s allies hold that its call for an immediate cease-fire would only help Russia consolidate territorial gains.
author: José Bautista

header: Ukraine pushes for phone talks between Zelensky and China’s leader.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Bakhmut Battle ‘Could Be Stabilized,’Ukrainian General Says, but Fighting Remains Intense
desc: The battle for the city has been the most violent of recent months, creating an increasingly dire humanitarian crisis for the few remaining civilians.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Victoria Kim

header: They Left Town as Convicts. Will They Be Buried as Heroes?
desc: As thousands of ex-prisoners fight and die in Ukraine, honoring their memory is becoming a patriotic imperative in Russia. But some committed crimes their old neighbors cannot forget.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: Putin Says He Could Put Tactical Nuclear Weapons in Belarus by Summer
desc: The proposal from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, talked of since last year, would be provocative without changing the West’s battlefield calculus in Ukraine.
author: Anton Troianovski, Vivek Shankar and Andrew Higgins

header: An Anxious Asia Arms for a War It Hopes to Prevent
desc: Doubts about both China and the United States are driving an arms race in the Indo-Pacific with echoes of World War II and new levels of risk.
author: Damien Cave and Chang W. Lee

header: Before 12:01 A.M., Migrants on Foot Dashed Into Canada to Beat Deadline
desc: A freer era of migration into Canada ended on Saturday when officials stopped accepting asylum petitions from people who walk in at unofficial crossings.
author: Jane Gottlieb and Ian Austen

header: Who Will Take Care of Italy’s Older People? Robots, Maybe.
desc: The Western world’s oldest population is facing a crisis of caregivers. Some are looking for a little helping, plastic, hand.
author: Jason Horowitz

header: Restoring a Giant Plane: Ukrainian Resilience or Folly?
desc: Ukraine, with far more pressing needs, plans to rebuild the colossal Mriya cargo plane, a symbol of pride that was destroyed last year in a battle for its airfield.

header: Amid Ruins and Explosions, Some Ukrainians Refuse to Leave Home
desc: In Avdiivka, as in Bakhmut and other devastated places on the front lines, most residents left long ago, but there are holdouts.
author: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: A Plan to Lift the Fog of War in Ukraine? It’s in the Cards.
desc: To help soldiers quickly distinguish friend from foe, the Pentagon is issuing playing cards with pictures of 52 different NATO weapons systems.
author: Lara Jakes

header: The Ukrainians hold on with old tanks, but relish the idea of advancing with modern Western battle tanks.
desc: NA
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Torture and Turmoil at Ukrainian Nuclear Plant: An Insider’s Account
desc: The former director of Europe’s largest nuclear facility describes abuse of Ukrainian workers and careless practices by the Russians who took control of the plant.
author: Marc Santora

header: Over 4,300 Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia or Russian-occupied areas, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: Carly Olson

header: U.N. Official Heads to Ukrainian Nuclear Plant as Safety Fears Grow
desc: The official met with President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss the Zaporizhzhia plant, amid worries that a Ukrainian offensive could raise the already-high risk of disaster.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Promised tanks arrive in Ukraine from Germany and Britain.
desc: The deliveries of advanced equipment are expected to assist Kyiv with a potential spring offensive.
author: Carly Olson

header: Blinken warns that calls for a cease-fire in Ukraine by Russia’s partners may be ‘a very cynical trap.’
desc: NA
author: Edward Wong

header: Ukraine claims to shoot down 12 of 12 Russian drones over Kyiv.
desc: NA
author: Daniel Victor

header: Ukrainians in a Hidden Command Post See Bakhmut Going Their Way
desc: Ukrainian commanders said that Russia exhausted all its reserves on the eastern city, though soldiers said the cost in lives had been steep.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Ukraine Goes Dark: Images From Space Drive Home the Nation’s Anguish
desc: A satellite operated by NASA and NOAA bares how Russia’s drones and missiles knocked out the nation’s power.
author: William J. Broad, Sarah Kerr, Marc Santora and Tim Wallace

header: The head of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog visits Ukraine’s embattled Zaporizhzhia plant.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Soldiers Massing Near Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, U.N. Official Warns
desc: Amid signs of offensives and counteroffensives, concern is rekindling about what it will mean for the biggest nuclear plant in Europe.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine, Poland and six other countries call for Meta and other tech giants to fight disinformation.
desc: An open letter from eight prime ministers calls for action “against disinformation that undermines our peace and stability.”
author: Patricia Cohen

header: How Ukraine’s Battered Steel Industry Galvanized Its War Effort
desc: Ukraine’s iron- and steel-producing factories have made body armor, helmets and armored plates for vehicles — and steelworkers risked their lives rolling out heavy machinery at the beginning of the war to help physically block the Russian advance.
author: Finbarr O’Reilly

header: The U.S. imposes sanctions on a Slovakian accused of trying to broker a Russia-North Korea arms deal.
desc: A White House spokesman said the man would be in violation of several U.N. Security Council resolutions.
author: Katie Rogers

header: Germany, stressing its long-term commitment, promises additional military aid to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Christopher F. Schuetze

header: In Berlin, King Charles of Britain lauds Germany’s support for Ukraine.
desc: “Together we must be vigilant against threats to our values,” the British monarch said to German lawmakers.
author: Carly Olson

header: Ukraine says it will use legal means to remove pro-Russian monks from a revered Orthodox site.
desc: Representatives of the monks and priests have vowed to ignore an eviction order.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: For Ukrainian Convicts, a Strange Odyssey Through Russian Prisons
desc: When Russian troops left Kherson, they took with them 2,500 Ukrainian convicts from local prisons. For some, it was the start of a bewildering, five-country journey highlighting the war’s absurdity.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Losses in Ukraine, and Its Gains
desc: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
author: Chris Buckley

header: Ukraine Charges a Leading Ukrainian Vicar, as Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine
desc: The charge against the religious leader, Pavlo Lebid, came as Russian forces hit the town of Avdiivka, among 70 other targets, along the front line.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

header: Bracing for Fights Ahead, Russia and Ukraine Step Up Recruitment
desc: After a winter of intense battles and heavy losses in Ukraine’s east, both Russia and Ukraine are taking steps to replenish their depleted forces.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Alan Yuhas

header: Sanna Marin, Finland’s Political Rock Star, Could Be Slipping
desc: Parliamentary elections on Sunday are extremely tight among the three biggest parties, with the prime minister’s Social Democrats in a tough fight to lead the next government.
author: Johanna Lemola and Steven Erlanger

header: In a secret command center, Ukrainians say they have exhausted Russia’s relentless assaults on Bakhmut.
desc: NA
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Soon after Russia invaded Ukraine, Finland laid out its argument for joining NATO.
desc: A Finnish defense official said his country had long prepared to defend itself but that Russia’s war changed the calculation.
author: John Ismay

header: Russia and Ukraine make recruitment pushes as they prepare for a long war.
desc: NA
author: Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Russia assumes the presidency of the U.N. Security Council on Saturday.
desc: NA
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: Belarus, echoing Russia, raises the prospect of nuclear conflict.
desc: Because of the conflict in Ukraine, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said, “a third world war loomed on the horizon with nuclear fires.”
author: Andrew Higgins

header: New Weapons Aren’t Enough: The Challenges of Ukraine’s Coming Assault
desc: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.
