header: The Children’s Rights Advocate Accused of Russian War Crimes
desc: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Inside the Ukrainian Frontline City Residents Are Refusing to Leave
desc: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
author: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: Russia Accuses Dissidents and Ukraine of Killing Pro-War Blogger
desc: The authorities detained a woman they said had delivered the bomb, hidden in a statuette, that killed the blogger, and called it the work of antigovernment activists and Ukraine.
author: Anton Troianovski, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Influential Russian Military Blogger Is Killed in St. Petersburg Bombing
desc: Vladlen Tatarsky represented a radical wing of pro-invasion bloggers and activists who backed Moscow’s war but also criticized what they saw as the flaws in the Russian Army.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Wagner claims ‘legal’ control of Bakhmut, while Ukraine says it is still fighting.
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner group founder, said Russian forces had raised their country’s flag in the center of Bakhmut.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Strange Days at the U.N. as Russia Takes the Helm of the Security Council
desc: The monthlong presidency of an organization dedicated to preserving world peace is now in the hands of a nation waging the biggest land war in Europe in decades.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: Russian Shelling Kills 6 as Assault Stalls in Ukraine’s East
desc: The attack came after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that permitting Moscow its monthlong presidency of the Security Council showed “the complete bankruptcy of such institutions.”
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia’s assault in eastern Ukraine appears stalled.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The St. Petersburg bombing is the latest attack that Russia has blamed on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Daniel Victor

header: Zelensky Gets Hero’s Welcome in Poland, Cementing Ukraine’s Ties
desc: Polish leaders backed Ukraine’s bid for NATO membership, but even without that, Russia’s invasion is making the alliance’s eastern flank more united, and more important.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Finland Joins NATO in a Power Shift and Rebuke to Putin
desc: The Nordic country became the alliance’s 31st member on Tuesday, spurred by the war in Ukraine, in a strategic setback for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: ‘If I Stop Now I’ll Have Nothing’: The African Students Who Fled Ukraine
desc: One student, accepted at a Georgian school, had her visa application rejected. Another, 18 months from his medical degree, received a deportation order from Germany. “It just makes you want to stop in the street and scream,” he said.
author: Monika Pronczuk

header: Macron, in China, Says He’ll Urge Xi to Work for Peace in Ukraine
desc: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke of the need for a “shared responsibility for peace and international stability.”
author: Roger Cohen

header: ‘Outrageous’: Russia Accused of Spreading Disinformation at U.N. Event
desc: Moscow used its rotating presidency of the Security Council to host a session on deported Ukrainian children, leading some officials to walk out.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: China’s Ambassador to the E.U. Tries to Distance Beijing From Moscow
desc: The ambassador, Fu Cong, said China was not on Russia’s side in the war in Ukraine. “‘No limit’ is nothing but rhetoric,” he said, referring to a statement from last year about the countries’ relationship.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Steven Erlanger

header: What We Know About the Bomb Attack on a Russian Pro-War Blogger
desc: The killing of Vladlen Tatarsky came at a volatile moment in Russia, and could herald a further crackdown on dissent. Here’s how the case has developed so far.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Near Bakhmut, Death Is Delivered Remotely and Watched on Video
desc: Using aerial drones to spot the enemy and direct artillery fire has become a staple of war for Ukraine and Russia, especially in the savage fight for control of Bakhmut.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine says Russia attacked the Odesa region with drones.
desc: NA
author: Erin Mendell

header: Can China Make Peace in Ukraine? Macron Isn’t Saying No.
desc: The French president hopes Beijing can be useful in pressing Russia to end the war in Ukraine. How exactly is not clear.
author: Roger Cohen

header: How Russia’s Offensive Ran Aground
desc: Whatever happens in Bakhmut, a once-ambitious winter offensive never really went anywhere.
author: Josh Holder and Marco Hernandez

header: Xi and Macron Call for Ukraine Peace Talks, but the Path Is Murky
desc: It is not clear that the Chinese and French leaders — much less Russia and Ukraine — have compatible terms for talks or peace, and Mr. Xi has not publicly agreed to pressure Moscow to negotiate.
author: Roger Cohen

header: Macron’s meeting with Xi could affect the direction of the war.
desc: NA
author: David Pierson

header: Ukrainian forces are ‘not going anywhere,’ Prigozhin says.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin, who leads the mercenary group, also said that Russia would need better organization and more ammunition to push beyond the besieged city.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Divisions emerge in NATO over giving Ukraine a pathway to membership, officials say.
desc: The debate on the status of Kyiv will continue up to the military alliance’s mid-July summit meeting.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Russia took 2,500 Ukrainian convicts with them as they left Kherson. For some, what ensued was absurd.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: China and France issue a joint statement supporting ‘all efforts to restore peace in Ukraine.’
desc: The statement was issued after a three-day summit by Xi Jinping and Emmanuel Macron in China.
author: David Pierson

header: Explosions hit a village in southern Ukraine where Russia had massed troops, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Zelensky’s aides send mixed messages on Crimea and the possibility of negotiations.
desc: Top government officials in Kyiv clarify that their mission remains to reclaim all Ukrainian territory from Russia.
author: Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine is poised for a critical spring offensive. The looming campaign will test the military’s resolve.
desc: NA
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
desc: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.

header: Fight for Roads Into Bakhmut Has Hit a Stalemate, Ukraine Says
desc: Even as Russian forces made some gains in the battered eastern city last week, Ukraine’s forces say they have thwarted Moscow’s efforts to sever supply lines. For now.

header: Europe Has Pledged a Million Shells for Ukraine in a Year. Can It Deliver?
desc: Probably not, experts say, given the shrunken state of its military industrial sector. A look at a major munitions maker helps explain why.
author: Lara Jakes

header: Leaked Document Shows Dire Nature of the Battle for Bakhmut
desc: An assessment that appears in a new batch of leaked classified documents appears to show that Ukraine was close to losing a key battle of the war in February.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia promises bonus pay to troops who destroy NATO tanks, documents say.
desc: Unconfirmed reports from leaked Pentagon documents show plans to shore up troops’ morale and sharpen their tactics as Ukraine takes delivery of more advanced weapons.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Ukraine Says Russia Is Preparing to Evacuate Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
desc: Ukraine is widely expected to launch a counteroffensive in the coming weeks to recapture territory from Russian forces. Some Ukrainian officials say it could focus on the south of the country.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

header: Leaked Documents Show Seoul Torn Between U.S. Demands and Its Own Policy
desc: The documents showed the United States most likely spied on a key Asian ally as pressure built for South Korea to help Washington supply ammunition to Ukraine.

header: French Diplomacy Undercuts U.S. Efforts to Rein China In
desc: Allies don’t always see things the same way, as Emmanuel Macron’s cozy visit to Xi Jinping made abundantly clear.

header: A Quick Guide to What the Leaked U.S. Intelligence Documents Say
desc: The authorities have so far made one arrest in the case, Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old air national guardsman. But many questions remain about the classified documents that have been appearing online.
author: Eric Nagourney

header: A pro-Russian hacking group may have targeted Canada’s energy infrastructure.
desc: NA
author: Dan Bilefsky

header: How Ukraine’s Power Grid Survived So Many Russian Bombings
desc: Russia was determined to break Ukrainians’ will by plunging them into cold and darkness. Its failure, in the face of Ukrainian resilience, offers lessons as winter has released its icy grip.

header: After protests in Poland over Ukrainian grain supplies, Kyiv and Warsaw reach a deal.
desc: Poland, Romania and Hungary, all of which border Ukraine and are members of the European Union, have struggled with a glut of grain and other Ukrainian agricultural products since last year.

header: A leaked document outlines 4 ‘wild card’ scenarios in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
desc: The scenarios, as assessed by the Defense Intelligence Agency, include the deaths of Presidents Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
author: Haley Willis, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert

header: Lethal Surprises Hidden in the Grass: Russia’s Trip Wires and Land Mines

header: Russia Moves to Make Draft Evasion More Difficult
desc: A new law would bar anyone called up to fight in Ukraine from leaving the country, among other restrictions, even as the Kremlin insists it is not planning a new conscription.

desc: The Pentagon is leading a separate team, including the White House, State Department and intelligence agencies, to determine the extent of the damage caused by the disclosures.
author: Eric Schmitt and Michael Crowley

header: Russia Adopts ‘Scorched Earth’ Tactics in Bakhmut, a Ukrainian Commander Says
desc: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky visited Bakhmut on Sunday and said the situation is difficult but under control.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Near Ukraine’s front lines, soldiers learn how to deal with combat stress.
desc: NA
author: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

desc: The reaction to the leak in South Korea is perhaps the strongest so far as the Biden administration scrambles to contain the damage from apparent spying on allies.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: From Red Carpet to Doghouse: Macron Returns From China to Allied Dismay
desc: Criticism of the French president’s performance in Beijing has been scathing among some allies, who saw him as cozying up to Beijing.

header: The Final Blocks: Inside Ukraine’s Bloody Stand for Bakhmut
desc: Pushed into a shrinking corner of the devastated city, the Ukrainian military is determined to hold out for strategic reasons, even as allies question the cost.

header: New Leaked Documents Show Broad Infighting Among Russian Officials

header: Ukraine investigates after a video appears to show the beheading of a prisoner of war.

author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A Problem for Ukraine: Countries Like Brazil Won’t Sell It Arms

header: Biden, Blending the Personal and the Diplomatic, Thanks Ireland for Backing Ukraine

author: Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

header: Leaked document says Russia’s ally Serbia is sending arms to Ukraine.
desc: The revelation could create tensions between the Kremlin and the Balkan nation.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: F.B.I. Arrests National Guardsman in Leak of Classified Documents
desc: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
author: Haley Willis, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Julian E. Barnes and Malachy Browne

header: Ukraine asks India for more humanitarian and diplomatic support.
desc: NA
author: Sameer Yasir

header: The Airman Who Gave Gamers a Real Taste of War
desc: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
author: Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Michael Schwirtz and Riley Mellen

header: Zelensky asks G7 finance officials to expand support for Ukraine’s economy.
desc: NA
author: Alan Rappeport

header: Pentagon Leaks: New Twists in a Familiar Plot

header: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland

header: Death Toll From Russian Missile Attack in Eastern Ukraine Climbs to 11
desc: Rescuers were searching through rubble a day after the city of Sloviansk was struck as fighting raged in Bakhmut.

header: A Ukrainian toddler was pulled from the rubble after a missile strike, but he did not survive.
desc: The 2-year-old boy and at least seven other people were killed after a Russian attack in Sloviansk, Ukrainian officials said. His father is believed to still be trapped in the carnage.

header: Why China’s Leader Hasn’t Called the President of Ukraine
desc: China had been Ukraine’s top trade partner, importing barley, corn and arms. Now, Russia’s war raises the question: Is there still a relationship?

header: Brazil’s Lula Meets Xi in China as They Seek Path to Peace in Ukraine
desc: Brazil has been reluctant about choosing sides in the war, as its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, seeks to rebuild the country’s ties with Beijing.

header: In Beijing, Brazil’s leader endorses China’s stance on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Keith Bradsher and André Spigariol

header: This is how Ukraine has survived the war on its power grid.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: The Russians took their children. These mothers went and got them back.
desc: Making a nerve-racking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
author: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Russia’s Defense Ministry offers rare acknowledgment of Wagner cooperation.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: When Freezing Sperm Makes a Patriotic Statement
desc: Some Ukrainian soldiers are trying to ensure that even if they die in the war, their partners can still build families. They also want to send Russia a message of defiance.

header: Russian Invasion of Ukraine Revolutionizes NATO Military Strategy
desc: Shocked by Russian atrocities, NATO is becoming the war-fighting alliance it was during the Cold War, committed to defending “every inch” of its territory from Day 1.

header: E.U. Cries Foul as Poland and Hungary Ban Ukraine Grain Imports
desc: The European Union lifted tariffs on Ukrainian grain last year. But farmers say they are suffering from a glut of produce in Europe.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Enjoli Liston

header: Under the Shadow of War, Kyiv Celebrates Orthodox Easter
desc: Thousands of Christians gathered in the Ukrainian capital to mark Holy Week, one year after Ukraine’s army forced Russian troops back from the area around Kyiv.

header: A revered Russian theater director is reborn.
desc: Dmitry Krymov, one of Russia’s most eminent directors, is among the dozens of artists who have left their homeland since Russia invaded Ukraine.
author: Dan Bilefsky and Jeremy Fassler

header: Harsh Sentence for Putin Critic Highlights Kremlin’s Repression
desc: A Moscow court sentenced Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in prison, making it clear that any criticism of the war can lead to prison time.
author: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine seeks to reopen transit routes for its grain as more countries look to impose import bans.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A missile strike on Sloviansk is one of the deadliest for Ukrainian civilians this year.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Five of Ukraine’s allies team up to try to push Russia out of the nuclear fuel market.
desc: NA

header: The opposition activist convicted of treason has long rankled the Kremlin.
desc: Vladimir Kara-Murza was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in a Russian penal colony.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: ‘Our Own Guys Are Shelling Us’: How Russian Propaganda Plagues Ukraine
desc: A year into the war, some residents of eastern Ukrainian towns still confound officials and the police with their support for Russia despite the constant bombardment from Russian forces.
author: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko, Dyma Shapoval and Daniel Berehulak

header: Zelensky and Putin Make Dueling Trips to Front Line in Ukraine
desc: The visits by the Ukrainian and Russian leaders came as both sought to display strength and confidence ahead of an anticipated Kyiv counteroffensive.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Victoria Kim

header: The Wrong Mr. Kozlov: When Sanctions Spell Trouble for Regular People
desc: After Russia invaded Ukraine, the European Union blacklisted about 1,500 people linked to the war. That has complicated the lives of those who share their sometimes fairly common names.

header: Russian artillery and aerial attacks against Bakhmut are growing fiercer, Ukraine says.
desc: According to a top Ukrainian general, Kyiv’s forces remain in control in the ravaged city, the focus of months of fighting, but Russian forces are turning it “into ruins.”
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Swift NATO Membership for Sweden
desc: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, visiting Sweden, said he hoped that objections to adding the country to the alliance would be ironed out by midsummer, when member states meet in Lithuania.
author: Helene Cooper

header: Blinken and Top Diplomats Stress Unity on Russia and China
desc: The foreign ministers of the Group of 7 nations affirmed their shared visions on Russia’s war on Ukraine and China’s assertiveness after talk flared this month over different strategies.
author: Edward Wong

header: Ukrainian survivors of Russia’s occupation give harrowing testimony at a House hearing.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine Diary: Ukrainians collect the bodies of dead Russian soldiers.
desc: NA
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Germany lists the Patriot system it promised to Ukraine as delivered.
desc: NA

header: Zelensky and Putin make dueling trips to front line in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Victoria Kim

header: Russia’s onslaught includes years of propaganda directed at Ukraine’s east.
desc: NA
author: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Dyma Shapoval

header: Ukrainian officials express frustration at the pace of weapons deliveries.
author: Anushka Patil and John Yoon

header: How Freeing Ukraine’s Trapped Grain Rankled Farmers Elsewhere in Europe
desc: When Russia’s war blocked vitally needed grains at Ukrainian ports, officials succeeded in finding other routes out. But the solution brought its own problems.
author: Patricia Cohen

header: Ukraine’s Social Media Stars Rethink How They Wield Their Influence
desc: Russian was once the lingua franca of influencers in Ukraine. Now, not so much.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Pentagon Speeds Up Tank Timeline for Ukraine but Resists Calls for Jets
desc: The U.S. will begin training Ukrainian troops on M1 Abrams tanks in the next few weeks, officials said, and combat-ready tanks could reach the battlefields by the fall.
author: Helene Cooper

header: ‘A Quick Death or a Slow Death’: Prisoners Choose War to Get Lifesaving Drugs
desc: An estimated 20 percent of Russia prisoner recruits are H.I.V. positive. To some, the front lines seemed less risky than prisons where they said they were denied effective treatments.

header: With needs so great in Ukraine after a year of war, some amputees are finding their way to a clinic in Minnesota.
desc: NA
author: David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

header: U.S. tanks might arrive soon, but Ukraine’s allies are struggling to meet other weapons pledges.
desc: Documents that were among leaked classified military assessments of the war reveal the struggles of Western allies to fulfill their pledged deliveries of tanks and other weapons systems.
author: Lara Jakes

header: NATO’s top official, visiting Kyiv, says Ukraine’s ‘rightful place’ is in the alliance.
desc: “I am here today with a simple message: NATO stands with Ukraine,” Jens Stoltenberg, the alliance’s secretary general, said at a joint news conference with the Ukrainian president.

header: The arrival of Abrams tanks would be a major step in arming Ukraine.
desc: Accelerated timeline means the tanks could enter the Ukrainian war in a few months, officials say
author: Helene Cooper

header: Ukraine Says Russian Troops Are Evacuating Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
desc: Russian troops are forcibly relocating residents near the southern city of Kherson as fighting there intensifies, Ukrainian officials said Sunday.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: Russia’s Technocrats Embraced the West, Then Enabled Putin’s War
desc: The expertise of economic officials who continue to work in the government has helped President Vladimir Putin largely keep the economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

author: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: Zelensky Signs Ban on Russian Place Names in Struggle Over National Identity
desc: The action late Friday was the latest in a series of steps by Ukraine to distance itself from a long legacy of Russian domination.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: United States Says Wagner Has Quietly Picked Sides in Sudan
desc: Wagner has offered powerful weapons, including surface-to-air missiles, to R.S.F. paramilitaries, American officials said.
author: Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong

header: ‘I Cry Quietly’: A Soldier Describes the Toll of Russia’s War
desc: For Valentyn, a Ukrainian soldier in the Donetsk region, the war’s death toll is more than a statistic. He is tasked with moving wounded troops — and dead bodies — away from the front lines, often under Russian fire.
author: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Ben Laffin

header: As War Rages in Sudan, Countries Angle for Advantage
desc: Even before its two leading generals went to war last week, “everyone wanted a chunk of Sudan,” an expert said of the strategically located country rich in natural resources.
author: Declan Walsh

header: Angry Farmers Pierce Europe’s United Front on Ukraine
desc: A grain deal that got Ukrainian exports moving and eased a global food crisis is now fueling protests in Romania and among other staunch supporters of Kyiv.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Ukraine Diary: Spring flowers bloom in Kyiv’s streets, a sign of life returning to the city.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Evelina Riabenko

header: Ukraine Diary: In frontline villages, animals are hard to leave behind.
desc: Although most people have fled villages near the fighting, some who stayed behind did so out of a desire to not abandon their farm animals.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: At Ukraine’s Gravesites, a Spring Ritual Hints at Renewal
desc: A decimated village welcomes back displaced residents for a day of remembrance and hope.
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima

header: Battlefield update: Russian forces have hit civilian areas around the southern city of Kherson, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: The Kremlin’s spokesman says his son fought in Ukraine.
desc: Dmitri S. Peskov’s comments highlighted the Moscow elite’s uneven participation in a war that has cost the lives of tens of thousands of Russian soldiers.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: The stakes for Ukraine’s spring offensive? ‘Everything.’
desc: NA
author: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: A grain glut leaves some Eastern European countries caught between solidarity with Ukraine and survival.
desc: NA
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Ukraine’s social media influencers have been dropping the Russian language, even at the cost of reach.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian-Led U.N. Meeting on Peace Draws West’s Accusations of Hypocrisy
desc: Taking advantage of its turn as president of the Security Council, Moscow sent Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov to preside over a session on peace and diplomacy.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: A Symbol of Loss in Almost Every Ukrainian Kitchen
desc: Soledar, crushed in Russia’s long assault on Bakhmut, was only a little town. But its salt is a national staple, and a matter of pride.
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukrainian Troops Repel Russian Attacks, and Hope Western Arms Turn the Tide
desc: Fierce fighting has yielded heavy casualties but little movement. Ukrainian forces need heavy weapons to change that, but they say it is no guarantee.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Stanislav Kozliuk

header: Xi and Zelensky Talk at Last, but Words Are Chosen Carefully
desc: Volodymyr Zelensky has urged discussions with Xi Jinping since the Russian invasion, but in its official account of the phone call, China left out two words: “Russia” and “war.”
author: David Pierson, Marc Santora and Vivian Wang

header: Ukraine War ‘Turned Everything Upside Down’ in This Polish Town
desc: A Polish town that was once occupied by the Soviets used to embrace its history with military re-enactments and Lenin banners. But “nobody wants to be reminded of Russia these days.”
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Save Ukraine, a small but effective nonprofit group, searches for missing children.
desc: NA
author: Julian E. Barnes

header: Ukraine Has Nearly All Combat Vehicles Allies Promised, NATO Says
desc: Gen. Christopher Cavoli, also the top commander of U.S. forces in Europe, made the comments to the House Armed Services Committee.
author: Eric Schmitt

header: A reporting team for an Italian newspaper comes under fire in southern Ukraine, and one journalist is killed.
desc: Another reporter was hospitalized in the city of Kherson and described the attack to the paper, La Repubblica.
author: Marc Santora

header: Relations between China and Ukraine have been uncertain since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
desc: President Xi Jinping of China and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last communicated in January 2022, less than two months before Russia invaded.
author: Vivian Wang

header: Russian forces pound Zaporizhzhia before an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Pope Francis and Ukraine’s prime minister have first known meeting since the start of the war.
desc: NA
author: Gaia Pianigiani

header: Deadliest Russian Attack in Months on Ukraine’s Cities Kills at Least 25
desc: The first widespread barrage on civilian targets in more than a month underscored the vital role of Ukrainian air defenses.
author: Marc Santora

header: Life in Ukraine’s Trenches: Gearing Up for a Spring Offensive
desc: With fighting in the eastern Donbas region settling into a bloody stalemate, a patch of the Zaporizhzhia region of southeastern Ukraine could prove to be the war’s next big theater.
author: Michael Schwirtz and David Guttenfelder

header: The E.U. will keep letting in Ukrainian grains without tariffs.
desc: Five countries whose farmers have been hurt by the policy, including Poland, will get carve-outs and compensation, under an agreement reached Friday.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: E.U. Extends Tariff Waiver for Ukrainian Grain, Despite Some Protests
desc: The bloc will provide more than $100 million to farmers in eastern countries where tariff-free Ukrainian grain produced a supply glut and plunging prices.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Large Fire Burns at Crimea Fuel Depot After Suspected Drone Attack
desc: A Russian-installed local official blamed the blaze on “enemy drones.” Ukraine, which typically maintains a policy of strategic ambiguity about strikes in Crimea, did not claim responsibility.
author: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim

header: In Uman, a mother holds out hope her children will still be found alive.
desc: A Russian rocket slammed into a nine-story apartment building before dawn in the central Ukrainian city of Uman.
author: Marc Santora

header: Russia’s latest strikes underscore the limits of Ukraine’s air defense systems.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: The wrong Mr. Kozlov: How sanctions are spelling trouble for regular people.
desc: NA
author: Monika Pronczuk

header: An unreleased report finds faults in Amnesty International’s criticism of Ukraine.
desc: The rights group commissioned an independent review of its August accusation that Ukrainian forces illegally put civilians in harm’s way.
author: Charlie Savage

header: The Kremlin steps up efforts to Russify occupied parts of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine Wants to Push Forward. Not So Fast, Says Its Black Soupy Mud.
desc: The unusually wet ground is one obstacle that the Ukrainian military, for all of its ingenuity, is finding difficult to overcome as it prepares for a counteroffensive against Russian forces.
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: They Refused to Fight for Russia. The Law Did Not Treat Them Kindly.
desc: Since Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, hundreds of Russian men have faced criminal charges for becoming war refuseniks. That has not stopped others from going to unusual lengths to avoid battle.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: Battlefield Update: Russia and Ukraine each claim gains in Bakhmut.
desc: The fight for Bakhmut, the ruined city in eastern Ukraine, has become a focal point of the war as both sides have poured troops into battle and sustained heavy casualties.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Both sides report attacks before an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
desc: The attacks follow a weekend of explosions deep behind Russian lines. A Ukrainian official said the depot fire is part of preparations for “the broad, full-scale offensive that everyone expects” Ukraine to launch soon.
author: Marc Santora and Malachy Browne

header: McCarthy Pledges Continued Support for Ukraine
desc: The speaker, who warned last year that there would be no “blank check” for Ukraine, told a Russian reporter he would continue support to Kyiv against Russia’s invasion.
author: Karoun Demirjian and Patrick Kingsley

header: U.S. Says 100,000 Russian Casualties in Ukraine in Past 5 Months
desc: About half of the reported dead were mercenaries for the Wagner group, a paramilitary force that recruited heavily from Russian prisons.
author: Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: As Signs Point to Counteroffensive, Russia and Ukraine Step Up Attacks
desc: Russian forces were reportedly moving into defensive positions, as Ukraine’s defense chief said the military was “reaching the finish line” for a major push to reclaim occupied land.
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukraine’s Military Says Crimea Blast Was Preparation for Coming Offensive
desc: Late Sunday, a day after the Crimea blast, explosions rocked Pavlograd in central Ukraine, and air raid sirens sounded across Ukraine.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: An explosion derails a freight train in a Russian border area, according to a local governor.
desc: The blast was the latest in a spate of apparent attacks to hit the area bordering Ukraine.
author: Cassandra Vinograd and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Defending press freedom, an eye on China and more on Ukraine’s grain: What to watch for this week.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil and Juston Jones

header: Moscow Claims Explosions Above the Kremlin Were an Attempt to Kill Putin
desc: Russia said Ukraine had launched a drone attack, which Kyiv vehemently denied, accusing Russia of manufacturing a pretext for escalation.
author: Anton Troianovski and Haley Willis

header: Russia Ramps Up Pressure on Civilians in Occupied Ukraine
desc: Wary of Ukrainian partisans and anticipating a counteroffensive, Russian authorities have “reinforced” counterintelligence units in occupied territory, Ukraine says.
author: Marc Santora

header: A second train derailment in two days is reported in a Russian border area.
desc: An explosion on Tuesday in Bryansk, along Ukraine’s northern border, sent a locomotive and about 20 train cars off the rails, local authorities said.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: Secret ‘Mission’ for Peace in Ukraine May Show Limits of Pope’s Influence
desc: Since Francis made cryptic reference to a Vatican peace effort, the suggestion has elicited denial or bewilderment by war’s protagonists.
author: Jason Horowitz

header: Verified videos show two explosions over the Kremlin.
desc: The explosions were separated by about 15 minutes and one caused a brief fire.
author: Haley Willis and Riley Mellen

header: At a U.N. event on press freedom, the publisher of The New York Times warns of dangers to democracy.
desc: NA
author: Christopher Mele and Andrea Kannapell

header: The U.S. will send an additional $300 million in military aid to Ukraine.
desc: The latest package includes ammunition for howitzer cannons and High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems, or HIMARS.
author: Michael Crowley

header: Zelensky says Russia is trying to stoke support at home by blaming Kyiv.
desc: The Ukrainian president flatly denied that his country was behind any drone attack on the Kremlin.
author: Johanna Lemola

header: Russia’s claim comes as Ukraine is readying for a counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Discreetly, Berlin Confronts Russian Spies Hiding in Plain Sight
desc: For years, Germany seemed to tolerate even flagrant Russian operations on its soil. But a new Cold War-like chill has now made the snooping difficult to ignore.
author: Erika Solomon

header: Russian and Ukrainian Delegates Fight Over Ukrainian Flag at Conference
desc: Two altercations over Ukrainian flags occurred at a regional parliamentary conference in Ankara, the Turkish capital.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russian Unease Over Ukraine War Grows Amid Attacks and Leadership Rifts
desc: With a Ukrainian offensive looming, explosions in Crimea and inside Russia have rattled Moscow, sparking bureaucratic infighting among military commanders.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: What We Know About the Explosions Over the Kremlin
desc: Moscow has accused Ukraine of a drone attack aimed at assassinating President Vladimir V. Putin, without providing evidence. Kyiv has strenuously denied involvement.
author: Cora Engelbrecht

header: Kremlin Blasts Were Real. The Rest Is Hazy, Maybe Intentionally.
desc: Kyiv and Moscow angrily blamed each other after two explosions in an apparent drone attack on the heart of Russian power, but whose outrage is real?
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: In The Hague, Zelensky Renews Call to Prosecute Russian War Crimes
desc: As international support for an independent tribunal appears to be growing, the Ukrainian leader called for “true justice” for crimes in the war.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze and Victoria Kim

header: The pope’s secret ‘mission’ for peace in Ukraine may demonstrate the limits of his influence.
desc: NA
author: Jason Horowitz

header: Attacks on Russian infrastructure help set the stage for Ukraine’s counteroffensive, analysts say.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The Dnipro River, Axis of Life and Death in Ukraine
desc: The river has helped to define Ukraine’s history and culture, and remains vital to daily sustenance, even as it also serves as a front line in war — as it has countless times over thousands of years.
author: Nicole Tung and Marc Santora

header: Russian soldiers could replace Wagner in Bakhmut, but daily combat would likely change, experts say.
desc: NA
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Explosions rock Kyiv and Odesa overnight after the Kremlin incident.
desc: The Ukrainian military provided images of downed drones that suggested some bore handwritten messages that read “For Moscow” and “For the Kremlin.”
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukrainians Return Home, Renewed and Resigned
desc: More than 5.5 million people who left after the war began in February 2022 have gone back home — and not just to large cities like Kyiv or Dnipro, but to small places near the front line, as well.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Ukraine Claims It Shot Down Russia’s Most Sophisticated Missile for First Time
desc: The air force said it intercepted the hypersonic missile with a newly delivered U.S.-made Patriot air-defense battery. U.S. officials confirmed the strike.
author: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay

header: As Putin Bides His Time, Ukraine Faces a Ticking Clock
desc: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.
author: Paul Sonne and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Wagner Chief Appears to Backtrack on Threat to Pull Fighters From Bakhmut
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin said his mercenaries had been promised the ammunition and equipment they needed and would not have to withdraw from Russia’s fight for the eastern Ukrainian city.
author: Neil MacFarquhar, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrés R. Martínez

header: Car Bombing Injures Prominent Russian Nationalist Writer, State Media Reports
desc: Zakhar Prilepin, who himself fought in eastern Ukraine, has long advocated an imperialist foreign policy by Moscow.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Anton Troianovski

header: The Forces Behind South Korea’s and Japan’s Thaw
desc: Eras of grievances between the two countries are giving way under the pressure of global changes, and with help from a personal outreach approach by both leaders.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: After Coronation, U.K. Awaits a Wider Changing of the Guard
desc: Beneath the gilded continuity of the coronation celebrations, there were signs that both Britain and its royal family are preparing for a new era.
author: Mark Landler

header: Russia launched a large wave of attack drones over Kyiv, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: Ukraine’s military said that it shot down all of the drones, in what was the fourth large-scale assault aimed at the city this month.
author: Marc Santora

header: Chaos and Shortages in Parts of Occupied Ukraine Amid Russian Evacuation Orders
desc: Running short of food, fuel and cash, and with a Ukrainian counteroffensive imminent, many civilians are defying a directive by occupation forces, unsure where they would go.
author: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova

header: The U.S. is providing $1.2 billion for Ukraine to buy air defense missiles and other crucial equipment.
desc: A Pentagon spokesman also confirmed that Ukrainian troops using a U.S.-made Patriot air-defense system shot down a hypersonic Russian missile.
author: John Ismay

header: Homemade, Cheap and Lethal, Attack Drones Are Vital to Ukraine
desc: Fighting superior Russian firepower, Ukrainian forces turn off-the-shelf drones into deadly weapons by adapting them to carry explosives.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: An A.F.P. journalist was killed by rocket fire near the intense fighting in the area around Bakhmut.
desc: Arman Soldin, 32, was the 17th journalist to be killed in Ukraine since 2022, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.
author: Anushka Patil

header: China Woos European Leaders on Trip Overshadowed by Kremlin Ties
desc: A three-stop tour by China’s foreign minister this week has everyone trying to balance economic and security interests when it comes to Russia and Ukraine.
author: Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

header: Fearing Attacks and Perhaps Unrest, Russia Plans Muted Victory Day
desc: The Kremlin will commemorate the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II, but many towns have canceled events on Tuesday.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: On Muted War Holiday, Putin Tries to Justify Invasion of Ukraine
desc: With Russia struggling on the battlefield, Vladimir V. Putin presided over a scaled-down celebration of the Soviet Union’s victory in World War II, while using it to repeat false claims about Ukraine.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As Putin bides his time, Ukraine faces a ticking clock.
desc: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.
author: Paul Sonne and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine’s Black Sea grain exports slow as a deadline looms on a key shipping deal.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Britain says it is donating long-range ‘Storm Shadow’ missiles to Ukraine.
desc: The missiles, which are launched from the air, are the latest in a pipeline of military aid delivered to the country by Britain, the United States and other NATO allies.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Stephen Castle

header: On one Ukrainian official’s screen, a map tells the story of Russia’s constant strikes.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: How Russia’s Rich Get Their Luxuries Now
desc: More than a year into Vladimir Putin’s invasion, the web of global trade has adjusted to Western sanctions, with a network of middlemen sending cars, electronics and more to Russia.
author: Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing

header: ‘Death Is Everywhere’ in a Once-Jubilant Ukrainian City
desc: No city in Ukraine has suffered the reversal of fortunes that Kherson has. Liberated in the fall, it was a symbol of hope. Now it is a kill zone.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Zelensky, Citing Equipment Gaps, Says It’s Too Soon for Counteroffensive
desc: Ukraine’s president played down the chance of an imminent military move, but the claim was greeted with some skepticism.
author: Carlotta Gall, Shashank Bengali, Lara Jakes and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The Justice Department transfers funds seized for sanctions violations to help rebuild Ukraine, a first.
desc: NA
author: Charlie Savage

header: Ukraine Makes Gains Near Embattled Bakhmut, a First in Months
desc: The leader of Russia’s Wagner paramilitary group confirmed the Ukrainian advance, and continued to air divisions among Moscow’s forces.
author: Carlotta Gall, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Traci Carl

header: The U.S. ambassador to South Africa accused the country of providing weapons to Russia.
desc: The American ambassador to South Africa told reporters that Washington is confident a Russian ship picked up a load of weapons and ammunition near Cape Town in December.
author: John Eligon

header: Zelensky’s comments about needing more time for a successful counteroffensive set off a debate on any hidden agenda.
desc: NA
author: Carlotta Gall

header: Ukrainian officials say they need more weapons. The West says it has already sent them.
desc: NA
author: Lara Jakes

header: Germany Announces Its Biggest Military Aid Package Yet for Ukraine
desc: The nearly $3 billion package is part of an effort by both sides to reset rocky relations, which have become increasingly important to maintaining European unity in backing the war.
author: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Zelensky Meets Pope and Meloni in Italy to Bolster Ukraine’s Support
desc: The Ukrainian president’s talks with the pope and Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni came at a potentially pivotal moment in the war with Russia, as Kyiv’s forces make advances near the key city of Bakhmut.
author: Jason Horowitz

header: Ukraine’s Advances Near Bakhmut Expose Rifts in Russian Forces
desc: Russia’s pro-war bloggers were quick to claim that Ukraine’s long-anticipated counteroffensive had begun, but Ukrainian officials downplayed the advances.
author: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian Soldiers Risk Their Lives to Keep Weapons From the Black Market
desc: They can’t track every shell, but at a time of heightened scrutiny in Washington they know they can ill afford slips with the big ticket items.
author: Lara Jakes

header: The United States is wiring Ukraine with radiation sensors to detect nuclear blasts.
desc: The federal National Nuclear Security Administration is setting up an advanced network that can verify an attacker’s identity.
author: William J. Broad

header: Top E.U. diplomat vows to stand with Ukraine for the long haul.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: Recriminations plague Russian forces as Ukraine steps up pressure.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: China will send an envoy to Russia and Ukraine in a quest for peace talks.
desc: Li Hui, China’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, is expected to begin his trip on Monday.
author: Vivian Wang

header: Kyiv’s gains near Bakhmut raise alarms in Russia that Ukraine’s counteroffensive has begun.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian-ordered evacuations near Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant alarm officials.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: With a new tranche of weapons, Ukraine has much of what it needs for a counteroffensive, analysts say.
desc: The additions to Ukraine’s arsenal, which include more tanks, drones and other weapons from Germany, may signal that Western officials believe Kyiv’s forces could reclaim significant swaths of territory.
author: Lara Jakes

header: The U.K. promises more missiles and drones for Ukraine.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain and said he was “very pleased” with new weapons packages pledged by allies.
author: Mark Landler

header: As Ukraine Makes Inroads in Bakhmut, Devastation Still Reigns
desc: The fight for Bakhmut is now the war’s single longest and bloodiest battle. Although the Ukrainians are making small gains, Russia still controls about 90 percent of the largely ruined city.
author: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: Ukrainians Send a Message With Their Bombs. On Them, Too.
desc: Ukrainians have a lot to say to Russia, and many have chosen to say it in ink on the sides of rockets, mortar shells and even exploding drones.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Zelensky Visits Germany, Praising Weapons Pledge and Seeking Jets
desc: The Ukrainian president was received with military honors in Berlin, where he thanked Germany’s leaders for standing with his country.
author: Erika Solomon

header: In European Tour, Zelensky Reaps Billions More in Promised Military Aid
desc: His trips to Britain, Germany, France and Italy demonstrated the shifting political landscape when it comes to supporting Kyiv, as concerns grow about U.S. backing as the presidential election looms.
author: Mark Landler

header: Ukraine Diary: Under the threat of airstrikes, a film crew in Kyiv forged ahead to ‘tell a story.’
desc: NA
author: Nicole Tung

header: To work around sanctions, cars, electronics and more get to Russia through Dubai.
desc: NA
author: Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing

header: The Wagner leader disputes a report that he offered to betray Russia.
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military group, dismissed a report from The Washington Post saying that leaked intelligence showed he had offered to share Russian Army positions with Ukraine.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine claims further advances around Bakhmut.
desc: Ukrainian soldiers made further advances around Bakhmut over the weekend.
author: Marc Santora, Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: The Latest Flash Point Among Ukraine’s Allies Is Whether to Send F-16s
desc: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
author: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

header: Gains Near Bakhmut Raise Ukraine’s Hopes of a Turning Tide
desc: The advances have been small, and Russians still hold most of the city, but Ukrainians say they see a meaningful shift in momentum.
author: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: As Ukrainian Attack Looms, Putin Faces Setbacks and Disunity in Russian Forces
desc: The problems that have hindered Russia’s 15-month war are still festering: stretched resources and disunity in the ranks. Still, Mr. Putin’s resolve augurs a willingness to prosecute a long war.
author: Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s push around Bakhmut presents Russia with tough decisions about its resources.
desc: Kyiv’s forces have reclaimed ground near the city that it took Russian forces months to seize, raising pressure on Moscow to devote more fighters and equipment there.
author: Marc Santora

header: Russian-Controlled Dam Risks Flooding in Southern Ukraine
desc: The development is a dramatic turnabout after the reservoir had reached a historic low. The dam, which lies along the front line, has been a point of tension throughout the war.
author: Riley Mellen and Haley Willis

header: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Hypersonic Russian Missiles Over Kyiv
desc: A Russian barrage also damaged a U.S.-made Patriot air-defense system, but officials said it was still working.
author: Victoria Kim and Eric Schmitt

header: The chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court has been detained and accused of taking a $2.7 million bribe.
desc: ‘This is a dark day in the history of the court,’ its judges said.
author: Daniel Victor

header: Ukraine and Russia Renew a Deal to Allow Ukraine to Ship Grain
desc: Russia last year blocked exports of Ukrainian grain across the Black Sea, a vital part of the global food supply, but they resumed last summer under a fragile pact.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gulsin Harman

header: Ukraine Diary: A rebuilding effort brings together Ukrainians from across generations.
desc: NA
author: Nicole Tung

header: Ukraine’s first lady requests nonlethal military aid from South Korea while in Seoul.
desc: While Olena Zelenska asked for military equipment to fight the war, South Korea pledged more nonmilitary aid to help Ukraine rebuild.
author: Anushka Patil

header: In a Sharp Reversal, Biden Opens a Path for Ukraine to Get Fighter Jets
desc: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
author: David E. Sanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt

header: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
desc: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: What Is the F-16 Fighter Jet and Why Does Ukraine Want It?
desc: The versatile and lightweight American warplane is seen by many of Ukraine’s allies as an important deterrent against Russia.
author: Lara Jakes

header: Ukraine Arrests a Top Judge as Crackdown on Corruption Expands
desc: At least three more Supreme Court judges, in addition to the chief justice, have been implicated in a growing bribery case, prosecutors say.
author: Carlotta Gall

header: As Russia Tries to Pummel Kyiv, a Blast in Crimea Hints at Ukraine’s Reach
desc: Ukrainian officials did not claim responsibility for a train derailment on the occupied peninsula, but it was the latest in a series of explosions hitting the railways and supply lines of Russia’s war machine.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine and China Will Dominate G7 Summit, but a New Threat Lurks: A.I.
desc: The leaders are expected to hold their first talks on a common regulatory approach to generative artificial intelligence.
author: David E. Sanger

header: A strengthened Zelensky lands in Japan for the G7 meeting.
desc: The Ukrainian president will address world leaders on Sunday. His arrival in Japan came after President Biden opened the door to other nations eventually providing F-16s to Ukraine.
author: Victoria Kim

header: Zelensky Urges Arab Leaders Not to ‘Turn a Blind Eye’ to Russian Aggression
desc: Addressing an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Arab nations to stand with him against Russia and called out their reluctance to take sides in the war.
author: Vivian Nereim

header: A Ukrainian government program received 10,000 applications to repair homes.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: A Chinese diplomat ends his Ukraine trip with no sign of a breakthrough.
desc: NA
author: Chris Buckley

header: Wagner Chief Says Bakhmut Is Taken; Ukraine Rejects Claim
desc: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
author: Marc Santora

header: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as Group of 7 Powers Meet in Japan
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
author: Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger

header: In Bakhmut, the Tides of Battle Are Ever Shifting
desc: Ukraine, this month, pressed ahead with three days of maneuvers that gained ground on the flanks of Bakhmut. But Russian forces still appear to hold the center of the strategic city.
author: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: As Russia Claims Victory in Bakhmut, Ukraine Sees Opportunity Amid Ruins
desc: Military analysts say that if Moscow continues to send reinforcements to defend the city, that could weaken Russian forces’ ability to hold off a broader counteroffensive that Ukraine has been planning.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine May Be Finally Getting the F-16s It Asked For. Why Did It Want Them?
desc: Ukraine’s sizable contingent of fighter jets come with a few problems. President Volodymyr Zelensky said F-16s would “greatly enhance our army in the sky.”
author: Carlotta Gall

header: The key events in the battle for Bakhmut, the war’s longest-running sustained fight.
desc: The city has for months been the center of the fighting in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine. Here’s a look at the critical moments.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Wagner’s chief says Bakhmut was captured, but the Ukrainian military says that’s not so.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Russia sees a victory in Bakhmut. Ukraine sees an opportunity.

desc: NA

desc: Beijing and Moscow are holding visits this week as alarm grows in China that Western countries backing Ukraine are turning their attention to Asia.

author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine Got the Keys to the F-16. Now Come the Lessons.

author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Wagner group forecasts disaster if Russia does not move into total war footing.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin has been ramping up pressure on Russia’s military leadership and extending his criticism to the country’s moneyed elites.

header: Ukraine and Russia engage in dueling drone attacks.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: A unit of Ukraine’s security services likely orchestrated the Kremlin drone attack, U.S. officials say.
desc: NA

header: Ukraine’s intelligence chief says it needs ‘significant reserves’ of weapons for a counteroffensive.
desc: NA

header: Russian strikes damage at least one airfield in western Ukraine.
desc: NA

desc: NA

desc: NA
author: Andrew E. Kramer

desc: NA
author: Aurelien Breeden

desc: NA

header: What We Know About the Drone Attack on Moscow
desc: Russia’s Defense Ministry said that at least eight drones had targeted Moscow and the surrounding region.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia has carried out more than 1,000 attacks on Ukrainian health care facilities, the W.H.O. says.
desc: NA
author: Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: Defense start-ups get praise in Ukraine, but face challenges at home.
desc: NA
author: Eric Lipton

header: A Russian official says Ukrainian shelling has forced the evacuation of 2,500 people from his border region.
desc: ‘The conditions are quite difficult,’ the local governor of the region said on social media.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine’s counteroffensive promises to be deadly. These recruits signed up anyway.
desc: “We’re going to die, probably,” one recruit said bluntly, as he trained on Friday with several hundred others at a military camp in Yorkshire, England.

desc: NA
author: Matthew Futterman

desc: They were among three people killed in a Russian missile attack, officials said. Ukraine opened an investigation, as Russians described shelling and evacuations in border regions.

header: Turn off public webcams, Ukraine’s intelligence agency pleads.
desc: NA
author: Anushka Patil

header: Explosions Hit Southern Ukraine as Both Sides Brace for Counteroffensive
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in an unusually personal speech, urged his compatriots to show their gratitude to the country’s soldiers.

header: Car Bombing in Russian-Occupied Ukraine Shows Reach of War
desc: The blast in the Zaporizhzhia region of southern Ukraine killed a cafe owner who was registered to run in elections seen as an attempt to legitimize Moscow’s illegal annexation of the area.

header: Ukraine and Russia blame each other for the dam’s destruction.
desc: NA

header: Ukraine condemns pro-Russian authorities over a claim that children from flooded areas are being taken to camps.
desc: NA
author: Emma Bubola

desc: Three small settlements in the eastern region of Donetsk have been taken back from Russian occupiers, Ukrainian officials say.

desc: Military analysts said it would take weeks or months to gauge the success of the attacks Ukraine mounted last week across a broad stretch of the front lines.

desc: Top political leaders said the botched May 31 launch, which was meant to put a military spy satellite in orbit, had been “irresponsibly” planned.

header: Allies will grapple with questions about Ukraine’s postwar reconstruction.

header: Ukraine retakes some villages but its forces face minefields and more airstrikes.

desc: NA

desc: NA
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Global markets are muted after the short-lived mutiny in Russia.
desc: NA

desc: NA

header: Black Sea Grain Deal Hangs on 11th-Hour Talks, Again
desc: Russia has repeatedly threatened to pull out of the wartime export agreement, which has helped stabilize global grain prices and avert famines. The latest deadline to renew it is Monday.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Vivek Shankar

header: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
desc: A tiny village is taking in 6,000 laborers from Asia. They are needed by a petroleum company controlled by the right-wing government, which has vowed to keep migrants out.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: How a Vast Demographic Shift Will Reshape the World
desc: The most powerful countries have benefited from large work forces for decades. What happens when they retire?
author: LAUREN LEATHERBY

header: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. and China Restart Climate Talks
desc: Also, the G20 finance ministers prepare to meet in India, China targets Canadian politicians and cricket rises in Texas.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Your Monday Briefing
desc: Britain’s troubled health service.
author: Natasha Frost

header: Explosions Damage Crimea Bridge as Russia Blames Ukraine for Attack
desc: Russia accused Ukraine of hitting the Kerch Strait Bridge for the second time in 10 months, saying that two maritime drones had struck the bridge, an essential supply line for Russian troops.
author: Marc Santora, Neil MacFarquhar and Haley Willis

header: Moscow Warns Ukraine Against Shipping Grain Across the Black Sea Without Its Consent
desc: The Kremlin’s comments came after Ukraine’s leader called for the shipments to continue despite Russia’s withdrawal from a landmark grain deal.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The U.S. announces $750 million in humanitarian and agricultural aid for Ukraine.
desc: The new funds will go toward food assistance, health and hygienic care, and providing emergency shelter, the agency said.
author: Gabriela Sá Pessoa

header: Russia blames Ukraine for attacking a vital bridge in occupied Crimea.
desc: Russian officials reported that Ukraine had attacked the Kerch Strait Bridge, damaging a critical artery connecting Russia with its troops fighting in southern Ukraine.
author: Marc Santora, Neil MacFarquhar and Haley Willis

header: For These Ukrainian Soldiers, the Fight Is Personal
desc: Ukraine lets soldiers from towns occupied by the Russian military join the battle to reclaim them.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: A Current War Collides With the Past: Remnants of World War II in Ukraine
desc: World War II has been an ideological battlefield in today’s war in Ukraine, and it is cropping up on the actual battlefield as well.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Far From the Front, They Stand in Honor of Ukraine
desc: The city of Chernivtsi in western Ukraine has been spared the mayhem of the Russian invasion. But like other towns in the region, it is doing its part, and has become, in effect, a back office of the war effort.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Russia Stops Ukraine Grain Deal, Shaking World Food Markets
desc: Moscow, which has repeatedly complained that the U.N.-brokered agreement is one-sided in Ukraine’s favor, said it could return to the deal if its demands were met.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko, Liz Alderman and Farnaz Fassihi

header: What We Know About the Attack on the Crimean Bridge
desc: Monday’s strike was the second in less than a year to target the Kerch Strait Bridge, which holds strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia pulls out of the Black Sea grain deal.
desc: The Kremlin terminated an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite a wartime blockade, a deal seen as essential to keeping global food prices stable.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russia Hits Grain Ports and Threatens Ships Headed to Ukraine
desc: Ukraine accused Moscow of specifically targeting the infrastructure for exporting food, after Russia pulled out of an agreement allowing ships carrying grain to sail past its Black Sea blockade.
author: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Joe Rennison

header: What Russia’s Grain Deal Actions Mean for Ukraine
desc: Moscow withdrew from a deal that allowed Ukraine to export grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade, and warned that ships sailing around Ukrainian ports would be seen as military targets.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Disruption to Ukraine Grain Exports Could Worsen Hunger in Some Countries, Experts Warn
desc: Moscow terminated a deal this week that allowing Ukraine to export its food crops, an agreement that had helped to stabilize grain prices and to ease a global food shortage.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Why Odesa Is So Important to Ukraine in the War With Russia
desc: Russia’s withdrawal from a U.N.-backed grain deal and its attacks on Odesa have brought the Black Sea port city’s importance back into focus.
author: Marc Santora

header: The Pentagon unveils $1.3 billion for Ukraine, bringing total new U.S. aid this week to $2.3 billion.
desc: The money is expected to be used to buy new air-defense missile systems and other military equipment.
author: John Ismay

header: Ukrainian Children With Cancer Fight Their Own War Within a War
desc: The war with Russia compounds the struggles of pediatric cancer patients and their families, but it has also prompted positive changes in treatment in Ukraine.
author: Megan Specia

header: As Russia Steps Up Attacks on Grain Ports, U.S. Warns of Possible Ruse
desc: A White House official said Moscow might stage an attack on a commercial ship and blame Ukraine.
author: Michael D. Shear, Neil MacFarquhar and James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Despite the grain deal’s collapse, Putin and Erdogan still rely on each other.
desc: Vladimir V. Putin and Recep Tayyip Erdogan have kept good relations despite the war in Ukraine, and analysts say that will continue after the Kremlin rejected a deal Mr. Erdogan helped broker.
author: Safak Timur

header: Ukraine starts using American-made cluster munitions in its counteroffensive, U.S. officials say.
desc: The weapons are being used in the southeast, the officials say.
author: Eric Schmitt

header: Analysts do not expect hostilities to escalate at sea, despite threats from Ukraine and Russia.
desc: NA
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: In Black Sea Showdown, Russia Batters Ukraine’s Ability to Export Grain
desc: Russia held exercises demonstrating its power to sink ships and stop those that try to run its blockade. For Ukrainian food exports to resume, Moscow said, a list of demands must be met.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko, Farnaz Fassihi, Victoria Kim and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: As Tensions Rise, Zelensky Pushes for Way to Ship Grain Through Black Sea
desc: The Ukrainian leader said he had spoken with the NATO chief and the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine since the full-scale invasion began last February.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Their City in Ruins, a Ukrainian University and Its Students Persevere
desc: Mariupol State University, an oasis amid the war, has graduated its newest class, more than a year after fleeing its devastated home city.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Russia Detains Igor Girkin, a Critic of Putin’s War Effort in Ukraine: What to Know
desc: The arrest was a sign that Russia was clamping down further on dissent, even among prominent nationalists, after last month’s brief mutiny by Wagner mercenaries.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Grain Deal’s End Could Have a Potential ‘Catastrophic Impact’ in Africa
desc: Somalia, Ethiopia and others in the Horn of Africa could be hit the hardest, a leader of an aid group said.
author: Elian Peltier

header: Zelensky says the counteroffensive is slow-going. He blames the wait for weapons.
desc: NA
author: Eric Schmitt

header: At least 31 people died after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Tensions flare at U.N. Security Council over the scuttled Black Sea grain deal.
desc: Officials shared concern of that the stoppage in grain shipments could lead to more global food insecurity and higher prices.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: Russia Raises Interest Rates, Trying to Cool Wartime Economy
desc: With the ruble weakening and the government spending ever more money on the war in Ukraine, Moscow took unexpectedly sharp action to curb inflation.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia raises interest rates in an attempt to cool a wartime economy.
desc: NA
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Weary Soldiers, Unreliable Munitions: Ukraine’s Many Challenges
desc: A month of reporting by New York Times journalists found the fighting mostly stalemated and Ukraine facing an array of obstacles against a determined foe.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak, Dzvinka Pinchuk, Yurii Shyvala and Mauricio Lima

header: Seeking Full Honors, Some Ukrainian Families Wait to Bury Their Dead
desc: Thousands of families have buried soldiers in cemeteries across Ukraine in “Alleys of Heroes.” But some have held off, awaiting a version of Arlington National Cemetery.

header: Russia Destroys Drones Targeting Moscow, and Blames Ukraine
desc: Two buildings were hit but there were no reports of casualties. Video verified by The New York Times shows smoke and damage to several buildings.
author: Andrés R. Martínez, Haley Willis and Tiffany May

header: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Odesa Cathedral and Apartment Buildings
desc: Moscow has renewed its attacks on the port city since pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal last week.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Vivek Shankar

header: Russia Strikes Danube Port, Escalating Attacks on Ukraine Grain Routes
desc: The assault, across the river from Romania, heightened the risk of a more direct confrontation with a NATO member and came on the same day that drones struck buildings in Moscow.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Andrés R. Martínez, Haley Willis and Tiffany May

header: Ukraine at NATO and a Russia-Africa summit: What to watch for this week.
desc: NA
author: Gabriela Sá Pessoa and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The attack on a Danube port raises the threat to Ukraine’s alternative export routes.
desc: NA
author: Andrew Higgins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia struck a port across the Danube from Romania, sending wheat prices up.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew Higgins

header: Putin signs a harsh new law targeting transgender people in Russia.
desc: The law, part of a broader L.G.B.T.Q. crackdown, includes a ban on transition surgery.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russian Attack on Odesa Badly Damages Historic Cathedral
desc: Overnight Russian missile strikes damaged Odesa’s largest Orthodox cathedral. The attack on the city killed one person and injured 22 others, according to Ukrainian officials.
author: The Associated Press and Reuters

header: How War Destroyed a ‘Long and Happy Marriage’
desc: The conflict in Ukraine has split apart millions of families. The story of Andrii Shapovalov and Tetiana Shapovalova reveals how a couple’s bond can become a casualty.

header: Main Thrust of Ukraine’s Offensive May Be Underway, U.S. Officials Say
desc: After holding back many of its units trained and armed by the West, Ukraine is now committing them, the officials said, but it remained unclear whether a full-scale assault was taking place.
author: Eric Schmitt, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Carlotta Gall

header: Leaving the Front Line in Ukraine — to Train for the Front Line
desc: A grueling obstacle course, a few miles from the fighting with Russia, is a final step in the initiation for Ukrainian marines.
author: Maria Varenikova and David Guttenfelder

header: With Grain in the Cross Hairs Again, So Is a Jewel of Ukraine
desc: Odesa, a port city long beloved by travelers, had been largely spared the worst of the war, but that began changing this week.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke

header: U.S. Sends More Weapons to Kyiv Amid Slow Counteroffensive
desc: The package, which includes artillery, air defenses and mine-clearing equipment, will help replenish Ukrainian forces advance through dense Russian minefields and other defenses.
author: Eric Schmitt

header: A Russian defense official reports a ‘massive’ assault.
desc: A Russian occupation official in the Zaporizhzhia region said Ukrainian forces newly equipped with Western weapons had begun a significant attack south of the town of Orikhiv.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Trevor Reed, Former U.S. Marine, Injured While Fighting in Ukraine
desc: Trevor Reed’s condition was not immediately clear. His decision to return to the region and volunteer to fight for Ukraine created some “exasperation” within the Biden administration, an administration official said.
author: Anushka Patil and Helene Cooper

header: ‘They Shoot Without Stopping’: Where Russia Is on the Attack in Ukraine
desc: Along the vast 600-mile front line, Russia is mostly playing defense. In the northeast, it is once again mounting fierce offensive operations.
author: Marc Santora and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: ‘This is the big test’: U.S. officials describe a new Ukrainian effort to sever Russia’s hold on the south.
desc: NA
author: Eric Schmitt

header: Putin Plans Trip to China, Another Russian Leader to Visit North Korea
desc: The visits reflect Moscow’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, given its isolation from the West.
author: Gaya Gupta and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine Launches Rare Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says
desc: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
author: Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski

header: With Slow Advance, Ukraine Aims for Better Shot at Russian Targets
desc: Ukraine is hoping that mile-by-mile gains could bring its weapons closer to Russian supply lines, if its forces can overcome Russia’s heavy defense.
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukraine’s Stepped-Up Assault Grinds Forward, but Scale Is Unclear
desc: Kyiv has intensified its counteroffensive against the Russian invasion, but has kept things murky on the size of the assault, the casualties and what forces it still has in reserve.

header: Russia says it intercepted a drone near Moscow, blaming Ukraine.
desc: Russia said it had foiled the attack, the second such incident in the capital region in less than a week.
author: Victoria Kim

header: Two Ukrainian Service Members Take a Break to Say ‘I Do’
desc: Their wedding was hosted by a charity group that provides uniforms, boots and other essentials to female soldiers, but because of demand recently started to organize such celebrations.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: What Russia Sees: In Crimea, ‘Everyone Is Having Fun’
desc: Since Russia invaded Ukraine last year, Russian government officials and state television have hammered home the message that everything is fine.
author: Alan Yuhas

header: Europe Vowed to Make Russia Pay for the War. It’s Not That Easy.
desc: Confiscating Russian state assets frozen by the United States and Europe could breach international law and set a dangerous precedent, experts say.

header: Wooing African Nations, Putin Casts West as a Common Foe
desc: At a summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin offered free grain as he sought to shore up ties with the continent. But lower-than-hoped-for attendance among African leaders hinted at tempering support.

header: Ukraine aims to drive a wedge through Russian-occupied territory in the south.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukraine reclaims a southern village, but a brutal fight still lies ahead.
desc: NA
author: Marc Santora

header: Amid the Counterattack’s Deadly Slog, a Glimmer of Success for Ukraine
desc: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.

header: Russia Strikes Another Grain Terminal, Extending a Campaign Against Ukraine’s Ports
desc: In St. Petersburg, President Vladimir V. Putin rejected calls for reviving a Black Sea grain deal or for ending fighting.
author: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim

header: Russia Says 2 Drones Hit Buildings in Moscow in Latest Wave of Attacks
desc: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.
author: Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski

header: ‘We Can Never Forgive This’: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.

header: A Spending Boom Fuels Russia’s Wartime Economy, Raising Bubble Fears
desc: The economic strength has helped to maintain popular support for Vladimir Putin’s war, but some have warned the state-led spending is threatening the country’s financial stability.

header: Putin’s Crackdown Leaves Transgender Russians Bracing for Worse

desc: Russia has been using antitank weaponry against the Ukrainian forces’ mine clearing vehicles, an analyst said.

header: Danube Ports, a Lifeline for Ukraine, Come Under Russian Threat

header: Saudi Arabia Will Host Talks About Ukraine’s Peace Plan, Diplomats Say
desc: Envoys from nations including the United States, Brazil, China and India have been invited, but it was not clear who would attend, the diplomats said.

header: Ukraine is moving to export grain through Croatia’s ports.
desc: NA

author: Ivan Nechepurenko, Alina Lobzina and Victoria Kim

header: Ukraine Says Russia Targeted Kyiv With Overnight Drone Attacks

header: Ukraine looks to boost ammunition production.
desc: NA

header: Battlefield Update: Ukraine says it has reclaimed ground south of Bakhmut amid heavy fighting.
desc: NA

header: What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by Ukraine

desc: A court sentenced Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko to seven years in a penal colony, in one of the most prominent cases of Russia’s crackdown on wartime dissent.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Finland Will Close 4 Border Crossings With Russia to Stem Migrants
desc: Officials accused Moscow of loosening migration controls. Relations between the countries deteriorated after Finland joined NATO following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
author: Johanna Lemola and Cassandra Vinograd

header: Friday Briefing
desc: Israel’s search of a major hospital in Gaza.
author: Natasha Frost

header: A Rare Opportunity to See China’s Leader Up Close and (Sort of) Personal
desc: President Xi Jinping of China is one of the most self-contained Chinese leaders in decades, who reveals next to nothing about his personal life.
author: David Pierson, Ana Swanson and David E. Sanger

header: In Talks With Biden, Xi Seeks to Assure and Assert at the Same Time
desc: China’s depiction of Xi Jinping’s U.S. visit reflected his sometimes-contradictory priorities: to project both strength and a willingness to engage with Washington.

header: Europe Moves to Fill Weapons Gap Amid Doubts About U.S. Commitment to Ukraine
desc: Germany, Norway, Britain and others are increasing weapons production to help Kyiv. But the aid may be coming too late as winter looms and Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia stalls.
author: Lara Jakes

header: The War Turns Gaza Into a ‘Graveyard’ for Children
desc: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
author: NA

header: In Ukraine’s Slowed-Down War, Death Comes as Quickly as Ever
desc: Ukraine is facing continual eastern assaults from Russian forces at a bloody cost for both sides, even as the lines on the map barely move.

header: Ukraine Remembers Popular Uprising That Foreshadowed War
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky hailed the so-called Maidan revolution, which toppled a pro-Russia leader 10 years ago, as the “first victory” in a long struggle against Moscow.
