header: She Once Won Eurovision. Now She’s on Russia’s Wanted List.
desc: Jamala, the song contest’s 2016 champion, had been a prominent advocate for Crimea’s Tatar population. The region was annexed from Ukraine by Russia in 2014.

header: U.S. Defense Secretary Visits Ukraine in Show of Support
desc: Lloyd J. Austin III’s trip was a gesture of solidarity when progress in the war against Russia has stalled and there are concerns about U.S. military aid.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine’s Children With Special Needs Suffer the ‘Huge Pressure’ of War
desc: Children with conditions like ADHD and autism have been particularly affected by the traumas and uncertainties of the war and the disruptions to daily life, families and experts say.

header: Electronic Warfare Confounds Civilian Pilots, Far From Any Battlefield
desc: Planes were built to trust GPS signals. Jamming and spoofing in the Middle East and Ukraine have diverted flights and caused inaccurate onboard alerts.
author: Selam Gebrekidan

header: North Korea Launches Rocket With Its First Spy Satellite
desc: The country had failed to put such a satellite into orbit in its two previous attempts at such a launch. This time, it was getting help from Russia, according to South Korea.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: Germany Freezes Government Spending as Budget Crisis Deepens
desc: The government, scrambling to fill a budget gap in the wake of a court ruling, said it would halt future spending commitments.
author: Melissa Eddy

header: Ukraine Heads Into Winter With a Fragile Power Grid
desc: Facilities remain hobbled by Russian attacks, repair work is unfinished and there is little spare equipment, although air defenses have been strengthened.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Putin Bristles as Other Leaders Criticize Russia’s Aggression in Ukraine
desc: For Mr. Putin, it was a rare interaction with Western leaders since the start of the war last year. It was also the first time he had to listen to direct public criticism at an international event.

header: The Certainties of a Putin Election Meet the Uncertainties of War
desc: There is little doubt about the outcome, should he run, but the election in March carries more significance as the first one since the invasion of Ukraine.

header: World Peace in 2024? The Olympics Has a Plan but Not Much Hope.

header: Finland Steps Up Border Closings in Dispute With Russia
desc: The escalation comes as Finland tries to address a rise in the arrivals of migrants and asylum seekers that officials blame on Moscow.

header: U.K. Sets an Immigration Record That the Tories Could Do Without

header: White House Eyes Possible Threat to Good Friday Agreement: Rwanda
desc: Biden administration officials are watching whether the British government’s attempt to salvage its Rwanda asylum policy risks undermining the Northern Ireland peace accord.
author: Mark Landler

header: Russia Bombards Kyiv With ‘Record’ Drone Assault, Ukraine Says

header: Surviving Winter in a Decimated Ukrainian Village

header: Russian Women Protest Long Deployments for Soldiers in Ukraine
desc: “Make way for someone else,” a new grass-roots movement demands as women challenge the official argument that the mobilized troops are needed in combat indefinitely.

header: Ukrainian Attack Cuts Power to Some Russian-Occupied Areas
desc: The assault on energy infrastructure, a significant theater in the war, followed a large-scale Russian drone attack on Kyiv.

header: Storm Batters Southern Ukraine, Spreading Misery for Civilians and Soldiers

header: Hamas releases a Russian hostage, and praises the Kremlin for support.
desc: NA
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

author: The New York Times

header: NATO Ministers Vow to Maintain Support for Ukraine
desc: Amid questions over Western resolve, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other diplomats stressed their commitment to Kyiv’s bid to join the alliance.

header: Germany to Override Debt Limit, Again, to Resolve Budget Crisis
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz pledged financial support for economic modernization and Ukraine, but will need backing for new borrowing to fill a spending gap.

header: NATO Leaders Try to Pin Down U.S. on Ukraine Aid as Republicans Waver
desc: Continued American funding for Ukraine was a key concern for leaders in the military alliance, who met as the current allocation was running down and a Ukrainian counteroffensive appeared stalled.

header: Finland to Close the Last Border Crossing With Russia for Two Weeks
desc: Relations have deteriorated markedly since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the Finns accuse Moscow of orchestrating a flow of migrants in retaliation for Finland joining NATO.

header: Russian Court Extends Detention of American Reporter
desc: The decision means that the journalist, Evan Gershkovich, who has denied the espionage charge against him, will remain in custody until Jan. 30.

desc: Winning the rights to host the major global event is a coup for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s efforts to remake the kingdom’s international image.

desc: In Russia, the pain and loss of the war in Ukraine are felt most profoundly in small villages, where a soldier’s burial produces not just grief but a yearning to find meaning in his death.

desc: Activists said the designation could put L.G.B.T.Q. people and their organizations under threat of criminal prosecution for something as simple as displaying the rainbow flag.

header: Russian Court Extends Detention of U.S. Journalist
desc: Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor who also holds Russian citizenship, was arrested in October on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Paul Whelan’s Family Says He Was Attacked in Russian Prison
desc: Mr. Whelan, who is serving a 16-year sentence in a labor camp, told his family that another inmate struck him in the face.

header: Ukrainians in Germany Weigh Wrenching Choice: Stay or Go Home

header: Monday Briefing: Big State Victories for Modi
desc: Plus Israel’s campaign in Gaza.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Opens War Crimes Inquiry Into Soldiers’ Deaths

desc: NA

desc: NA
author: Glenn Thrush

desc: It is the first time the Biden administration has declared an emergency to expedite arms shipments to the Middle East, which are controversial because of the civilian death toll from Israeli airstrikes.

desc: NA
author: Ben Hubbard

header: The war will worsen poverty in neighboring countries, a study predicts.
desc: NA

desc: Also, King Charles’s cancer diagnosis and the women who ruled the Grammys.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Russian Strikes Hit Ukrainian Cities at a Tense Time for Kyiv
desc: The attacks killed at least five people, officials said, as Ukraine raises pleas for more American aid and President Volodymyr Zelensky considers changes in his administration.
author: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Worries About Losing Its Biggest Weapon: U.S. Military Aid
desc: Without it, Kyiv could hold out for part of the year, one expert said, but would then begin losing the war.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

header: U.S. Ambassadors in the Pacific Urge Action on Ukraine, Israel and Border Bill
desc: With the package teetering on the brink of collapse, diplomats said the nation’s credibility was on the line.
author: Carl Hulse

header: Biden criticizes Republicans for blocking an immigration bill containing aid for Israel and Gaza.
desc: Senators from both parties shaped the legislation, which links a crackdown on unlawful migration to delivering emergency aid to war-torn areas overseas.
author: Erica L. Green

header: Senate Democrats put salvaging an aid bill for Israel and Ukraine on hold for at least a day.
desc: NA
author: Annie Karni

header: Tucker Carlson Says His Putin Interview Will Be Shown on Thursday
desc: The interview, which Moscow said took place this week, would give the Russian leader a chance to reach a potentially sympathetic audience in the United States.
author: Anton Troianovski, Jim Rutenberg and Paul Sonne

header: Sweden Closes Investigation of Pipeline Blasts, but Stays Silent on Cause
desc: The natural-gas connection was sabotaged in September 2022, seven months after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, prompting rampant speculation about who was to blame.
author: Rebecca R. Ruiz and David E. Sanger

header: Giorgia Meloni Solidifies Her Credentials in Europe
desc: The Italian prime minister helped persuade the Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, to go along with a landmark fund for Ukraine. It was a big moment for Europe. And for her.
author: Jason Horowitz

header: A Russian Bank Account May Offer Clues to a North Korean Arms Deal
desc: Moscow may be trying to help Pyongyang with access to the international financial system in exchange for missiles and ammunition, U.S.-allied intelligence officials suggest.
author: Motoko Rich

header: Hungary and E.U. Lock Horns, This Time Over Foreign-Interference Law
desc: The European Commission began a disciplinary procedure over recent legislation that focuses on contacts between foreigners and Hungarians.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk

header: Zelensky Removes His Top General, in Major Shake-Up of Ukraine Military
desc: Gen. Valery Zaluzhny led the effort that thwarted Russia’s initial assault on Kyiv. But his troops have struggled to make progress recently, and tensions have mounted with the civilian leadership.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

header: Putin Calls on U.S. to ‘Negotiate’ on Ukraine in Tucker Carlson Interview
desc: In a two-hour interview, President Vladimir Putin of Russia was more direct than usual about how he sees his Ukraine invasion ending: not with a military victory, but a deal with the West.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: A New General Takes Over as Ukraine Struggles on the Battlefield
desc: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky is taking a job vacated by a general who is well-regarded by the army, in what is widely perceived as a politicized shake-up of Ukraine’s military leadership.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine Has a New Military Commander but the Problems Haven’t Changed
desc: As Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky assumes his role, he must reckon with a grim calculus: When does the cost of defending ground outweigh any benefit gained by inflicting pain on the enemy?
author: Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt

header: Putin to U.S.: Let’s Make a Deal on Ukraine (on My Terms)
desc: The Russian leader clearly believes he can now negotiate from strength, but the message in the Tucker Carlson interview was muddled, critics say.
author: Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski

header: The Brief Reign of Japan’s First Foreign-Born Beauty Queen
desc: Karolina Shiino, a naturalized Japanese citizen who was born in Ukraine, resigned two weeks after winning the Miss Japan crown.
author: Victoria Kim and Hisako Ueno

header: Russia Bars Antiwar Candidate in Election Putin Is All But Sure of Winning
desc: The barring of the only candidate voicing opposition to the war in Ukraine showed how little tolerance the Kremlin has for dissent. Here’s what to know about the presidential election in March.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As Fears Rise, Some Australians Seek U.S.-China Détente
desc: Many countries are trying to figure out what to do about a more insecure, more nuclear-driven world. Australia has an idea.
author: Damien Cave

header: Robert Badinter Dies at 95; Won Fight to End Death Penalty in France
desc: He spent decades as an esteemed defense lawyer but was best known as the justice minister who enacted a 1981 law abolishing capital punishment.
author: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden

header: Reversing Course, Guinness Gives a Frenchman’s Eiffel Tower the Record
desc: Weeks after disqualifying a 24-foot tower made of matchsticks, Guinness World Records apologized and said it had been too “heavy handed.”
author: Jenny Gross

header: Short on Soldiers, Ukraine Debates How to Find the Next Wave of Troops
desc: A potential expansion of the nation’s military draft to replenish the exhausted, battered army has become an emotional, politically charged issue.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Drone Strike Ignites a Fuel Depot, Setting a Neighborhood Ablaze in Ukraine
desc: Seven people from two families died in the inferno in Kharkiv on Friday night, as burning oil flowed like lava. “People were doomed,” an official said.
author: Oleksandr Chubko, Carlotta Gall and Lynsey Addario

header: An Outburst by Trump on NATO May Push Europe to Go It Alone
desc: Many were alarmed by comments that he would “encourage” Russia to attack U.S. allies that didn’t spend enough on their militaries, but European leaders were already pondering the prospect of an alliance without the United States.
author: David E. Sanger

header: Finland Elects Alexander Stubb President as It Ushers in NATO Era
desc: The election of the center-right politician fills a role that is responsible for foreign policy in an era of rising wariness of neighboring Russia.
author: Erika Solomon and Johanna Lemola

header: A bill that includes aid for Israel clears a critical hurdle in the U.S. Senate.
desc: NA
author: Karoun Demirjian

header: On a Frozen Border, Finland Puzzles Over a ‘Russian Game’
desc: As it votes on Sunday for a new president, NATO’s newest member says Moscow is testing it by turning asylum seekers into a political pressure point.
author: Erika Solomon

header: Monday Briefing: Pakistan’s Stunning Election Results
desc: Also, Donald Trump derides NATO and the U.S. prepares to watch the Super Bowl.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Claims Russia Used New Hypersonic Missile for First Time
desc: Russia has not confirmed that a Zircon hypersonic missile was used. The United States says it’s looking into the claim.
author: Constant Méheut

header: As U.S. Weighs Aid, Ukraine Turns to European Allies for Support
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to seek more military assistance in Berlin, Paris and possibly London.
author: Marc Santora

header: A U.S. aid bill for Israel and Ukraine faces Republican opposition in the House.
desc: NA
author: Catie Edmondson and Karoun Demirjian

header: Finland’s New President Faces Unexpected First Test: Not Russia, but Trump
desc: Alexander Stubb was elected vowing to bolster Finland’s new role in NATO, just as Trump’s threats have thrown the future of the alliance into doubt.
author: Johanna Lemola and Erika Solomon

header: A bill with $14 billion for Israel’s war in Gaza passes the Senate but may falter in the House.
desc: NA
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Karoun Demirjian

header: Pope and Argentine President Appear to Find Some Common Ground
desc: The two men hold radically different world views and the president, Javier Milei, has spoken about Francis in harsh terms, but the Vatican said their meeting was “cordial.”
author: Elisabetta Povoledo

header: Austin, Speaking by Video, Reiterates U.S. Support for Ukraine
desc: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III spoke on Wednesday to a U.S.-led group that marshals military aid to Ukraine.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine, Struggling on Land, Claims to Deal Blow to Russia at Sea
desc: The Ukrainian military says it has sunk a large Russian landing ship off the coast of Crimea, although Ukrainian troops inland find themselves in a precarious position.
author: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

header: Losing Ground, Ukraine Seeks New Positions Around Avdiivka
desc: As Russian forces breach a supply line and seek to encircle opposing soldiers, Ukraine’s commanders maneuver to “more advantageous positions.”
author: Marc Santora

header: Russia Hides Its War Toll. We Pieced Together the Clues.
desc: Interviews with wounded Russian soldiers, and with relatives of others, reveal glimpses of what injured veterans can expect when sent home from Ukraine.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: Europe Wants to Stand on Its Own Militarily. Is It Too Little, Too Late?
desc: Outraged by Donald J. Trump’s remarks about encouraging Russia to punish some NATO members, and downbeat about Ukraine’s military prospects, Europe faces growing anxiety over its own security.
author: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

header: How Russia Depicts Wounded Soldiers: As Heroes, or Not at All
desc: Troops with amputated limbs or serious injuries return home to find a patchwork system of treatment and, often, efforts to keep them out of the public eye.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: Wednesday Briefing
desc: Ukraine turns to Europe for more support.
author: Daniel E. Slotnik

header: Putin Says He Prefers Biden Over Trump. Commentators Are Skeptical.
desc: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, called President Biden experienced and predictable. But Moscow watchers said the comments most likely had an ulterior motive.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Thursday Briefing: Indonesia’s New Leader
desc: Also, a coalition forms in Pakistan and motorbikes pile high in Vietnam.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Avdiivka, Longtime Stronghold for Ukraine, Falls to Russians
desc: With Ukraine’s forces at risk of encirclement, the top military commander ordered a retreat. In startlingly candid accounts, soldiers described disarray and despair.
author: Carlotta Gall, Marc Santora and Constant Méheut

header: Five Places Russia Is Fighting to Break Through Ukrainian Lines
desc: Outmanned and outgunned, Ukrainian ground forces are in perhaps their most precarious position since the opening months of the war.
author: Marc Santora, Scott Reinhard and Josh Holder

header: What to Know About the Fall of Avdiivka
desc: Russia’s capture of a city that had been a stronghold of Ukrainian defenses in the Donetsk region is a strategic and symbolic blow.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Zelensky Visits Berlin and Paris to Shore Up Support as U.S. Wavers
desc: The Ukrainian president signed security agreements and sought to push the European leaders to bolster aid as concerns over American funding grow.
author: Erika Solomon and Constant Méheut

header: ‘Dictators Do Not Go on Vacation,’ Zelensky Warns Washington and Europe
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed back against skepticism of a Ukraine victory, calling on world leaders not to ask when the war would end, but why Russia was still able to wage it.
author: Peter Baker, David E. Sanger and Erika Solomon

header: Navalny’s Death Raises Tensions Between U.S. and Russia
desc: President Biden condemned “Putin and his thugs” for the Russian dissident’s demise, while European allies urgently sought assurances that the United States would not abandon them.
author: Peter Baker

header: Where does Navalny’s reported death leave Russia and Putin?
desc: The reported death of Aleksei A. Navalny ushers in a new turning point for President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia, underscoring both the Kremlin’s power and the potential for instability that continues to threaten it.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: For Ukrainians, Navalny was a controversial figure.
desc: Mr. Navalny was respected in Ukraine for his political activism, but he was also seen in a less-flattering light there because of his comments that appeared to question its territorial sovereignty.
author: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: In Prison or Out, Navalny Was the Thorn in Putin’s Side
desc: A straight-talking former real estate lawyer, he stayed relevant even from prison, pleading with Russians not to give up or give in to their fears and railing against the “criminal” war in Ukraine.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: With Prison Certain and Death Likely, Why Did Navalny Return?
desc: An activist who thrived on agitation, he feared irrelevancy in exile. Winning new respect as he continued to lambast the Kremlin from behind bars cost him his life.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: The Death Throes of a Ukrainian City
desc: Toward the end of Russia’s long assault, hundreds of civilians still remained in Avdiivka. Those who escaped in the last weeks spoke of relentless devastation.
author: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: City’s Fall Leaves Ukraine With an Even Tougher Fight Ahead
desc: After the capture of Avdiivka, Ukrainian forces will need a new defensive line in unforgiving terrain, while Russia tries to press its advantage.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: As Putin Threatens, Despair and Hedging in Europe
desc: There is a dawning recognition that the continent urgently needs to step up its own defense, especially as the U.S. wavers, but the commitments still are not coming.
author: David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

header: A Stunned Russian Opposition in Exile Considers a Future Without Navalny
desc: The death of Aleksei A. Navalny in a Russian prison has been a blow to an opposition movement in which he was the figurehead. But it has also raised hopes of a united front against President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina

header: Hungary Snubs U.S. Senators Pushing for Sweden’s Entry Into NATO
desc: Officials in Budapest declined to meet with a bipartisan group of American lawmakers who favor expanding the military alliance.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Arrested for Leaving Flowers, Navalny Mourners Fear Worse to Come
desc: At least 366 people were detained over the weekend, leading to concern that the arrests could signal greater government repression ahead of Russia’s elections in March.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Navalny’s Death Shocked the World, but Will It Galvanize Opposition to Putin?
desc: His death united world leaders and demonstrators in grief, but it also left Russia without a charismatic counterweight to its leader’s increasingly repressive policies.
author: Mark Landler

header: U.S. Says It Struck 5 Houthi Targets in Yemen, Including an Underwater Drone
desc: The American military said it believes it is the first time such an undersea weapon had been used in the current conflict in the Red Sea.
author: Julian E. Barnes

header: Ursula von der Leyen Seeks Second Term as Top E.U. Official
desc: The German politician has been European Commission president since 2019, becoming a key contact for the Biden administration.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Israel’s Occupation of Palestinian Territories Draws Focus of U.N. Court
desc: Dozens of countries are expected to argue before the International Court of Justice about the legality of Israeli actions in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
author: Marlise Simons

header: Protesting Polish Farmers Block Much of Ukraine’s Western Border
desc: The farmers are demonstrating against what they see as an influx of Ukrainian food products crowding the Polish market and undercutting their livelihood.
author: Anatol Magdziarz, Maria Varenikova and Emma Bubola

header: Russian Forces Press On With Attacks in Southern Ukraine
desc: The assaults on the village of Robotyne, which come at the same time as successful attacks in the east, are designed to pressure Ukrainian troops across the front line, analysts say.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Russian Pilot Who Defected to Ukraine Is Believed Dead in Spain
desc: The apparent death in Spain of Maksim Kuzminov is likely to fuel speculation that it was the work of Russia’s intelligence services.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Constant Méheut

header: Russia Arrests U.S. Citizen, Accusing Her of Treason by Aiding Ukraine
desc: The country’s main security agency said the 33-year-old detainee lived in Los Angeles. A lawyers group said she was accused of donating $50 to the war effort.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: A Russian Military Blogger Dies After Criticizing Army Losses
desc: The ultranationalist blogger, Andrei Morozov, had described a campaign of intimidation against him and threatened to end his own life.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: In Taiwan, Visiting Lawmakers Say U.S. Support Is Firm
desc: A bipartisan House delegation said the United States would stand by the island in the face of pressure from China, drawing connections between Taiwan’s cause and Ukraine’s.
author: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

header: As Russia and the U.S. argue before the I.C.J., each accuses the other of hypocrisy.
desc: NA
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: U.S. Warns Allies Russia Could Put a Nuclear Weapon Into Orbit This Year
desc: The American assessments are divided, however, and President Vladimir Putin denied having such an intention, saying that Russia was “categorically against” it.
author: David E. Sanger

header: U.S. Defends Israel’s Occupation of the West Bank at Top U.N. Court
desc: A U.S. official urged judges not to call for Israel’s withdrawal from occupied territory, arguing that Israel faced “very real security needs” and that a Palestinian state must be established for a lasting peace.
author: Marlise Simons, Cassandra Vinograd, Neil MacFarquhar and Thomas Fuller

header: Wife, Protector and Now Political Heir: Yulia Navalnaya Rallies Russians
desc: The wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader long shunned the spotlight, but his death in prison may make that impossible. “I have no right to give up,” she said.
author: Neil MacFarquhar

header: Unpredictable Strongman? Two Years Into War, Putin Embraces the Image.
desc: Vladimir Putin is drawing on history to position himself in the realm of Russian rulers of the past. Critics say his grip on power is not as strong as it seems.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: For Many Ukrainians, It’s Been a 10-Year War, Not a 2-Year One
desc: Russia’s invasion came in two phases, many Ukrainians say: the first a decade ago, when it sent soldiers over the border in an unacknowledged military intervention, and the second when it began its full assault two years ago.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and The New York Times

header: Navalny’s Mother Says Authorities Are ‘Blackmailing’ Her Over Son’s Remains
desc: She said Russian authorities told her they would not release his remains unless she agreed to a “secret funeral.” Meanwhile, Aleksei Navalny’s widow met with President Biden.
author: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Bosnia’s Dysfunction Snarls Efforts to Curb Moscow’s Reach in the Balkans
desc: The United States and Europe have championed a new pipeline to bring gas to Bosnia and cut supplies from Russia. But the project has been stalled by feuding among ethnic groups.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Navalny and the Mirage of a Different Russia
desc: Aleksei Navalny symbolized a possibility for Russia. His death symbolizes its end.
author: Amanda Taub

header: Inside the Hospitals Treating Brain Injuries in Ukraine
desc: Two years of war produced thousands of damaged brains. We followed surgeons and soldiers on the road to recovery.
author: Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Orban Gives Green Light to Sweden’s NATO Bid
desc: Viktor Orban, the Hungarian prime minister, said after a meeting with Sweden’s leader, and a deal for more fighter jets, that the two countries are “ready to fight for each other.”
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Friday Briefing: Two Years of War in Ukraine
desc: Also, an attempt at a moon landing.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Waiting for Serhiy
desc: After nearly two years and only scraps of information, a Ukrainian family still hopes their son, a marine captured by the Russians in Mariupol, will come home soon.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and David Guttenfelder

header: The Spy War: How the C.I.A. Secretly Helps Ukraine Fight Putin
desc: For more than a decade, the United States has nurtured a secret intelligence partnership with Ukraine that is now critical for both countries in countering Russia.
author: Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine Marks 2nd Anniversary of Russian Invasion, Determined Despite Setbacks
desc: European and other Western leaders gathered in Kyiv to pledge support for Ukraine amid U.S. reluctance, while its troops suffer growing losses on the battlefield, where the Russians have been gaining ground.
author: Marc Santora

header: 31,000 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed in Two Years of War, Zelensky Says
desc: The tally that President Volodymyr Zelensky revealed on Sunday differs sharply from that given by U.S. officials, who have said the number is closer to 70,000.
author: Carlotta Gall and Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine’s Deepening Fog of War
desc: Two years after Russia’s full-scale invasion, Ukrainian leaders are seeking a path forward in the face of ferocious assaults and daunting unknowns.
author: Marc Santora

header: Hard Lessons Make for Hard Choices 2 Years Into the War in Ukraine
desc: Western sanctions haven’t worked. Weapons from allies are running low. Pressure may build on Kyiv to seek a settlement, even from a weakened position.
author: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

header: Russia’s Brutal War Calculus
desc: The costs of two years of war in Ukraine have been enormous. But many Russians are feeling optimistic.
author: Paul Sonne and Josh Holder

header: In Russia, Knowing That Her Son Is Dead, and Waiting for Him Anyway
desc: She watched, distressed, as Aleksei was sent off to war. Now, 14 months after he died in eastern Ukraine, Yulia Seleznyova holds a sliver of hope for a miracle.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Belarus Holds an Election, but the Outcome Is Not Hard to Predict
desc: The opposition in exile has called for a boycott of the parliamentary vote, which includes only parties that support Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, who has ruled the country for 30 years.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Fire in Valencia, Spain, Leaves Residents Homeless After Panicked Escapes
desc: A fire that killed at least 10 people left many refugees from Ukraine without homes and others scrambling to rebuild their lives.
author: Rachel Chaundler

header: Kremlin Warns Against NATO Ground Intervention in Ukraine
desc: The warning came in response to comments by President Emmanuel Macron of France, who said “nothing should be ruled out” when asked about the possibility.
author: Paul Sonne and Constant Méheut

header: The NATO Welcoming Sweden Is Larger and More Determined
desc: The alliance’s expansion, with Finland last year and soon Sweden, was a consequence from the invasion of Ukraine that Russia’s president may not have calculated.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: In Ukraine, Russia Is Inching Forward Death by Death
desc: Russian forces have an unorthodox view of acceptable levels of military losses, with a willingness to expend troops and equipment to make even small gains on the battlefield.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Macron Does Not Rule Out Sending Western Troops to Ukraine
desc: The French leader said that talks had not resulted in any consensus among European officials on putting troops on the ground in an “official” way, but that “anything is possible.”
author: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden

header: Senate Aide Investigated Over Unofficial Actions in Ukraine
desc: Kyle Parker says he delivered sniper gear as part of his unabashed support for Ukraine. Investigators say there may be “counterintelligence issues.”
author: Lara Jakes, Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Russian Court Jails Leading Rights Advocate for ‘Discrediting’ Military
desc: Oleg Orlov, 70, a co-chairman of Memorial, which shared the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize, was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison for speaking out on the Ukraine war.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: Wednesday Briefing: Russia Warned Against NATO Troops in Ukraine
desc: Plus, the latest on a possible cease-fire in Gaza.
author: Jonathan Wolfe

header: Hungary’s Parliament Approves Sweden’s NATO Bid After Stalling
desc: Budapest had been the final obstacle to the Nordic country’s joining the alliance, which has been trying to isolate Russia over its war in Ukraine.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Ego, Putin or Jets? Reasons for Orban’s Stance on Sweden Perplex Many.
desc: The Hungarian leader has given various rationales for stalling Swedish membership in NATO. The real reason may have to do with his own standing and domestic politics.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Tuesday Briefing: Hungary Approved Sweden’s NATO Bid
desc: Plus, movement in a possible Israel-Hamas deal.
author: Jonathan Wolfe

header: Seeking to Unsettle Russia, Macron Provokes Allies
desc: The French president’s openness to Western troops in Ukraine signaled a quest for military resolve. But some allies felt blindsided.
author: Roger Cohen

header: Ukraine Charges Key Figure in Arms Trade With Corruption
desc: A Times investigation showed how the war helped Serhiy Pashinsky rehabilitate a troubled reputation. Now he faces charges related to accusations about his past.
author: Daria Mitiuk

header: Putin Says West Risks Nuclear Conflict if It Intervenes More in Ukraine
desc: “We also have weapons that can strike targets on their territory,” Mr. Putin said in an annual speech. “Do they not understand this?”
author: Anton Troianovski

header: New Nuclear Threats From Putin, Timed for a Moment of Anxiety
desc: Repeated threats by President Vladimir Putin of Russia to make use of nuclear weapons have become the background theme of the war in Ukraine, often timed for maximum effect.
author: David E. Sanger

header: Russia Took the City. Now It’s Coming for Their Villages.
desc: Ukrainian farmers and miners and their families who live to the west of the recently captured Avdiivka are poised to flee in the face of a Russian onslaught.
author: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: A Breakaway Region of Moldova Asks Russia for Protection
desc: Transnistria declared independence in 1992 but is not recognized internationally. The request by the territory’s legislature could fuel regional tensions as the war in Ukraine rages.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Surprisingly Weak Ukrainian Defenses Help Russian Advance
desc: Ukraine only built a sparse, rudimentary defensive line outside Avdiivka. Russia is taking advantage.
author: Josh Holder, Constant Méheut, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: From a Funeral Image, the Textures of Faith and State in Russia
desc: The opposition leader Aleksei Navalny called himself “a typical post-Soviet believer” of Russian Orthodox faith. But the institution of the church bound itself closely to President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Oleg Matsnev

header: For Navalny’s Followers, a ‘Surge of Inspiration’ at a Sad Event
desc: Although the funeral of Aleksei Navalny seemed to underline Vladimir Putin’s dominance of Russia, it was also a day when pent-up dissent, and optimism, re-emerged, if only briefly.
author: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: Why More American Weapons Will Soon Be Made Outside America
desc: With the wars in Ukraine and Gaza straining U.S. arsenals, Washington is seeking to expand production with global partners like Australia.
author: Damien Cave

header: Thousands Turn Out for Navalny’s Funeral in Moscow
desc: The police presence appeared heavy for the service. Some attendees shouted, “No to war” and “Russia will be free” as they marched to the cemetery where the opposition leader was to be buried.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: How Germany’s Most Wanted Criminal Hid in Plain Sight
desc: Daniela Klette, a militant from the Red Army Faction, was on the run for decades. Yet with publicly available digital recognition tools, German police could probably have found her much sooner.
author: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Biden Says U.S. Will Begin Aid Airdrops in Gaza
desc: The president said that the United States would work with Jordan and other allies to deliver aid by air and that supplies could eventually be delivered by sea.
author: Julian E. Barnes and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Now It’s Germany’s Turn to Frustrate Allies Over Ukraine
desc: First President Emmanuel Macron of France, then Chancellor Olaf Scholz, exposed divisions among Western countries trying to avoid direct hostilities with Russia.
author: David E. Sanger and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Russian Strike’s Toll Rises to 12 as Zelensky Blames Air Defense Delay
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not refer to the United States, but his words appeared to reflect frustration over a stalled American aid package.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The U.N. team’s sexual violence report describes its members’ expertise in the field as extensive.
desc: NA
author: The New York Times

header: Kremlin Seeks to Suppress Navalny’s Influence, in Death as in Life
desc: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
author: Paul Sonne and Oleg Matsnev

header: Tuesday Briefing: Trump can appear on ballots
desc: Also, France protects abortion rights and a U.N. report on sexual assault during the Oct. 7 attack.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Shift in Russian Tactics Intensifies Air War in Ukraine
desc: Moscow’s recent gains in the east have been aided by more aggressive air support on the front lines. But that also has helped Ukraine shoot down enemy planes in the past two weeks.
author: Constant Méheut

header: International Court Accuses 2 Russian Officers of War Crimes in Ukraine
desc: Arrest warrants were issued by the International Criminal Court for two military officials, a general and an admiral, both accused of targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.
author: Marlise Simons

header: Ukraine’s First Lady Declines Invitation to State of the Union Address
desc: Olena Zelenska’s office cited a scheduling conflict. The Russian opposition figure Yulia Navalnaya also declined an invitation.
author: Constant Méheut and Michael D. Shear

header: Too Little Ammunition, Too Many Russians: The Harrowing Retreat From Avdiivka
desc: The fall of the city, when it came in mid-February, was brutal and fast. Soldiers fought for their lives. Many did not make it.
author: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Lynsey Addario

header: Russia Strikes Odesa With Missile During Visit by Zelensky and Greek Leader
desc: Neither man was hurt, and it was unclear whether the Russian Army was targeting them.
author: Constant Méheut

header: I.M.F. Agrees to Much Larger Rescue Package for Egypt
desc: The International Monetary Fund will provide $8 billion to Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades.
author: Nada Rashwan

header: Egyptians Are Buying and Selling Gold Just to Stay Afloat
desc: Clamor for the precious metal is growing as the buying power of the country’s currency plunges in value against the dollar, and inflation eats away at savings.
author: Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan

header: Thursday Briefing: Haley Drops Out
desc: Also, Israel-Hamas talks stall before Ramadan.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Wednesday Briefing: Americans Vote on Super Tuesday

header: E.U. ministers discuss expanding sanctions against Iran’s weapons program.
desc: NA

desc: NA

desc: NA
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: A Boxing Victory Offers Hope to War-Weary Ukrainians
desc: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk became the world’s undisputed heavyweight champion on Sunday. The victory has lifted morale in a country struggling to contain Russian advances on the battlefield.
author: Constant Méheut, Maria Varenikova and Nataliia Novosolova

header: Russia Presses Attacks in Northeast Ukraine, Seeking Buffer Zone on Border
desc: Advances by Russian forces have raised fears that they could bring their artillery in range of Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Russia and Ukraine Engage in Dueling Air Assaults Behind the Front Lines
desc: Both sides have been looking for ways to inflict damage beyond the battlefield, targeting military logistics hubs and urban centers.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Russians Poured Over Ukraine’s Border. There Was Little to Stop Them.
desc: The stunning incursion into the Kharkiv Region lays bare the challenges facing Ukraine’s weary and thinly stretched forces as Russia ramps up its summer offensive.
author: Michael Schwirtz, Jeffrey Gettleman, Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut

header: The Technocrat Who’s Taking Control of Putin’s War Effort
desc: Andrei R. Belousov, an intellectual with no military experience, is known for backing a state-dominated economy.
author: Paul Sonne

header: Xi’s Warm Embrace of Putin in China Is a Defiance of the West
desc: Western leaders looking for signs that the Chinese leader used his influence on President Vladimir V. Putin to end the war in Ukraine are likely to be disappointed.
author: David Pierson

header: Global Tensions and a Hostile Neighbor Await Taiwan’s New Leader
desc: President Lai Ching-te has pledged to stay on his predecessor’s narrow path of resisting Beijing without provoking it. It won’t be easy.
author: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Meaghan Tobin

header: Toxic Political Culture Has Even Some Slovaks Calling Country ‘a Black Hole’
desc: Slovakia has long been dogged by criticism that it is prone to authoritarianism, but a frenzy of blame since an assassination attempt has heightened such concerns.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Crash Comes as Iran and the U.S. Are Working Through Several Conflicts
desc: The two countries are groping their way out of a number of simultaneous crises, including over the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.
author: David E. Sanger

header: Georgia’s President Vetoes Foreign Influence Law
desc: The law has triggered protests and threatens to derail the nation’s pro-European aspirations in favor of closer ties with Russia.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russian Forces Close In on Ukrainian Town in Northeast
desc: Vovchansk has been a prime target of Russia’s offensive in the northeast as it seeks to push back Ukrainian troops from the border.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Faced With a Russian Onslaught, Ukraine Struggles to Keep the Lights On
desc: The government has for the first time ordered nationwide rolling blackouts for Monday night to conserve energy.
author: Maria Varenikova, Constant Méheut and Nataliia Novosolova

header: ‘What’s the Problem?’ Zelensky Challenges West Over Hesitations.
desc: “Shoot down what’s in the sky over Ukraine,” he said in a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times. “And give us the weapons to use against Russian forces on the borders.”
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Daniel Berehulak

header: Forced to Relive Childhood Horrors in Old Age
desc: The oldest Ukrainians whose towns have been bombarded and overrun by Russia’s invasion have memories of similar miseries at the hands of Nazi Germany in World War II.
author: Emile Ducke and Evelina Riabenko

header: Zelensky Says ‘Escalation Has Already Occurred’ in Ukraine War
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suggested that Western allies were hesitant to take bolder steps to aid his country in part because they wanted to maintain trade and diplomatic ties with Russia.
author: Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: Evacuation Point
desc: As they evacuated from the fighting in Ukraine, the passengers already thought of what they left behind.
author: Emile Ducke

header: Under Relentless Russian Assault, Ukraine Adopts a Defensive Crouch
desc: As Moscow’s forces retake land from which they were ousted at the end of 2022, the Ukrainian military has adopted a strategy of fighting while slowly falling back to more heavily fortified positions.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Zelensky Presses for Approval to Fire American Weapons at Targets in Russia
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that he needed “weapons and permission” to better defend his country.
author: Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: NATO’s Reluctance to Shoot Down Russian Missiles Frustrates Zelensky
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged NATO allies to play an active role in the war, saying it was a matter of defense.
author: Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: Russia Starts Tactical Nuclear Drills, in a Warning to Ukraine’s Allies
desc: Moscow has said the exercise is a response to “provocative statements and threats of individual Western officials.”
author: Paul Sonne

header: Advancing Russian Troops Threaten to Reverse Some of Ukraine’s Hard-Won Gains
desc: Such losses could hurt Ukrainian morale as Russia makes advances all along the front line.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Russia Detains Another Defense Official, in New Sign of Putin Shake-Up
desc: Lt. Gen. Vadim Shamarin is accused of “large-scale” bribery, the latest in a series of high-profile arrests that have coincided with the appointment of a new defense minister.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Friday Briefing: Aid Trickles Through Gaza Pier
desc: Also, China holds ‘punishment’ drills around Taiwan.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Steps Up Attacks With U.S. Long-Range Missiles
desc: The assaults have hit military targets in Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine. Pressure is now mounting on Washington to let Kyiv fire the missiles into Russia itself.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Russia Bombs Hardware Superstore in Kharkiv, Killing 12, Ukraine Says
desc: It was the latest attack in a sustained bombing campaign that has made life increasingly dangerous for civilians in the northeastern Ukrainian city.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Some U.S. Weapons Stymied by Russian Jamming in Ukraine
desc: Two classified Ukrainian reports show that some U.S. precision-guided weapons are vulnerable to electronic warfare, an element in Ukraine’s recent battlefield setbacks.
author: Carlotta Gall and Vladyslav Golovin

header: Ukraine Starts Freeing Some Prisoners to Join Its Military
desc: Nearly 350 inmates have been freed under a new law that allows them to serve in exchange for the possibility of parole, the country’s justice minister said.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Drones Have Offered Last Line of Defense for a Strategic Ukrainian Town
desc: Short of troops and artillery, soldiers increasingly have been relying on pilotless drones to drop explosives and supplies to hold Chasiv Yar. But how long can they slow the Russian advance?
author: Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima

header: In Interview, Zelensky Challenges West Over Hesitations to Support Ukraine
desc: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the United States and Europe to do more to defend his nation, dismissing fears of nuclear escalation and proposing that NATO planes shoot down Russian missiles in Ukrainian airspace.
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Dmitriy Khavin, Caterina Clerici, Daniel Bateman, Phil Caller and Rebecca Suner

header: Onstage, Witches and Cossacks Strike a Chord With Ukrainians
desc: A play based on a 19th-century literary classic is a smash hit among Ukrainians who see in the story cultural and historical echoes of what they face after two years of war.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Optimistic About the War in Ukraine, Putin Unleashes a Purge at Home
desc: Despite years of criticism, President Vladimir V. Putin has only now changed his defense minister and allowed high-level corruption arrests.
author: Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia Plans New Offensive in Ukraine’s Northeast, Zelensky Says
desc: Moscow is again amassing forces near the border, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned. His comments came as officials said that a Russian strike had killed at least 16 people in Kharkiv.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: U.S. Lawmakers Visit Taiwan and Vow Support in Face of Chinese Military Drills
desc: A bipartisan delegation promised to stand by the island’s newly elected president, Lai Ching-te, after Beijing surrounded the self-governing island with naval vessels and aircraft.
author: Catie Edmondson

header: North Korean Rocket Carrying Spy Satellite Explodes After Takeoff
desc: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has made deploying a fleet of spy satellites one of his country’s latest <U+200B>military ambitions.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: China, Japan and South Korea Hold Regional Summit Overshadowed by U.S.
desc: In the first trilateral meeting since 2019, the neighbors sought common ground in trade and cultural exchange while tiptoeing around thorny security issues.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: A Border Runs Through Their Families. Now It’s a Front Line.
desc: In northeastern Ukraine, and in the part of Russia it touches, the war strains the emotions of people with relatives, and family histories, that span both sides.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Calls Mount to Let Ukraine Strike Russia With Western Weapons
desc: The U.S. and other allies have banned Ukraine from firing Western weapons into Russia. Kyiv says that has handcuffed its ability to prevent cross-border attacks.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Blinken Hints U.S. May Accept Ukrainian Strikes in Russia With American Arms
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken made his remarks after some European leaders called on President Biden to lift the restrictions he has imposed on Ukraine’s use of U.S. weapons.
author: Edward Wong

header: Divisions Set to Deepen in Georgia After Foreign Influence Law Passes
desc: Many Georgians see restrictions on organizations that receive international funding as a sign their country is moving away from the West and toward a Russia they abhor.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: What the I.C.J. Ruling Actually Means for Israel’s Offensive in Rafah
desc: There is a substantial consensus among legal experts that Israel cannot continue its current Rafah offensive without violating the court’s order.
author: Amanda Taub

header: Three European Countries Formally Recognize Palestinian Statehood
desc: The moves are a rebuke to Israel, who is the face of mounting international anger over the country’s military offensive in Gaza.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Georgia’s Ruling Party Secures a Contentious Law on Foreign Influence
desc: The Parliament, controlled by the Georgian Dream party, overrode a presidential veto of a bill critics say could undermine the country’s efforts to join the European Union.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine Warns of Deepening Russian Threat in the North
desc: Analysts say an offensive in the Kharkiv or Sumy regions could stretch Ukrainian troops to the breaking point and allow Moscow to punch through.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Ukrainian Drone Strikes Target Russian Nuclear Radar Stations
desc: A radar facility more than 1,100 miles into Russia was damaged, satellite imagery showed. The attacks have drawn concern from U.S. officials.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Blinken Hints U.S. May Allow Ukraine Greater Latitude to Strike in Russia
desc: The U.S. secretary of state suggested that Ukraine’s use of American-supplied arms could expand beyond the current limitation to strikes in the Kharkiv area.
author: Edward Wong

header: On Northern Border, Permission to Fire Into Russia Buoys Ukraine
desc: After weeks of entreaties, Ukraine won permission to hit targets inside Russia with American-made weapons, a tactic that it says will help it defend territory in the northeast.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Weapons That Ukraine Might Use to Shoot Into Russia
desc: Decisions by President Biden and others give Ukrainian forces several new options. But they’re still restricted in the use of Western missiles that could strike far inside Russia.
author: Lara Jakes

header: Taking the Fight to Russia: The West Weighs Ukraine’s Use of Its Weapons
desc: More NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.
author: Lara Jakes

header: U.S. Defense Chief Says Asia-Pacific Region Remains Priority
desc: Speaking in Singapore, Lloyd J. Austin III sought to reassure allies and put China on notice that Ukraine and the Mideast were not distracting the U.S. from this focus.
author: Chris Buckley and Damien Cave

header: After Trump’s Conviction, a Wary World Waits for the Fallout
desc: Already braced for uncertainty about the U.S. election, countries in Europe and Asia are now even more unclear about the future of American diplomacy.
author: Hannah Beech and Paul Sonne

header: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine’s Energy System, Again
desc: The large-scale air assault struck several sites in western Ukraine, including places near the borders with NATO member countries.
author: Constant Méheut

header: She’s 98, and Walked Past Corpses to Escape Russian Attacks
desc: “If only everything would stop,” said Lidiia Lomikovska, who walked to safety after her town was attacked. But for civilians in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, it is not stopping.
author: Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Tyler Hicks

header: 46 Children Were Taken From Ukraine. Many Are Up for Adoption in Russia.
desc: The New York Times traced how a web of officials and politicians aligned with President Vladimir V. Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
author: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: How We Found 46 Ukrainian Children Taken by Russian Officials
desc: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
author: Nikolay Nikolov, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Natalie Reneau

header: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
desc: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
author: Emma Bubola

header: In Singapore, China Warns U.S. While Zelensky Seeks Support
desc: The annual Shangri-La Dialogue became a stage for competing demands on U.S. global power, including the war in Ukraine and tensions over Taiwan.
author: Chris Buckley and Damien Cave

header: As Challenges Pile Up, a Spate of Summitry Spotlights Western Resolve
desc: Wars in Ukraine and Gaza, along with Donald J. Trump’s candidacy, are testing the Western alliance. But starting with the 80th anniversary of D-Day this week, leaders have a rare opportunity to showcase unity.
author: Mark Landler

header: The Internet’s Final Frontier: Remote Amazon Tribes
desc: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
author: Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

header: Monday Briefing: What’s Next for South Africa
desc: Also, India’s elections and internet in the Amazon.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Strikes Into Russia With Western Weapons, Official Says
desc: The official said Ukraine had destroyed missile launchers in the Russian region of Belgorod using an American-made rocket system.
author: Maria Varenikova, Constant Méheut and Aric Toler

header: What Ukraine Has Lost
desc: We measured every town, street and building blown apart in Ukraine to show the first comprehensive picture of where people can’t return home.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman, Finbarr O’Reilly, Tim Wallace and Marco Hernandez

header: How We Tracked Every Damaged or Destroyed Building in Ukraine
desc: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.
author: Marco Hernandez and Nikolay Nikolov

header: In Former Soviet States, a Tug of War Between East and West
desc: Geopolitical rivalry, intensified by fighting in Ukraine, is amplifying domestic struggles in countries like Georgia and Moldova whose people are split on which side to support.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Wednesday Briefing: Modi’s Bruising Path to a Third Term
desc: Also, a Times analysis of the destruction in Ukraine.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: As Ukraine’s Summer Starts With Blackouts, Worries Over Winter Begin
desc: Recent rolling power outages have raised alarm about what will happen when cold weather arrives and energy consumption goes even higher.
author: Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: Between the Offensives: Images From a Journey in Ukraine’s Borderland
desc: Photographs from two trips along Ukraine’s northeastern border regions, in the months before Russia renewed an offensive there, reveal loss and transformation.
author: David Guttenfelder and Peter Robins

header: Bombed and Bruised, a City Braces for Another Russian Onslaught
desc: Residents of Sumy, in northeastern Ukraine, repelled Moscow’s forces in 2022. Now, after months of punishing airstrikes, Ukrainian officials say the Kremlin is preparing a new offensive.
author: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Biden Links Fight for Ukraine With Allied Effort on D-Day
desc: Speaking in Normandy, the president argued that similar principles were at stake in both wars: the defense of freedom and a rules-based international order.
author: Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

header: Zelensky Shares Emotional Moment With U.S. Veteran at D-Day Ceremony
desc: The veteran, Melvin Hurwitz, embraced the Ukrainian president and called him “the savior of the people.” Mr. Zelensky told Mr. Hurwitz that he and his fellow World War II veterans had “saved Europe.”
author: Orlando Mayorquín

header: Russia Detains a French National Suspected of Collecting Military Data
desc: The detention is the latest in a series in which foreigners have been arrested or held against their will in Russia, exacerbating tensions with the West.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The E.U. Is Voting. It’s Never Mattered More.
desc: Hundreds of millions of voters are electing a European Parliament this weekend. The outcome will help tip the balance of the continent’s struggle between unity and nationalism.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: D-Day at 80
desc: Veterans of the pivotal battle of World War II are disappearing. Europe, facing new conflict, recalls what their comrades died for.
author: Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

header: A Russian American Is Sentenced in Russia Over Social Media Posts
desc: The latest detention of an American national in Russia has renewed fears that the Kremlin is seeking to use U.S. citizens as bargaining chips.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina

header: Slovak Prime Minister Speaks Publicly for First Time Since Assassination Attempt
desc: Robert Fico said in a video address that he hoped to return to work in the coming weeks. He blamed the political opposition for the attack, a notion that the parties have strongly denied.
author: Jesus Jiménez and Sara Cincurova

header: Energy Drinks Boost Ukraine’s Soldiers, and Its Economy
desc: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
author: Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Biden Straddles the Patriotic and the Political in Speech at Normandy
desc: The president said “echoes of 1944 are summoning us” during his address that honored the valor of D-Day fighters.
author: Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

header: As Fighting Rages in Ukraine, a Struggle Is On for Artillery Supremacy
desc: Ukrainian forces say U.S. shells are making a difference. Across the border, they say, Russia is trying to get its artillery nearer targets like the city of Kharkiv.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Macron Hosts Biden in Paris, Honoring a Not Always Easy Bond
desc: The friendship between France and the U.S. endures. But tensions have mounted over the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, and how Europe can step out of America’s shadow.
author: Roger Cohen and Peter Baker

header: Biden and Macron Talk Togetherness, With No Mention of Discord Over Gaza
desc: The two presidents, in a brief appearance before reporters, declined to take questions, in a departure from tradition.
author: Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

header: French-American Friendship in Four Courses
desc: Under Emmanuel Macron, “culinary diplomacy” is back on the menu, with a lavish dinner fortifying an old alliance at a tense historical moment.
author: Roger Cohen

header: The E.U. Votes: What We’re Watching For
desc: The main things to know as voters in 27 countries head to the ballot box to shape the next five years of European Union policies.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Sarah Hurtes

header: Jordan Bardella, the New Face of France’s Surging Right
desc: Charismatic and clean cut, shorn of the Le Pen name, the young National Rally leader took his party to its blockbuster showing in European elections on Sunday.
author: Roger Cohen

header: British Leader Apologizes for Leaving D-Day Commemoration Early
desc: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak conceded that he made a major public relations misstep in the heat of a general election campaign.
author: Mark Landler

header: Their City Has a Plaque From Putin. They Want Zelensky to Tear It Down.
desc: Some residents of Bari, Italy, hope Ukraine’s president will drop by while at a nearby summit to help rid them of a memento of links with Russia.
author: Lara Jakes

header: Reconstruction Official Resigns, Highlighting Tensions in Ukraine
desc: The departure of the official, who had pointed up mismanagement of funds, was a blow to government efforts to assuage allies’ concerns about how aid is spent.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Releases Female Prison Inmates to Join Ukraine War
desc: Tens of thousands of male convicts have been freed to fight in Ukraine. It is not clear if a small contingent of female volunteers released from a prison portends wider use of female soldiers.
author: Ekaterina Bodyagina and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukrainian Activist Traces Roots of War in ‘Centuries of Russian Colonization’
desc: One Ukrainian researcher and podcaster is a leading voice in efforts to rethink Ukrainian-Russian relations through the prism of colonialism.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Sunny Days in Moscow
desc: A single image of a blustery day in wartime Moscow captures the feeling of triumph sweeping through Russia.
author: Nanna Heitmann

header: Buoyed by Election, Meloni Basks in Spotlight as Italy Hosts G7
desc: The Italian prime minister was a rare leader to be fortified by the vote for the European Parliament. This week she has a chance to show her influence on an even broader stage.
author: Emma Bubola

header: Battered by Far Right in E.U. Vote, Macron Calls for New Elections in France
desc: The president’s decision, on the eve of the summer Olympic Games that begin in Paris in July, ushered in a period of deep political uncertainty in France.
author: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden

header: In E.U. Elections, the Center Holds, but the Far Right Still Wreaks Havoc
desc: Voters in the European Union delivered strong gains to anti-immigrant, nationalist parties, challenging leaders in Germany and France, and unsettling the political establishment.
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Iran Names Six Candidates for President, Including Parliament Speaker
desc: The June 28 election to succeed President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month, comes as the country faces acute domestic and international challenges.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In Calling Elections in France, Macron Makes a Huge Gamble
desc: The president has challenged voters to test the sincerity of their support for the far right in European elections. Were the French letting off steam, or did they really mean it?
author: Roger Cohen

header: Every Dollar Counts. To Pay for the War, Ukraine Embraces Privatization
desc: The government hopes to sell off a range of companies to fund the military and stabilize the economy as the grueling conflict with Russia drains its coffers.
author: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Most of a Russian Missile and Drone Barrage
desc: Drawing on replenished supplies, Ukraine used mostly Western-provided air defense systems to deter the overnight assault.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Warships Enter Havana Harbor as Part of Planned Exercises
desc: Experts called the naval exercises routine but also a show of strength as Washington maintains military support for Ukraine in its war against Russia.
author: Eve Sampson

header: Weakened Leaders of the West Gather in Italy to Discuss an Unruly World
desc: The Group of 7 gathers major industrialized countries, but its leaders are politically weak and Ukraine and Gaza remain unsolved.
author: Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger

header: In Wake of Election Defeat, Germany’s Weakened Leader Will Slog On
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his governing coalition emerged battered from the vote for the European Parliament. But a snap election seems unlikely.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze and Sarah Maslin Nir

header: Christophe Deloire, Who Fought for Threatened Journalists, Dies at 53
desc: As the leader and spokesman for Reporters Without Borders, he rescued some, sought refuge for others and lobbied for pluralism in the press.
author: Sam Roberts

header: Pope Francis Is Accused of Using a Homophobic Slur Again
desc: Two prominent Italian news agencies said the pontiff used the term on Tuesday during a meeting with priests, after he was accused of uttering the same word last month while speaking with Italian bishops.
author: Emma Bubola

header: In China’s Backyard, America Has Become a Humbler Superpower
desc: The United States no longer towers over the Asia-Pacific, dictating terms to its allies. Instead, it’s offering to be a teammate and share responsibilities.
author: Damien Cave

header: Saudi Arabia’s Next Billion-Dollar Sports Play: A Boxing Takeover
desc: A proposal awaiting financing would attempt to bring together dozens of the world’s best boxers in a single, Saudi-run pro league.
author: Tariq Panja

header: Wednesday Briefing: Hunter Biden Found Guilty on Gun Charges
desc: Also, pressure on Israel and Hamas to reach a deal.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Welcomes Pledges of More Military Aid With Cautious Optimism
desc: Kyiv signed security pacts with several Western allies this week. Whether they will fundamentally change the course of the war, or endure beyond looming elections elsewhere, is unclear.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Japan Commits $4.5 Billion for Ukraine, Zelensky Says
desc: The agreement underscores Japan’s efforts to strengthen its security and diplomatic ties with Europe after the full-scale conflict began in 2022.
author: Tim Balk

header: Ukraine Stalled Russia Near the Border. This Town Has Paid the Price.
desc: Faced with an assault from the northeast, Ukrainian forces made their stand in Vovchansk. The front line is still there, but little else is.
author: Finbarr O’Reilly and Maria Varenikova

header: Putin Makes Cease-Fire Offer With Sweeping Demands on Ukraine’s Territory
desc: Ukraine denounced the offer, saying that Mr. Putin was “afraid of real peace.” The Russian leader made the remarks one day before a peace summit organized by Kyiv.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Paul Sonne

header: G7 Leaders Agree on $50 Billion Loan to Ukraine From Frozen Russian Assets
desc: The agreement comes as Ukraine has been forced to sell some state assets and as the momentum in the war has shifted in favor of Russia.
author: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

header: G7 Agrees to $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets. How Will It Work?
desc: The United States and others plan to give the sum to Kyiv, with the interest from Moscow’s assets frozen in the West used to repay it. But many of the details about the arrangement are unclear.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: A U.S. pact aims to help Ukraine’s military into the future, officials say.
desc: The deal will outline a long-term effort to train and equip Ukraine’s forces, promising to provide more modern weapons and help the Ukrainians build their own self-sustaining military industry that is capable of producing its own arms, U.S. officials said.
author: David E. Sanger

header: Will Biden’s Help for Ukraine Come Fast Enough and Last Long Enough?
desc: The president signed a 10-year security pact with Ukraine and promised, with E.U. help, a $50 billion loan. But will the money arrive in time to turn the tide, and will the deal outlast the election in November?
author: David E. Sanger

header: At a meeting of a Ukraine defense alliance, Austin pledges to keep sending military aid.
desc: NA
author: John Ismay

header: G7 Leaders, Expanding the Circle, Shift Focus to Migration and the South
desc: Leaders from India, Brazil, the Middle East and Africa joined discussions in a nod to the changing global balance of power.
author: Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger

header: Inside the Chechen Units Helping to Fight Russia’s War
desc: After hundreds of years of enmity with Russia, Chechens are deploying to Ukraine to fight Moscow’s war.
author: Nanna Heitmann and Neil MacFarquhar

header: The Sticking Points That Kept Russia and Ukraine Apart
desc: Documents from 2022 shed new light on what prevented Ukraine and Russia from ending the war — and what would complicate a future negotiation.
author: Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine-Russia Peace Is as Elusive as Ever. But in 2022 They Were Talking.
desc: Representatives from the warring nations held peace talks in the early weeks of the Russian invasion. They fizzled. Documents from those talks show why any new ones will face major obstacles.
author: Anton Troianovski, Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz

header: More Than 80 Nations Back Talks to Ease Path to Peace in Ukraine
desc: Meeting in Switzerland, world leaders backed a joint statement urging more diplomacy, but were divided on how to engage Russia.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine Peace Talks Held in Switzerland, Though Russia Isn’t Invited
desc: Kyiv hopes to garner nations’ support for three points in its peace proposal, but it’s a hard sell, with China and Brazil declining to send high-level delegations.
author: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Western Anxiety Makes for an Unexpectedly Smooth G7 Summit
desc: Political weakness, intractable wars in Ukraine and in the Middle East, and challenges from Russia and China combined to create solidarity behind American leadership.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Russian Forces Quash Prison Mutiny Led by Terrorism Suspects, State Media Reports
desc: The assailants had taken two guards hostage and were killed, the prison service said.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: It’s Not Just Russia: China Joins the G7’s List of Adversaries
desc: While not invited to the Group of 7 meeting, China was still a major presence, with the summit’s final communiqué referencing the country 28 times, almost always as a malign force.
author: David E. Sanger

header: America’s Voice in Taiwan Has Some Parting Advice About China
desc: Worries about Chinese belligerence rose during Sandra Oudkirk’s three years in Taipei. As she leaves, she is seeking to assure Taiwan of continued U.S. support.
author: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

header: The Greens Are Dead. Long Live the Greens!
desc: Europe’s climate change-minded parties performed poorly in the European Union elections. Is the once ambitious European green movement over, or could its electoral crash launch a rebirth?
author: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: A Battlefield Break to Cheer Ukraine’s Soccer Team in Euro 2024
