header: The Russian military appears to be packing up equipment in Syria, satellite imagery shows.
desc: Such a move highlights the uncertainty of Moscow’s foothold in Syria, which has served as an important strategic foothold in the Middle East.
author: Devon Lum, Arijeta Lajka and Eve Sampson

header: Chinese-Flagged Ship Suspected of Cutting Cables Remains Halted Weeks Later
desc: After fiber-optic cables under the Baltic Sea were cut last month, European officials hurried to stop the Yi Peng 3. It’s still at anchor there, with no update on three nations’ investigation.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Henrik Pryser Libell

header: Rights Groups See a Chance to Seek Justice for Syrian Regime’s Victims
desc: It seems unlikely that deposed President Bashar al-Assad, who fled to Russia, will be forced to stand trial. That is not deterring activists who have worked for years to document his government’s crimes.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Cajole, Plead and Flatter: Ukraine Makes Its Case to Trump
desc: Using diplomacy, flattery and the occasional shot in the dark, Ukraine is doing everything it can to win over President-elect Donald J. Trump to its side.
author: Constant Méheut, Kim Barker and Maria Varenikova

header: As Ambassador, Rahm Emanuel Says His Impatience Nudged Japan Forward
desc: In a society used to quiet consensus-building, Tokyo has made bold changes to its defense policy. “Did I contribute to that?” Mr. Emanuel asked. “Uh, yeah.”
author: Motoko Rich

header: Ukraine Says It Killed General Who Led Russia’s Nuclear Defense Force
desc: A Ukrainian official said Kyiv was responsible for the assassination in Moscow of Gen. Igor Kirillov, the chief of Russia’s radioactive, chemical and biological defense forces.
author: Anton Troianovski and Constant Méheut

header: German Government Collapses at a Perilous Time for Europe
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz lost a confidence vote, deepening the political turbulence in one of the continent’s most powerful economies.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley

header: Who Was Igor Kirillov, the Russian General Assassinated in Moscow?
desc: The general had faced sanctions for using chemical weapons in Ukraine.
author: The New York Times

header: U.S. Cites ‘Indications’ North Korean Soldiers Died Fighting for Russia
desc: The Pentagon spokesman said the North Koreans had entered combat last week in the Russian region of Kursk, but he did not specify the number of casualties.
author: Kim Barker

header: Putin Stays Silent on Syria, With Russia’s Future There in Question
desc: In an hourlong televised meeting with his top military brass, Vladimir Putin left Syria unmentioned and made it clear that winning in Ukraine was his top priority.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Video Captures Moment When Blast Killed Russian General
desc: A video clip that recorded the assassination of Igor Kirillov, a high-ranking general, gives a few clues about the power and the placement of the explosive device.
author: Aric Toler and Eve Sampson

header: Bomb Kills Russian Military General in Moscow
desc: Gen. Igor Kirillov was responsible for Russia’s radioactive, chemical and biological defense forces. A Ukrainian official said Kyiv was behind his assassination.
author: Nader Ibrahim

header: What North Korea Gains From Its Alliance With Russia — and What It Risks
desc: Sending troops to fight against Ukraine has gotten North Korea much-needed cash and diplomatic leverage. But there may be hidden costs, too.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: <U+200B>Impeachment in South Korea Has Cost Washington a Staunch Ally
desc: President Yoon Suk Yeol shifted his country closer to Washington and stood up to Beijing. But that foreign policy could be recalibrated in the future.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: Behind Germany’s Political Turmoil, a Stagnating Economy
desc: One of Europe’s powerhouses is losing its competitive edge, and the political class can’t agree on why — or what to do about it.
author: Jim Tankersley

header: Zelensky Meets With European Leaders to Discuss Ukraine’s Future
desc: As Donald J. Trump prepares to take office in the United States, President Volodymyr Zelensky attended a meeting hosted by the NATO chief to plot the path forward in the war with Russia.
author: Jenny Gross and Steven Erlanger

header: Zelensky Raises Prospect of European Peacekeepers in Ukraine
desc: But many European leaders say that with no sign that Russia is interested in peace, it is too early to discuss the presence of peacekeeping forces.
author: Jenny Gross and Constant Méheut

header: Killing of Russian General Sends a Message, but Doesn’t Change the War
desc: Ukraine’s forces are steadily losing ground on the battlefield. The assassination of a top general in Moscow won’t improve their war effort, analysts and Western officials say.
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Europe Has a Leadership Vacuum. How Will It Handle Trump?
desc: With Germany and France both in political turmoil, the new administration of Donald J. Trump will begin at a time of instability for the continent.
author: Mark Landler and Jim Tankersley

header: Russia Detains a Man It Says Killed a General on Ukraine’s Orders
desc: The Russian prosecutor’s office said the suspect, a 29-year-old citizen of Uzbekistan, confessed to planting the bomb on the orders of Ukrainian agents.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: The Year in Pictures 2024: Far From Ordinary
desc: Photographers captured historic moments of war, grief and wonder that defined the year.
author: NA

header: Putin Glosses Over Russian Setbacks, Including Syria
desc: The Russian president, in a marathon annual news conference, said that he had not yet met with Bashar al-Assad, the ousted Syrian leader who fled to Moscow, but that he planned to.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Its Syrian Bases in Doubt, Russia Sends Cargo Flights to Libya
desc: A Libyan officer said the stepped-up flights from Russia and Syria delivered military gear.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: China’s Nuclear Buildup Is on Track Despite Graft Scandals, Pentagon Says
desc: Corruption investigations may have shaken Beijing’s confidence in top commanders, but China’s military expansion hasn’t slowed, a report found.
author: Chris Buckley and John Ismay

header: Ukrainians Mourn the Loss of a Young Journalist and Her Stories
desc: Viktoria Roshchyna died in September in Russian custody. The reporter had been well-known for her stories about life in parts of occupied Ukraine.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: How Will Ukraine Keep the Lights on This Winter?
desc: The Ukrainian energy network has been so battered by Russian attacks that officials are seeking out new options to prevent a crisis, like renting floating power plants and scavenging scrapped ones from the region.
author: Constant Méheut

header: At 23, Surviving Scandal to Take a Green Seat in the E.U. Parliament
desc: Lena Schilling, the youngest lawmaker in Brussels, faced a harsh questioning of her character and credibility before winning a chance to fight against climate change in the halls of power.
author: Valeriya Safronova

header: A Cultural Casualty of the War in Ukraine: ‘The Nutcracker’
desc: Lithuania’s national opera house had stopped showing Tchaikovsky’s 1892 masterpiece in solidarity with Ukraine over the war with Russia. Then a new minister expressed fondness for the Russian composer, igniting a furor.
author: Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross

header: Why Are North Korean Troops in Ukraine Taking Heavy Casualties?
desc: The North Korean army is one of the world’s largest.<U+200B> As it joins Russia’s war against Ukraine, its soldiers are paying a price for Kim Jong-un’s geopolitical maneuvers.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: Slovak Leader Visits Putin, Breaking With E.U.’s Policy of Isolation
desc: Prime Minister Robert Fico’s surprise visit to Moscow on Sunday, reportedly to discuss natural gas and Ukraine, was a blow to European unity against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: A Canceled Vote in Romania Hands Russia a Propaganda Coup
desc: Many in the West have applauded the annulling of the first round of the presidential election, won by a Moscow-friendly candidate, but even his critics say it raises troubling questions about Romanian democracy.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: As Budget Impasse Grinds On, Macron Appoints a New Cabinet
desc: President Emmanuel Macron of France named the choices less than three weeks after the previous government collapsed. He had already picked François Bayrou as prime minister.
author: Richard Fausset and Aurelien Breeden

header: Russia Unleashes Another Wave of Attacks on Ukraine
desc: Moscow again struck Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, part of an effort to wear down the country. “In the trenches, there are no holidays,” one man said.
author: Marc Santora and Liubov Sholudko

header: Pope Francis’ Christmas Message Calls for Peace Amid War
desc: Pope Francis called for cease-fires for the conflicts in Ukraine and in the Middle East during his Christmas message in St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City.
author: The Associated Press and Reuters

header: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 15 Years for Espionage
desc: Eugene Spector was already serving a sentence for a bribery conviction when he was charged with spying, for which a court ordered him to serve an additional 13 years.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Pope Calls for Peace on Christmas as Church Begins Jubilee Year Celebrations
desc: Pope Francis’ Christmas message was a plea for reconciliation, peace and care for others.
author: Elisabetta Povoledo

header: Is a Putin Ally in Eastern Europe Making a Cautious Overture to the West?
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus keeps arresting political opponents, but analysts wonder if a string of unusual pardons is a bid to get sanctions eased.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Andrew Higgins

header: Around the World, Lights and Color Mark the Season
desc: Around the world, people found ways to show their holiday spirit.
author: Keith Bedford and Sara Ruberg

header: Released From a Russian Prison, This Activist Got Right to Work
desc: Vladimir Kara-Murza, a vehement critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, didn’t want to be part of a prisoner exchange. But he says more exchanges are needed.
author: Valerie Hopkins

header: He Inherited a Seat in Britain’s House of Lords. How Will It Feel to Lose It?
desc: The U.K. government has pledged to remove hereditary peers from Parliament in 2025. For Lord Cromwell and 87 others, it is a wistful departure.
author: Mark Landler

header: A Visual Guide to the Tangled Alliances and Rivalries in Syria
desc: After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, old alliances have crumbled, and global powers are figuring out their relationships with Syria’s new de facto leaders.
author: Josh Holder, Vivian Yee and Samuel Granados

header: Ukraine Slows Firing of Missiles Into Russia as Trump Prepares to Take Office
desc: The long-range missiles provided by the United States and Britain were used to strike inside Russian territory, despite concerns that their use would escalate the conflict. Kyiv’s stockpiles are running out.
author: Kim Barker, Lara Jakes, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes

header: What We Know About the Ship Finland Seized Over Fears of Sabotage
desc: Finland seized an oil tanker that authorities believe might have deliberately cut vital undersea cables. Finnish authorities believe the tanker may be linked to Russia.
author: Johanna Lemola and Lynsey Chutel

header: Finland Says Vessel Suspected of Cutting Cable May Be Part of Russia’s ‘Shadow Fleet’
desc: Finland seized an oil tanker after the latest in a series of disruptions to undersea infrastructure.
author: Johanna Lemola and Lynsey Chutel

header: What We Know About the Plane Crash in Kazakhstan
desc: The Embraer 190 was traveling to Grozny, Russia, but crashed near Aktau, Kazakhstan, killing 38 people onboard. Investigators are focusing on Russian air defense as the likely cause.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Plane Crash Investigators Focus on Russian Air Defenses as Possible Cause
desc: Russian aviation authorities said the Azerbaijan Airlines plane had hit a flock of birds. But some experts cast doubt on that account, pointing to footage showing apparent holes in the fuselage.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The Children Who Left Gaza
desc: Sixteen young people evacuated from Gaza for treatment of dire injuries. Months later, they face new lives in an unfamiliar country.
author: Laura Boushnak and Alan Yuhas

header: The War Killed Her Dreams. To Survive, She Treated Its Fighters.
desc: Trapped in Sudan’s brutal civil war, a young woman chose to work in a clinic on the front line, treating civilians and combatants. She had to navigate suspicion from both sides.
author: Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett

header: In Bomb-Scarred Cities, Risking Life and Limb to Get Civilians to Safety
desc: The danger and hardship gets worse by the day for civilians in eastern Ukraine. Still, they resist leaving the places that have become their homes.
author: Tyler Hicks and Gaëlle Girbes

header: Has Russia’s Shadow Fleet, Built to Evade Sanctions, Added Sabotage to Its List?
desc: Russia has assembled a fleet of hundreds of vessels to covertly ship its oil. With so many ships at sea, the idea of using some to cause havoc may be proving irresistible to the Kremlin.
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Putin Apologizes but Stops Short of Taking Responsibility for Kazakhstan Crash
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the Azerbaijani leader, Ilham Aliyev, in a phone call, “that the tragic incident took place in Russian airspace.”
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Azerbaijan Blames Russia for Plane Crash and Rebukes Kremlin
desc: The leader of Azerbaijan criticized the Russian response to the crash of a passenger jet that Azerbaijani officials said had most likely been hit by Russian air defenses.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: A Year Both Brutal and Bright: 13 Favorite Dispatches From 2024
desc: In a year marked by wars, extreme weather and general wickedness, many dispatches defaulted to a distinctly dark tone. But as our correspondents traversed the globe, they found pockets of light, too.
author: Bryant Rousseau

header: Russia and Ukraine Swap More Than 300 Prisoners Ahead of U.S. Transition
desc: Exchanges have taken place before, but this deal, involving big numbers on both sides, comes as Trump prepares to take over in Washington, potentially endangering American aid to Kyiv.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: On E-Scooters and ATVs, Russian Forces Swarm Ukrainian Positions in the East
desc: Stepped up attacks by Russia are heightening longstanding concerns over how Ukraine manages its military and countering assumptions that Moscow’s offensive would slow, soldiers and military analysts say.
author: Marc Santora

header: Putin Declares ‘Everything Will Be Fine’ Despite Russia’s Growing Challenges
desc: Speaking on the 25th anniversary of his rule, President Vladimir V. Putin delivered an upbeat and vague New Year’s Eve message that did not address casualties in Ukraine or rising inflation at home.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Where Is Russia Finding New Soldiers? Wherever It Can.
desc: From murder suspects to immigrants to a former Olympic gold medalist, Russia pressures those it thinks should fight in Ukraine.
author: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: New Year’s 2025: Celebrations Around the World
desc: See how people across the globe celebrated.
author: The New York Times

header: Ukraine Halts the Flow of Natural Gas From Russia to Europe
desc: A transnational pipeline was shut down on Wednesday after Kyiv refused to renew a prewar agreement that allowed for the transit of Russian gas through its territory.
author: Marc Santora, Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross

header: Why Did Ukraine Halt the Flow of Russia’s Natural Gas to Europe?
desc: And why didn’t it cut off Russia’s natural gas earlier?
author: Marc Santora, Andrew Higgins and Stanley Reed

header: Zelensky Expresses Hope for 2025, but Russia Presses On With Attacks
desc: In his New Year’s address, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged continued U.S. support.
author: Marc Santora

header: Drones, Exploding Parcels and Sabotage: How Hybrid Tactics Target the West
desc: Russia and other hostile states have become increasingly brazen in adopting “gray zone” attacks against Europe and the United States, leaving defense officials with a dilemma: How to respond?
author: Lara Jakes

header: Italy’s Prime Minister Visits Trump at Mar-a-Lago
desc: Giorgia Meloni, the Italian prime minister, joins just a handful of other world leaders who have been to the president-elect’s Florida estate since his victory.
author: Emma Bubola

header: Russia Claims Control of Key Town as Ukraine Renews Push in Kursk
desc: Ukraine has largely been driven out of Kurakhove, a battered but strategic town in the Donbas, Russia said. Kyiv’s forces were pressing a renewed offensive in southern Russia.
author: Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Launches New Attack in Kursk Region of Western Russia
desc: Ukrainian forces’ assault was in the Russian region where they made a surprise incursion last summer.
author: Marc Santora

header: A Gas Cutoff Sends Shivers Through a Russian-Backed Breakaway Region
desc: A renegade part of Moldova once boasted it would become a Russian-speaking Switzerland. Now without gas, its leader assured residents, “We will not allow a societal collapse.”
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Azerbaijani Anger Over Plane Crash Grows, in Deepening Schism With Russia
desc: In the crash’s aftermath, Azerbaijan has unleashed rare and stinging criticism of Russia, with the country’s president saying Moscow’s response has caused “surprise, regret and rightful indignation.”
author: Anton Troianovski

header: How Austria Could Get Its First Far-Right Chancellor Since World War II
desc: The leader of the anti-immigration, pro-Russia Freedom Party has been given the chance to try to form a government after months of coalition talks among mainstream parties collapsed.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze

header: In South Korea, Blinken Affirms Alliance Amid Challenges Facing Democracies
desc: The U.S. secretary of state aimed to show that his country stood by South Korea as it grapples with a political crisis, and as Donald J. Trump returns to power.
author: Edward Wong and Choe Sang-Hun

header: For Many Returning Russian Veterans, a Long Road of Recovery Awaits
desc: A large number of soldiers return as amputees, and many suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Once home, they face stigma and a grueling course of rehabilitation.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Russian Strike Kills 13 in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine
desc: The attack, which also wounded dozens of people, came hours after Ukraine’s military attacked an oil depot deep inside Russia.
author: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Blinken and Top French Diplomat Criticize Trump’s Talk of Taking Greenland
desc: In Paris, the two officials acknowledged potential strains on alliances with the return of Donald J. Trump to power, but said their countries would try to maintain strong ties.
author: Edward Wong and Richard Fausset

header: Short of Heat and Power, a Breakaway Region Struggles Without Russian Gas
desc: An energy crisis in Transnistria, a pro-Russian territory between Moldova and Ukraine, erupted on Jan. 1 when Moscow stopped supplying natural gas through a pipeline running across Ukraine.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: A Far-Right Government in Austria Would Be a Jolt, but Not Unexpected
desc: The Freedom Party and its leader, Herbert Kickl, have steadily built support by demonizing immigrants, while entering Austria’s political mainstream.
author: Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Kremlin Confirms Readiness for Putin to Meet Trump
desc: The president-elect had said Russia’s leader wanted to meet him to discuss the war in Ukraine. The Kremlin said it welcomed such dialogue, but a meeting could occur only after Mr. Trump took office.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Putin Gets a Snub in the Vast Wine Cellars of a Former Soviet Republic
desc: The Russian president celebrated his 50th birthday at a winery in Moldova. After the invasion of Ukraine, it moved the bottles he was given away from public view.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Elon Musk Is Trying to Break Germany’s Quarantine on the Far-Right AfD
desc: Political leaders have shunned the Alternative for Germany. But on his social media platform X, Mr. Musk is pitching the party as mainstream.
author: Jim Tankersley

header: Egypt’s Economy Is Damaged. It Sees a Scapegoat, and a Potential Fix, in Refugees.
desc: Palestinians, Sudanese and Syrians fleeing war have found a home in the country. But Cairo says newcomers are straining resources and is seeking financial help from the West.
author: Vivian Yee

header: The Painting, the Photograph and the War for Ukraine’s Culture
desc: An image depicting a famous 19th-century painting of Cossacks, with current Ukrainian soldiers standing in for the warriors, has struck a chord as Kyiv battles to assert its identity.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine Says It Captured 2 North Korean Soldiers Fighting for Russia
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the soldiers were captured in the western Kursk region, where Ukraine has been fighting to hold on to territory it seized last summer.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Battles Rage Inside Russia, With Waves of Tanks, Drones and North Koreans
desc: Ukrainian soldiers are describing fierce clashes as Russian forces try to retake territory in the Kursk region that could be key in eventual cease-fire talks.
author: Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Ukraine Launches ‘Massive’ Drone Attacks Inside Russia, Officials Say
desc: The barrage appeared to be one of the largest recent assaults in Ukraine’s campaign to damage Russia’s war machine on its home territory.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Troops Captured by Ukraine Provide Rare Glimpse Into North Korea’s Military
desc: Ukraine’s president released a video of the two soldiers being interrogated, revealing they knew little about the war they were sent to fight in.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: For These Teenagers in Ukraine, Hope Arrived at the Stage Door
desc: The students in a summer acting course performed a play set in America, called, “It’s okay!” And it gave them hope that their lives would be OK, too.
author: Kim Barker and Dzvinka Pinchuk

header: A New Age of American Interference in Europe
desc: Elon Musk and MAGA are already disrupting the status quo, and Europe seems ill-prepared.
author: Katrin Bennhold

header: Missile Attack Prompts Emergency Power Cuts in Ukraine
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said air defenses had shot down at least 30 missiles from a “massive” barrage that had targeted gas and energy facilities.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: U.K. Leader Vows Long-Term Partnership With Ukraine on Kyiv Visit
desc: Prime Minister Keir Starmer signaled continued solidarity, with further U.S. support in question under a second Trump administration.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Inside Ukraine’s Last Stand at a Vital Coal Mine
desc: The mine, near the frontline city of Pokrovsk, produced coking coal crucial for Ukraine’s steel industry. It kept running until the very last moment, when Russian forces finally reached its gates.
author: Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Azerbaijan’s Leader, Emboldened, Picks a Rare Fight With Putin
desc: Russia’s president is said to have blamed birds or a Ukrainian drone for a Dec. 25 crash of an Azerbaijani plane. Azerbaijan says Russian air defenses were at fault.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Poland’s Leader Suggests Russian Hand in Plot to Attack Western Cargo Planes
desc: “I can only confirm that Russia planned acts of air terror, not just against Poland but against airlines across the globe,” said Poland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk.
author: Michael Schwirtz

header: Russia Attacks Kyiv With Ballistic Missiles, Ukraine Says
desc: At least three people were killed in the assault on the capital, and at least one died and 11 were wounded in a separate strike in the southern city of Zaporizhzhia.
author: Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russia and Iran Sign Cooperation Treaty in the Kremlin
desc: The agreement is focused more on trade than military issues, but it will bring two countries with a shared desire to challenge the West closer together.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Farnaz Fassihi

header: The ‘Minister of Everything’ for Justin Trudeau Enters Race to Replace Him
desc: Chrystia Freeland, the former deputy prime minister, sought to distance herself from Mr. Trudeau in a public letter criticizing him for “costly political gimmicks.”
author: Vjosa Isai

header: 3 Lawyers for Navalny Sentenced for Passing Along His Correspondence
desc: A Russian court said the lawyers for Aleksei Navalny, the country’s top opposition figure before his death in a penal colony last year, were guilty of involvement in an extremist group.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: How the Oct. 7 Attacks Transformed the Middle East
desc: With an Israel-Hamas cease-fire set to begin, the shock waves from their war have reshaped the region in unexpected ways.
author: Erika Solomon

header: Ukraine Braces for Trump’s Return, Eager for Peace, but Wary of the Terms
desc: Soldiers and civilians alike say that after so much loss, the new U.S. president must push for a just settlement, not peace at any cost.
author: Marc Santora

header: Fighting Alongside Russia, North Koreans Wage Their Own War
desc: Ukrainian forces described a different kind of enemy, fighting with unfamiliar tactics and little option to retreat.
author: Marc Santora and Helene Cooper

header: Facing Setbacks and Desertions at the Front, Ukraine Detains Commanders
desc: Two generals and a colonel blamed for the loss of territory in eastern Ukraine to Russian forces last year have been held, the country’s security service said.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: As Trump Takes Office, Zelensky Urges Europe to Stand Firm Against Russia
desc: Speaking a day after Trump’s inauguration, Ukraine’s president told world leaders at Davos that Europe needs to remain united and “learn how to take care of itself.”
author: Marc Santora

header: Britain Says Russian Spy Ship Returned to U.K. Waters in Sign of Kremlin Threat
desc: The British defense secretary told Parliament that the Yantar, which he described as a Russian spy ship, had come near Britain’s coast for the second time in a few months.
author: Stephen Castle and Michael Schwirtz

header: Europe Braces for a New Trump Era, Uncertain About What It Means
desc: President Trump appears willing to shake up almost every policy area, and a behind-the-scenes E.U. task force has been trying to prepare. But is Europe ready?
author: Jeanna Smialek

header: Houthis Free the Crew of a Cargo Ship They Hijacked 14 Months Ago
desc: The Iranian-backed rebel group in Yemen had earlier said they would scale back attacks given the cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Trump’s Hint at Deal Making Gives China a Little Breathing Room
desc: Whether it is over TikTok, fentanyl or trade, Beijing might welcome a compromise to buy time to address its ailing economy and bolster its position globally.
author: David Pierson

header: Clinton Bailey, Who Documented a Vanishing Bedouin Culture, Dies at 88
desc: Armed with a camera and tape recorder, he spent decades preserving the ancient traditions of nomadic Middle Eastern tribes.
author: Isabel Kershner

header: Did Ukraine Kill Its Own by Downing a Russian Plane? A Year Later, It Hasn’t Said.
desc: Russia says Ukraine shot down a military transport carrying 65 captured Ukrainians. Ukraine has not confirmed its role, identified the bodies it received, or said how it happened.
author: Cassandra Vinograd and Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine Is Losing Fewer Soldiers Than Russia — but It’s Still Losing the War
desc: Russia has lost about twice as many men to death and serious injury as Ukraine. But the trends favor the Kremlin.
author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut

header: With Support Dwindling and Trump in Power, Zelensky Could Face Tough Re-election
desc: The high popularity that the Ukrainian president had in the early days of the Russian invasion, with an approval rating of about 90 percent, has dipped badly.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Kenneth P. Vogel

header: Ukraine Sends Volley of Drones at Russia, Hitting Oil Refinery
desc: Videos showed fireballs over a facility in Ryazan, 110 miles southeast of Moscow. Kyiv is seeking to disrupt Russian military logistics and put pressure on the country’s economy by striking its oil industry.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Trump Is Leading a Global Surge to the Right
desc: But not all of the leading conservative populist parties in the world are the same — in rhetoric or on policy.
author: Jim Tankersley, Emma Bubola, Andrew Higgins and Aurelien Breeden

header: Trump Hints at New Talks With Kim Jong-un. It Might Be Harder This Time.
desc: North Korea’s leader has grown more assertive since their last efforts at diplomacy ended in failure — and now has Russia at his side.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: A Storm, a Spill and a Disaster for the Black Sea’s Beaches
desc: Vast stretches of Russian coast have been tarred by heavy fuel oil from two freighters that foundered in a storm.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Belarus’s Strong-Arm Leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko, Cruises to Re-election
desc: Europe’s longest-serving leader won re-election in a contest widely believe to have been rigged. The result cements the power of a leader whose country is considered Russia’s staunchest ally.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: His Opponents Sidelined, Lukashenko Is Set for a 7th Term in Belarus
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, a close ally of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has been making signs of reaching out to the West. He is all but certain to win an election on Sunday.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Europe Is Pouring Money Into Defense. Is It Enough?
desc: With a full-blown land war in Ukraine and an isolationist American president back in the White House, European leaders have come to a stark conclusion: They must spend more on their militaries.
author: Josh Holder

header: Trump Alarms Denmark in an Icy Exchange Over Greenland
desc: President Trump told Denmark’s leader he wanted to take over Greenland, European officials say. Denmark has asked its E.U. allies not to inflame the situation until Mr. Trump’s intentions are clearer.
author: Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek

header: Here’s a Closer Look at the 4 Released Hostages
desc: The young women freed on Saturday were working as “spotters” for Israel’s army when they were abducted in the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, 2023.
author: Natan Odenheimer, Ephrat Livni, Talya Minsberg, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Lynsey Chutel

header: As Hamas Exchanges Gaza Hostages, It Puts on a Show of Force
desc: The handover of four female Israeli soldiers by Hamas on Saturday came as Israel released 200 prisoners. But a dispute arose over the hostage release timetable.
author: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller

header: Israel Welcomes the Return of the Women Who Warned of a Raid From Gaza
desc: Young female “spotters” for Israel’s army reported suspicious activity across the border. When Hamas attacked, 15 were killed and seven abducted. Four came home on Saturday.
author: Isabel Kershner

header: Many Ukrainian Aid Groups Stop Work After Trump’s Halt on Foreign Assistance
desc: The Trump administration’s orders have sent a chill through humanitarian organizations in Ukraine, which depend heavily on such assistance.
author: Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut

header: Standoff at Ukrainian Procurement Agency Threatens to Disrupt Weapons Supply
desc: Ukraine’s defense minister fired the head of a state agency that acquired over $7 billion in armaments last year, citing “unsatisfactory” results. But, the official vowed to remain.
author: Constant Méheut

header: As Trump and Putin Circle Each Other, an Agenda Beyond Ukraine Emerges
desc: President Trump jabs at the Russian leader with threats; Vladimir Putin responds with flattery. But there are notable signals in their jousting, including a revived discussion about nuclear arms control.
author: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

header: Chastened by Past Wars, Kremlin Tries to Elevate Its Veterans
desc: Russians who fought in Chechnya and Afghanistan came home to silence and stigma. There’s a very public push to make things different this time.
author: Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina

header: At Auschwitz, a Solemn Ceremony at a Time of Rising Nationalism
desc: World leaders and a dwindling group of survivors joined in a ceremony to mark the 80th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp by the Red Army.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Sweden Suspects ‘Gross Sabotage’ After Damage to Cable Under Baltic Sea
desc: The Nordic country has opened an investigation into the damage, just weeks after NATO stepped up its military presence in the area following a series of similar incidents.
author: Christina Anderson and Amelia Nierenberg

header: Confronted by Trump, Denmark Looks to Its European Neighbors for Support
desc: The prime minister does a European tour while announcing more spending on security around the island, following President Trump’s stated desire to have Greenland, a semiautonomous Danish territory, as part of the U.S.
author: Steven Erlanger and Lynsey Chutel

header: Gaza and Lebanon Truces Are Fragile, but All Sides May Keep Them Going
desc: Bloodshed over the weekend highlighted the brittleness of the cease-fires in both places. Still, Israel, Hamas and Hezbollah each have reasons to postpone a new escalation, at least for a few weeks.
author: Patrick Kingsley

header: Serbian Leader, Trying to Quell Protests, Jettisons a Key Ally
desc: Demonstrations around Serbia pose a challenge to the decade-long hold on power by President Aleksandar Vucic, who spurred his prime minister to step down.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Germany’s Likely Leader Flirts With a Taboo: Working With the Far Right
desc: Responding to the killing of a child, the poll-leading Christian Democrats are pushing to overhaul migration laws — possibly with votes from the Alternative for Germany.
author: Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Russia Seizes Another Ukrainian Town in Push to Take All of Donetsk
desc: Moscow’s troops used the same pincer tactic on Velyka Novosilka that has enabled their recent capture of town after town in eastern Ukraine.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Kyiv Mayor Feuds With Zelensky in Schism Over Martial Law
desc: The mayor, Vitali Klitschko, who has had a tense relationship with President Volodymyr Zelensky, accused him of trying to usurp the powers of elected officials in the capital.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: North Korean Troops No Longer Seen on Front Lines Fighting Ukraine
desc: North Korea sent its best troops to aid Russia in its war against Ukraine. But after months of suffering severe losses, they have been taken off the front line.
author: Michael Schwirtz and Julian E. Barnes

header: How Does DeepSeek’s A.I. Chatbot Navigate China’s Censors? Awkwardly.
desc: Asked about sensitive topics, the bot would begin to answer, then stop and delete its own work. It refused to answer questions like: “Who is Xi Jinping?”
author: Vivian Wang

header: A U.K. Teen Became Fixated on Extreme Violence. But Was It Terrorism?
desc: Axel Rudakubana, who killed three girls in a stabbing spree at a dance class, was obsessed with violence but had no known ideology. His case has led to calls for a rethink of counterterror strategy.
author: Lizzie Dearden

header: How the World Is Reeling From Trump’s Aid Freeze
desc: President Trump’s order to halt most foreign aid has intensified humanitarian crises and raised questions about the United States’ reliability as a global leader.
author: Sui-Lee Wee, Declan Walsh and Farnaz Fassihi

header: Norway Seizes Russian-Crewed Ship Suspected of Cutting an Undersea Cable
desc: The authorities said they believed the vessel may have been involved in damaging the cable, the latest act of apparent sabotage in the Baltic Sea.
author: Henrik Pryser Libell and Lynsey Chutel

header: Kremlin Chokes YouTube Service, but Russians Find Ways Around It
desc: The Kremlin is trying to cripple YouTube in Russia, internet experts say, pushing some people to state-controlled domestic alternatives. But many Russians have found workarounds.
author: Paul Sonne

header: Egypt Fears Syria’s Revolutionary Fervor Could Be Contagious
desc: Since Islamist rebels overthrew the Assad dictatorship in Syria, Egypt, with parallels in its own recent history, has watched warily.
author: Vivian Yee

header: Trump Urges Trading Ukraine’s Critical Minerals for More U.S. Aid
desc: Ukraine has already emphasized that by supporting its war effort, the U.S. could get access to the country’s wealth of critical minerals like lithium and uranium.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine Says at Least 18 Civilians Are Killed in Strikes
desc: At least 14 people were killed in Poltava, Ukrainian officials said, blaming Russia. Four died in Sudzha, a Russian town held by Ukraine, in a strike each country blamed on the other.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Standoff at Ukrainian Agency Disrupts Arms Contracts, Suppliers Say
desc: Ukrainian defense companies say they cannot sign new contracts or receive payment — potentially jeopardizing future supplies to already struggling troops.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Pro-Russia Ukrainian Is Killed in Moscow Blast, Russian Media Says
desc: Armen Sarkisyan, the founder of a separatist battalion fighting in eastern Ukraine, died after an explosion in an apartment complex, according to reports citing the Russian authorities.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: With Trump’s Backing Uncertain, Europe Scrambles to Shore Up Its Own Defenses
desc: European leaders gathered Monday to plot a rough path forward on defense. Wavering support from President Trump is driving the debate.
author: Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger

header: Rescuers Search for Survivors After Missile Strike in Ukraine
desc: Ukrainian officials said at least 14 people were killed in Poltava, Ukraine, after a Russian missile hit a residential building in the city, which is nearly 150 miles from the front lines.
author: Reuters

header: For China, Trump’s Moves Bring Pain, but Also Potential Gains
desc: President Trump’s tariffs hurt China, but his other actions have alienated U.S. allies, giving Beijing an opening to strengthen its global standing.
author: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Sui-Lee Wee

header: 3 Mexican Sectors Most Affected by U.S. Tariffs, and How the Country Could Respond
desc: President Trump’s tariffs will have major effects on Mexico’s auto industry, agriculture and energy, but the country has some means for responding.
author: Simon Romero

header: French Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
desc: The vote clears the way for final approval of France’s 2025 budget, easing concerns about the country’s political turmoil — but not ending them.
author: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter

header: Foreign Strongmen Cheer as Musk Dismantles U.S. Aid Agency
desc: Leaders in Russia, Hungary and El Salvador welcomed the Trump administration’s assault on U.S.A.I.D., which many authoritarians have seen as a threat.
author: Paul Sonne

header: Allies and foes decry Trump’s plan: ‘Out of the question.’
desc: NA
author: Lara Jakes

header: Trump’s Gaza Takeover Would Violate International Law, Experts Say
desc: Forcing Palestinians to leave the enclave would be “a straightforward crime against humanity,” an Oxford professor said. It would be a further violation to take over the territory.
author: Amanda Taub

header: These Are the Major Obstacles to Trump’s Gaza Plan
desc: The politically explosive proposal to move Palestinians out of Gaza and remake it as a U.S. territory included few details. Experts say it ignores the political dynamics of the region and would probably violate international law.
author: Peter Baker, Patrick Kingsley, Amanda Taub, Qasim Nauman, Lara Jakes, Aaron Boxerman, Michael Crowley and Cassandra Vinograd

header: To Keep Aid Coming, Ukraine Appeals to Trump Allies: Conservative Christians
desc: A Ukrainian delegation to the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington will make the case that Russia threatens the religious freedom of Christians who don’t follow the Russian Orthodox Church.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Lara Jakes

header: At a Draft Site in Ukraine, an Anguished Wait for a Chance to Say Goodbye
desc: The Ukrainian authorities are rounding up recruits. Relatives huddle at a center on the edge of Kyiv for a chance to see loved ones before they’re shipped to war.
author: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko

header: An American Teacher Went to Ukraine. Now He’s in a Russian Prison.
desc: Stephen Hubbard was a wanderer. But when he moved to Ukraine, the war brought arrest, torture and imprisonment. He turns 73 this week.
author: Kim Barker and Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: How War Has Wreaked Havoc on Ukraine’s Classrooms
desc: Students have been forced to attend classes underground or online, especially in regions near the front line. Experts say that Ukrainian children are falling behind as a result, academically and socially.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Trump’s Foreign Aid Freeze Has Created Chaos. Here Is What to Know.
desc: Critics say a Trump administration order calls into question the United States’ global standing and reliability.
author: Yonette Joseph, Malika Khurana and Adam Pasick

header: Angela Merkel Is Retired. But She’s Still on the Ballot.
desc: If anything unites the parties in Germany’s election campaign, it is running away from the former chancellor, whose legacy voters have soured on.
author: Jim Tankersley

header: Far-Right Leaders Rally in Spain to ‘Make Europe Great Again’
desc: At a gathering in Madrid, members of Europe’s far-right parties set aside any trepidation they might have about President Trump’s threats and instead focused on a common enemy: the European Union.
author: Emma Bubola

header: Can European ‘Boots on the Ground’ Help Protect Ukraine’s Security?
desc: Deterring Russia from re-invading Ukraine, once this war ends, could require 150,000 troops and American help with air cover, intelligence and missile defense, experts say.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: U.N. Suspends Humanitarian Work in Yemeni Area After Houthis Detain More Staff
desc: The total employees arrested since 2021 has risen to 24, a U.N. spokesman said. The Iran-backed Houthis have held them on murky charges of espionage and foreign intervention.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: Vance, in First Foreign Speech, Tells Europe That U.S. Will Dominate A.I.
desc: Speaking in Paris at an artificial intelligence summit, the vice president gave an America First vision of the technology — with the U.S. dominating the chips, the software and the rules.
author: David E. Sanger

header: Germany’s Would-Be Chancellor Tries to Get Back on Cruise Control
desc: Dogged by protesters, but apparently safe from damage in the polls, Friedrich Merz is putting a failed immigration gambit behind him.
author: Jim Tankersley and Tatiana Firsova

header: The Fiercest Fighting of the Ukraine War May Be in Russia
desc: The Times interviewed Russian soldiers who said they face a brutal fight to dislodge determined Ukrainian forces from a sliver of Russian land. Trapped civilians fear catastrophe.
author: Nanna Heitmann, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina

header: Ukrainian Lawmakers Approve Contentious Purchase of Nuclear Reactors
desc: Opponents of the project say it is costly, will take far too long to strengthen Ukraine’s battered power supply and opens the door to corruption.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Can European ‘Boots on the Ground’ Help Protect Ukraine’s Security?
desc: Deterring Russia from re-invading Ukraine, once this war ends, could require 150,000 troops and American help with air cover, intelligence and missile defense, experts say.
author: Steven Erlanger

header: How Ukraine Pitched Trump on a Deal for Critical Minerals
desc: President Trump says he wants to make a deal for minerals from Ukraine in exchange for aid. That followed a long effort by Ukrainian officials to appeal to Mr. Trump’s transactional nature.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Hegseth Says Return to Ukraine’s Pre-2014 Borders Is ‘Unrealistic’
desc: In his first trip abroad, the new U.S. defense secretary told allies, including NATO officials, that a durable peace could only come “with a realistic assessment of the battlefield.”
author: Steven Erlanger

header: Treasury Secretary Makes Trip to Kyiv
desc: The visit by Scott Bessent was the first by a Trump official since the president’s return to office and came amid uncertainty about the future of U.S. support for Ukraine.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: North Korea Is Caring for Russia’s Wounded Soldiers, Envoy Says
desc: Russia’s ambassador to North Korea said that its Asian ally is also hosting Russian children orphaned by its war against Ukraine, as the two nations deepen ties.
author: Choe Sang-Hun

header: Who Is Marc Fogel? The American Teacher Caught in a Global Power Struggle.
desc: Mr. Fogel, who had lived and taught in many countries, including Russia for nine years, spent 3 1 years in Russian custody for having cannabis for medical use, and is in poor health.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko and Julian E. Barnes

header: U.S. Is Releasing Russian Cybercriminal to Moscow, Officials Say
desc: The release is part of a swap with the Kremlin that freed an American schoolteacher being held in a Russian prison.
author: Anton Troianovski, Maggie Haberman, Julian E. Barnes and Jonathan Swan

header: What International Law Says About Trump’s Proposal to Remove Palestinians From Gaza
desc: Taking over the enclave, forcing Palestinians to leave and preventing them from returning would be clear violations of international law, experts say.
author: Amanda Taub

header: Ukraine Will Not Be Sidelined in Peace Talks With Russia, Trump Says
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and European defense ministers had expressed concern that they might not be present for talks between President Trump and Russia’s leader to end the war.
author: Jeanna Smialek, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Fuller

header: To some Ukrainian soldiers, the prospect of cease-fire talks is ‘too painful.’
desc: NA
author: Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine’s Borders in Maps: Pre-2014 Invasion to Now
desc: Ukraine’s government wants to restore the country’s frontier to where it was before Russia launched its first invasion more than a decade ago. The U.S. defense secretary said that was “unrealistic.”
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Cease-fire talks could upend Ukraine’s domestic politics.
desc: NA
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Can Britain avoid a rift with Trump over Ukraine?
desc: Prime Minister Keir Starmer faces a diplomatic dilemma as he weighs his longstanding support for Ukraine against his determination to cultivate President Trump.
author: Mark Landler

header: Ukrainians Fear Peace May Strand Them Forever From Lost Homes
desc: Bitterness has greeted suggestions that occupied territory will have to be ceded to Russia: “It’s like ripping off a man’s arm or leg and then saying, ‘Let it be as it is.’”
author: Kim Barker

header: Russian Drone Damages Radiation Shield at Chernobyl, Ukraine Says
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called the damage “significant” but said there were no signs of radiation leaks. A Kremlin spokesman denied that Russia had carried out the strike.
author: Kim Barker, Andrew E. Kramer and Qasim Nauman

header: NATO Emphasizes Unity as Concerns Mount That Europe Will Be Left Out of Ukraine Talks
desc: President Trump has made it clear that he is pushing for an end to the war in Ukraine. The move has left Europe worried that it, and Ukraine, could be left out as he negotiates with Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin.
author: Jeanna Smialek and John Ismay

header: Trump Says Saudi Arabia May Host Talks With Vladimir Putin on Ukraine
desc: The kingdom has increasingly emerged as a mediator in the Russia-Ukraine war, leveraging ties with both sides as well as with President Trump.
author: Ismaeel Naar

header: Warming Trend in U.S.-Russia Relations Leaves Ukraine in a Tough Spot
desc: Trump’s recent moves, including a conversation with Putin and a demand for Ukrainian mineral rights, are worrisome signs for Zelensky.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Rejects U.S. Demand for Half of Its Mineral Resources
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky publicly faulted the American proposal because it did not include security guarantees.
author: Constant Méheut, Andrew E. Kramer, David E. Sanger and Eve Sampson

header: Left Out of Ukraine Talks, Europe Races to Organize a Response
desc: The Trump administration’s push for direct negotiations with Russia without Ukraine’s involvement leaves the European allies with no clear role.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Starmer Offers to Send U.K. Peacekeeping Troops to Ukraine
desc: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said for the first time on Sunday that he was “ready and willing” to deploy troops to help guarantee Ukraine’s security.
author: Yan Zhuang

header: German Chancellor Rebukes Vance for Supporting Party That Downplays Nazis
desc: At the Munich Security Conference, Olaf Scholz accused the U.S. vice president of unacceptable interference in Germany’s coming elections.
author: Jim Tankersley and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Former Charity Worker and Activist Faces an Unlikely Accusation: Coup Plotter
desc: A woman who runs a pro-Ukraine group has been accused by Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia of plotting to topple him as part of his campaign against organizations he says are funded from abroad.
author: Andrew Higgins

header: Putin Has Long Wanted More Power in Europe. Trump Could Grant It.
desc: Remarks by Vice President JD Vance and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth are fueling concerns that the U.S. will move away from Europe and align with Moscow.
author: Paul Sonne

header: Trump’s Ambition to Redraw the World Map Ignores Those Affected Most
desc: President Trump’s approach to foreign policy deals is reviving a bygone imperial approach that may backfire, experts say.
author: Mark Landler

header: A Quick, Quiet Trip to Belarus Signals a Turn in U.S. Policy
desc: After years of the U.S. trying to isolate Russia’s closest ally, a meeting with Belarus’s president points to better relations, raising hopes of loosening his repression and his embrace of Moscow.
author: Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus

header: Even in Death, Navalny Is Seen by the Kremlin as an Enduring Threat
desc: Russian authorities have zealously prosecuted people with links to Aleksei A. Navalny’s organization inside Russia in the year since he died.
author: Paul Sonne and Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: German Election Spotlight Turns to Trump
desc: The American president’s foreign policy, and a divisive speech by his vice president, drew attention away from an attack by a refugee that some expected would fan political tensions over migration.
author: Jim Tankersley

header: European Leaders Meet in Paris as U.S. Pushes Ahead With Ukraine Plan
desc: The hastily called gathering was part of a flurry of diplomacy expected to center on Ukraine this week as Trump officials prepare to start talks with Russia on their own.
author: Catherine Porter and Steven Erlanger

header: U.S. and Russia Pursue Partnership in a Head-Spinning Shift in Relations
desc: The two sides met in Saudi Arabia for their most extensive discussions in years. In addition to Ukraine, business ties were on the table.
author: Anton Troianovski and Ismaeel Naar

header: How Can It End? A Step-by-Step Guide to a Possible Ukraine Deal.
desc: Balancing Ukraine’s sovereignty with Russia’s demand for its own “security guarantees” promises to be the hardest part of any negotiation. But experts see possible compromises.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: After Walking a Fine Line With Trump, Zelensky Shows His Annoyance
desc: Left out of a meeting between American and Saudi officials, the Ukrainian leader also canceled a trip to Riyadh.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: Rubio Meets Saudi Crown Prince for Talks on Gaza and Ukraine
desc: Marco Rubio’s visit to Riyadh, his first as secretary of state, came amid uncertainty about the future of Gaza and Ukraine and criticism of unilateral U.S. moves over the wars in both places.
author: Patrick Kingsley and Ismaeel Naar

header: Europe’s Leaders, Dazed by an Ally Acting Like an Adversary, Recalculate
desc: Faced with undisguised hostility from the Trump administration, Europeans are preparing for what is shaping up to be a go-it-alone era.
author: Mark Landler

header: The Land Ukraine Could Be Forced to Give Up to End the War
desc: President Trump has promised to bring a quick end to the war in Ukraine, suggesting that Russia could keep at least some of the Ukrainian territory it had captured.
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Nikolay Nikolov, Laura Salaberry and Samuel Granados

header: U.S. and Russian Officials Agree to Work on Ukraine War Settlement
desc: After more than four hours of discussions in Saudi Arabia, both sides also agreed to work on normalizing bilateral relations and investments.
author: The New York Times

header: Zelensky and Trump Trade Blows as Feud Escalates Over Peace Talks
desc: President Trump called Volodymyr Zelensky a “dictator without elections” after the Ukrainian president said Mr. Trump was in a “web of disinformation.”
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukrainians, Stunned by Trump’s Comments, Fear They Can No Longer Trust U.S.
desc: President Trump’s claim that Ukraine was responsible for its war with Russia has left many Ukrainians disillusioned.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Trump Falsely Says Ukraine Started the War With Russia. Here Is What to Know.
desc: A look at how the war in Ukraine began, the state of the peace talks and why the country isn’t holding elections.
author: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Zelensky Meets U.S. Envoy to Ukraine Amid Public Feud With Trump
desc: Keith Kellogg and President Volodymyr Zelensky were expected to discuss possible paths to ending the war and ways to defuse tensions between Washington and Kyiv.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Bucha Has a Question: Does Trump Remember the Russian Massacre?
desc: Residents of a Ukrainian suburb that was the site of notorious attacks on civilians after Russia invaded are alarmed by President Trump’s warm words for Moscow.
author: Kim Barker

header: U.S. Objects to Calling Russia ‘Aggressor’ in G7 Statement on Invasion
desc: The American opposition to a draft of a Group of 7 statement marking the third anniversary of Russia’s attack on Ukraine comes after President Trump blamed Kyiv for starting the war.
author: Steven Erlanger, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and David E. Sanger

header: As Moscow and Washington Talk, Russians Hope the Result Is Normalcy
desc: Many people in Russia expressed relief that an end to the conflict in Ukraine seemed nearer and that the hardships of war, and the shunning of their country by much of the world, may soon end.
author: Ivan Nechepurenko, Nataliya Vasilyeva and Alina Lobzina

header: With Explosive Goggles, Ukraine Sought to Blast Russian Drone Operators
desc: A senior Ukrainian intelligence official confirmed the plot to blow up drone goggles. But it was unclear how much effect the scheme had on Russian forces.
author: Kim Barker and Michael Schwirtz

header: Meeting Again in Paris, European Leaders Try to Recalibrate After Trump Sides With Russia
desc: The American president’s latest remarks embracing Vladimir Putin’s narrative that Ukraine is to blame for the war have compounded the sense of alarm among traditional allies.
author: Catherine Porter and Andrew Higgins

header: Kremlin Message to Trump: There’s Money to Be Made in Russia
desc: Russian officials are arguing that American companies stand to make billions of dollars by re-entering Russia. The White House is listening.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: Russia Talks Peace While Troops Threaten New Region in Ukraine
desc: Moscow’s forces are three miles from Dnipropetrovsk, a province they have never invaded. If they cross in, the advance would be a morale blow to Ukraine and complicate any territorial negotiations.
author: Constant Méheut, Olha Konovalova and Tyler Hicks

header: U.S. Pressing Tough Demands in Revised Deal for Ukraine’s Minerals
desc: The Trump administration wants revenues from Ukraine’s natural resources, according to a draft obtained by The New York Times, with no security guarantee in exchange.
author: Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer

header: U.S. and Ukraine Appear to Move Closer to Deal for Minerals Amid Leaders’ Public Feud
desc: President Trump on Friday continued to bash President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and pressure him for mineral rights.
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Luke Broadwater

header: Emboldened Kremlin Steps Up Efforts to Seize Businesses in Russia
desc: The legal onslaught on Moscow’s second-largest airport has been seen as part of the Kremlin’s wartime drive to seize control of key assets still in private hands.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Shocked by Trump, Europe Turns Its Hopes to Germany’s Election
desc: Germany’s economy is stalled and its politics fractured. But it sees an opening for a new chancellor to lead Europe’s response to a changing America.
author: Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Germany’s Economy Was Once the Envy of Europe. Not Anymore
desc: Metrics reveal an economy sliding backward. It will be one of the biggest issues in the election set for Sunday.
author: Jim Tankersley and Josh Holder

header: On the Ropes, Olaf Scholz Keeps Punching
desc: The German chancellor, who defied calls to step aside after his government fell apart, is down in the polls but insisting he can still win.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Europe Vows to Step Up Baltic Sea Security After a New Cable Break
desc: The bloc announced new steps to prevent threats to undersea lines after Sweden discovered damage to one east of Gotland island.
author: Isabella Kwai, Christina Anderson and Johanna Lemola

header: Arab Leaders Scramble to Counter Trump’s Gaza Plans
desc: Leaders of Gulf states met with their Egyptian and Jordanian counterparts to strategize before a broader Arab summit early next month.
author: Ismaeel Naar

header: When Germany Votes, It Will Be About the Economy
desc: The country’s competitiveness has stagnated and its once-powerful industries are suffering. Just ask these executives.
author: Melissa Eddy and Jim Tankersley

header: Three Years Into War in Ukraine, Trump Ushers In New World for Putin
desc: Fresh possibilities have emerged for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with a change of power in Washington.
author: Paul Sonne

header: Europe Prepares to Face Russia as Trump’s America Steps Back
desc: European leaders visited Kyiv to mark the war’s third anniversary. The show of solidarity in Ukraine on Monday comes at a head-spinning moment for the continent.
author: Kim Barker, Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger

header: Zelensky Pushes Back Against U.S. Mineral Deal and Announces European Summit
desc: The Ukrainian leader also said he would step down if Ukraine was allowed to join NATO, though it was unclear if he was serious or not.
author: Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Officials Mark Ukraine War Anniversary With Resounding Silence
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is not scheduled to attend any events on Monday to mark the anniversary of the full-scale invasion that he ordered.
author: Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Zelensky Sets Somber Tone as Ukraine Marks War Anniversary
desc: For Ukrainians, Feb. 24 was a day to remember, without major ceremony, what has been lost in the three years since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
author: Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine Nears a Deal to Give U.S. a Share of Its Mineral Wealth
desc: President Trump said that Ukraine’s president may soon visit the White House to sign a deal, though how it ties in to efforts to end the Russian invasion and guarantee Ukraine’s security is unclear.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Fair or Not, Zelensky Is Angering Trump. Is His Style Hurting Ukraine?
desc: Through three years of wartime leadership, Ukraine’s president has mostly played weak hands wisely. But his approach has fallen flat with the Trump administration.
author: Andrew E. Kramer

header: U.S. and European Allies Split Sharply at the U.N. Over Ukraine
desc: The United States opposed a resolution demanding Russian withdrawal from Ukraine, but won Security Council approval of one calling for peace without assigning blame, exposing fissures between allies.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

header: In One Woman’s Life, the Story of Ukraine’s War, 3 Years On
desc: In treatment for cancer and with her husband in a Russian prison, Olha Kurtmallaieva, 25, worries that time may be running out for her and, possibly, her country.
author: Kim Barker

header: Putin Dangles Rare Earths Deals for U.S. in Russia and Occupied Ukraine
desc: In an interview broadcast on Monday, President Vladimir Putin said U.S. companies stood to profit in Russia, but suggested a Ukraine peace deal was still far off.
author: Anton Troianovski

header: U.S. and Ukraine Agree to Minerals Deal, Officials Say
desc: President Trump, who had insisted he wanted “payback” for past military aid to Kyiv, suggested President Volodymyr Zelensky would visit Washington this week to sign an agreement, which he called a “very big deal.”
author: Constant Méheut, Andrew E. Kramer and Alan Rappeport

header: The U.S.-Ukraine Mineral Deal: What We Know
desc: After a heated meeting in the White House, both sides have signaled that they are still open to reaching an agreement.
author: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut

header: Facing Trump’s Hostility, Ukraine Weighs Its Options. But They Are Few.
desc: There is a broad reckoning in Ukraine: Washington can no longer be relied upon as a supporter. But Kyiv still has agency on the battlefield and can seek increased support from Europe.
author: Constant Méheut

header: Taiwan Watches Trump Undercut Ukraine, Hoping It Won’t Be Next
desc: As President Trump turns toward Russia, Taiwan grapples with its reliance on U.S. support in the face of conflict with China.
author: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

header: Draft of Minerals Deal Features Vague Reference to Ukrainian Security
desc: A copy of the agreement obtained by The New York Times says that the United States “supports Ukraine’s effort to obtain security guarantees needed to establish lasting peace.”
author: Andrew E. Kramer and Constant Méheut

header: At Stake in Ukraine-Trump Deal: Titanium, Lithium and Rare Earths
desc: The country has a bounty of minerals and other natural resources, including gas and oil, but they may not be easy to extract.
author: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Trump’s Ukraine Mineral Deal Is Seen as ‘Protection Racket’ Diplomacy
desc: The United States wants to be paid in exchange for helping the country fend off an invader.
author: Amanda Taub

header: Rare Protest at U.S. Embassy in Ukraine Reflects Fears Over Trump
desc: The demonstration drew only a handful of people, but showed how some Ukrainians fear that Washington is drifting away from backing Ukraine now that President Trump is in power.
author: Kim Barker

header: How Can Europe Talk to Trump? Flatter, Then Gently Resist.
desc: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, epitomized how the continent’s leaders are trying to navigate President Trump’s increasingly hostile administration.
author: Jeanna Smialek and Aurelien Breeden

header: Starmer Flies to Meet Trump, With a Gift and a Difficult Message
desc: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain cut international aid to raise military spending. He’s hoping to make a case for Ukraine at the White House.
author: Mark Landler

header: Long Shunned, Pro-Russia Politicians in Ukraine See an Opening
desc: From prison and from exile, supporters of Moscow have been ramping up social media posts aimed at backing Russia’s call for elections in Ukraine and slamming President Volodymyr Zelensky.
